['NOTE', 'official', 'document', 'Indexademics', 'Unless', 'otherwise', 'stated', 'document', 'may', 'accredited', 'individuals', 'groups', 'club', 'IDX', 'document', 'distributed', 'sold', 'modified', 'personal', 'use', 'way']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Outgassing: -process in which water and water vapor emerge from the Earth's crust and below	['Outgassing', 'water', 'water', 'vapor', 'emerge', 'Earth', 'crust']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Eustasy: -changes in the global sea level caused by changes of water volume in the oceans	['Eustasy', 'global', 'sea', 'level', 'caused', 'changes', 'water', 'volume', 'oceans']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Hydrologic cycle: -the exchange & flow of all forms of water through Earth's lower atmosphere, hydrosphere, biosphere, and lithosphere	['Hydrologic', 'cycle', 'exchange', 'flow', 'forms', 'water', 'Earth', 'lower', 'atmosphere', 'hydrosphere', 'biosphere', 'lithosphere']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Evaporation: -net movement of free water molecules away from a wet surface into air that is less than saturated	['Evaporation', 'movement', 'free', 'water', 'molecules', 'away', 'wet', 'surface', 'air', 'less', 'saturated']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Transpiration: -when plants release water into the air from stomata in their leaves	['Transpiration', 'plants', 'release', 'water', 'air', 'stomata', 'leaves']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Evapotranspiration: -made up of evaporation and transpiration over land	['Evapotranspiration', 'evaporation', 'transpiration', 'land']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Interception: -when precipitation lands on vegetation before going into the ground	['Interception', 'precipitation', 'lands', 'vegetation', 'going', 'ground']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Stem flow: -intercepted water that drains down the stems of plants	['Stem', 'flow', 'water', 'drains', 'stems', 'plants']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Throughfall: -precipitation that falls directly to the ground or that drips from leaves	['Throughfall', 'falls', 'directly', 'ground', 'drips', 'leaves']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Infiltration: -water soaking into the soil	['Infiltration', 'soaking', 'soil']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Overland flow/Surface runoff: -water that does not soak into the soil and that goes downhill	['Overland', 'runoff', 'soak', 'soil', 'goes', 'downhill']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Streamflow: -when overland flow starts to flow in channels	['Streamflow', 'overland', 'flow', 'starts', 'flow', 'channels']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Percolation: -water that has already infiltrated into the soil moving downwards	['Percolation', 'already', 'infiltrated', 'soil', 'moving', 'downwards']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Soil moisture zone: -volume of subsurface water stored in the soil that is accessible to plant roots	['Soil', 'moisture', 'zone', 'subsurface', 'water', 'stored', 'soil', 'accessible', 'plant', 'roots']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Base flow: -place where water table intersects a stream channel	['Base', 'flow', 'water', 'table', 'intersects', 'stream', 'channel']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Water budget: -derived from precipitation and soil moisture (if any) - evapotranspiration 	['Water', 'budget', 'precipitation', 'soil', 'moisture', 'evapotranspiration']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Surplus: -extra water that remains after expenditure demands are met	['Surplus', 'water', 'remains', 'expenditure', 'demands', 'met']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Deficit: -when precipitation and soil moisture is insufficient to meet demands	['Deficit', 'precipitation', 'soil', 'moisture', 'insufficient', 'meet', 'demands']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Precipitation: -moisture supply to Earth's surface	['Precipitation', 'supply', 'Earth', 'surface']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Potential evapotranspiration: -amount of water that would evaporate & transpire with optimum moisture conditions	['Potential', 'evapotranspiration', 'water', 'would', 'evaporate', 'transpire', 'optimum', 'moisture', 'conditions']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Actual evapotranspiration: -potential evapotranspiration - deficit. Gives the amount of water that is actually lost through evapotranspiration.	['Actual', 'evapotranspiration', 'evapotranspiration', 'deficit', 'Gives', 'amount', 'water', 'actually', 'lost', 'evapotranspiration']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Soil moisture storage: -same as soil moisture zone. Volume of subsurface water stored in the soil that is accessible to plant roots	['Soil', 'moisture', 'storage', 'soil', 'moisture', 'zone', 'Volume', 'subsurface', 'water', 'stored', 'soil', 'accessible', 'plant', 'roots']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Hygroscopic water: -inaccessible water to plants. Exists in all climates.	['Hygroscopic', 'water', 'water', 'plants', 'Exists', 'climates']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Wilting point: -when the only water left is inaccessible. Kills off plants	['Wilting', 'point', 'water', 'left', 'inaccessible', 'Kills', 'plants']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Capillary water: -accessible water to plants. Held in soil by surface tension	['Capillary', 'water', 'water', 'plants', 'Held', 'soil', 'surface', 'tension']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Field capacity: -storage capacity. Maximum amount of water that a specific kind of soil can hold that's available to plants	['Field', 'capacity', 'capacity', 'Maximum', 'amount', 'water', 'specific', 'kind', 'soil', 'hold', 'available', 'plants']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Porosity: -available pore spaces	['Porosity', 'pore', 'spaces']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Gravitational water: -water surplus in the soil body after the soil becomds saturated	['Gravitational', 'water', 'surplus', 'soil', 'body', 'soil', 'becomds', 'saturated']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Soil moisture utilization: -usage by plants of the available moisture in the soil	['Soil', 'moisture', 'utilization', 'plants', 'available', 'moisture', 'soil']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Soil moisture recharge: -when water infiltrates the soil and replenishes available water	['Soil', 'moisture', 'recharge', 'water', 'infiltrates', 'soil', 'replenishes', 'available', 'water']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Permeability: -property of the soil that determines the rate of recharge	['Permeability', 'soil', 'determines', 'rate', 'recharge']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Droughts:	['Droughts']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36		Meteorological drought: -defined by degree of dryness compared to the regional average. Region specific.	['Meteorological', 'drought', 'degree', 'dryness', 'compared', 'regional', 'average', 'Region', 'specific']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36		Agricultural drought: -when shortages of precipitation and moisture affect crop yields	['Agricultural', 'drought', 'shortages', 'precipitation', 'moisture', 'affect', 'crop', 'yields']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36		Hydrological drought: -effects of precipitation shortages on water supply	['Hydrological', 'drought', 'precipitation', 'shortages', 'water', 'supply']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36		Socioeconomic drought: -when reduced water supply causes the demand for goods/services to exceed it	['Socioeconomic', 'drought', 'reduced', 'water', 'supply', 'causes', 'demand', 'exceed']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Hydropower: -electricity generated using the power of moving water	['Hydropower', 'generated', 'using', 'power', 'moving', 'water']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Wetland: -area that is permanently/seasonally saturated with water	['Wetland', 'saturated', 'water']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Groundwater: -water below the surface	['Groundwater', 'surface']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Zone of aeration: -layer where soil and rock are less than saturated	['Zone', 'aeration', 'soil', 'rock', 'less', 'saturated']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Zone of saturation: -layer where soil and rock are completely saturated	['Zone', 'saturation', 'soil', 'rock', 'completely', 'saturated']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Water table: -point of transition between these two zones	['Water', 'table', 'transition', 'two', 'zones']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Aquifer: - subsurface layer of permeable rock or unconsolidated materials (silt, sand, or gravels) through which groundwater can flow in amounts adequate for wells and springs.	['Aquifer', 'subsurface', 'layer', 'permeable', 'rock', 'unconsolidated', 'materials', 'silt', 'sand', 'gravels', 'groundwater', 'flow', 'amounts', 'adequate', 'wells', 'springs']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Aquiclude: - the impermeable layer of rock below the groundwater.	['Aquiclude', 'impermeable', 'layer', 'rock', 'groundwater']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Unconfined Aquifer: - has a permeable layer above and an impermeable layer (aquiclude) below.	['Unconfined', 'Aquifer', 'permeable', 'layer', 'impermeable', 'layer', 'aquiclude']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Confined Aquifer: - has impermeable layers both above and below.	['Confined', 'Aquifer', 'impermeable', 'layers']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Potentiometric Surface: - a pressure level created by the pressure on the water in a confined aquifer.	['Potentiometric', 'Surface', 'pressure', 'level', 'created', 'pressure', 'water', 'confined', 'aquifer']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Wells:	['Wells']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	- Ordinary Well: drilled into an unconfined aquifer; the water is not under pressure and so does not rise, rather needing to be pumped up.	['Ordinary', 'Well', 'drilled', 'unconfined', 'aquifer', 'water', 'pressure', 'rise', 'rather', 'needing', 'pumped']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	- Artesian Well: drilled into a confined aquifer; the water rises to the potentiometric surface.	['Artesian', 'Well', 'drilled', 'confined', 'aquifer', 'water', 'rises', 'potentiometric', 'surface']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	- Gushing Artesian Well: an artesian well whose top is lower than the potentiometric surface, causing the water to rise up out of the well.	['Gushing', 'Artesian', 'Well', 'artesian', 'well', 'whose', 'top', 'lower', 'potentiometric', 'surface', 'causing', 'water', 'rise', 'well']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Drawdown: - lowering of the water table of an unconfined aquifer; occurs when the rate of pumping water from a well exceeds the rate the water can replenish itself.	['Drawdown', 'lowering', 'water', 'table', 'unconfined', 'aquifer', 'occurs', 'rate', 'pumping', 'water', 'well', 'exceeds', 'rate', 'water', 'replenish']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Cone of Depression: - the lowered water table around the well forms a cone of depression.	['Cone', 'Depression', 'lowered', 'water', 'table', 'around', 'well', 'forms', 'cone', 'depression']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Water Withdrawal (Nonconsumptive Use): - removal or diversion of water from surface/groundwater supplies followed by the subsequent return of that water to the same supply; e.g. water use by industry, agriculture, and in steam-electric power generation (a portion of the water withdrawn may be consumed but not all).	['Water', 'Withdrawal', 'Nonconsumptive', 'Use', 'removal', 'diversion', 'water', 'supplies', 'followed', 'subsequent', 'return', 'water', 'supply', 'water', 'use', 'industry', 'agriculture', 'power', 'generation', 'portion', 'water', 'withdrawn', 'may', 'consumed']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Consumptive Use: - permanent removal of water from the immediate water environment; this water is not returned and so is not available for a second/third use; e.g. water lost to evapotranspiration, consumed by humans/livestock, or used in manufacturing.	['Consumptive', 'Use', 'permanent', 'removal', 'water', 'immediate', 'water', 'environment', 'water', 'returned', 'available', 'use', 'water', 'lost', 'evapotranspiration', 'consumed', 'used', 'manufacturing']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	GROUNDWATER CONTAMINATION ARTICLE	['GROUNDWATER', 'CONTAMINATION', 'ARTICLE']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	(You only need to know 2-3 of these with examples for short answer!)	['need', 'know', 'examples', 'short', 'answer']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Natural Sources: - some substances found naturally in rocks or soils (e.g. arsenic, chlorides, iron) can become dissolved in groundwater, and other naturally occurring substances (e.g. decaying matter) can move in groundwater. Some of these substances can pose health threats if consumed excessively, others can bring undesirable odors/tastes/colors.	['Natural', 'Sources', 'substances', 'found', 'naturally', 'rocks', 'soils', 'arsenic', 'chlorides', 'iron', 'become', 'dissolved', 'groundwater', 'naturally', 'occurring', 'substances', 'decaying', 'matter', 'move', 'groundwater', 'substances', 'pose', 'health', 'threats', 'consumed', 'excessively', 'others', 'bring', 'undesirable']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Septic Systems: - outflow from septic tanks, cesspools, and privies can contaminate groundwater. The large number and widespread use of septic systems make them a serious contamination source. Improperly sited, designed, constructed, or maintained septic systems can contaminate groundwater with bacteria, viruses, nitrates, oils, detergents, and chemicals. Septic system cleaners can also contaminate wells. Many regulations require specific distances between septic systems and drinking water wells.	['Septic', 'Systems', 'outflow', 'septic', 'tanks', 'cesspools', 'privies', 'contaminate', 'groundwater', 'large', 'number', 'widespread', 'use', 'septic', 'systems', 'make', 'serious', 'contamination', 'source', 'Improperly', 'sited', 'designed', 'constructed', 'maintained', 'septic', 'systems', 'contaminate', 'groundwater', 'bacteria', 'viruses', 'nitrates', 'oils', 'detergents', 'chemicals', 'Septic', 'system', 'cleaners', 'also', 'contaminate', 'wells', 'Many', 'regulations', 'require', 'specific', 'distances', 'septic', 'systems', 'drinking', 'water', 'wells']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Improper Disposal of Hazardous Waste: - hazardous waste should always be disposed of properly. Many chemicals should not be disposed of in household septic systems (e.g. oils, garden chemicals, paint); and many industrial substances should not be disposed of in drains at the workplace they could contaminate drinking water sources. Industries use large varieties and quantities of chemicals, and therefore proper disposal is extremely important.	['Improper', 'Disposal', 'Hazardous', 'Waste', 'hazardous', 'waste', 'always', 'disposed', 'properly', 'Many', 'chemicals', 'disposed', 'household', 'septic', 'systems', 'oils', 'garden', 'chemicals', 'paint', 'many', 'industrial', 'substances', 'disposed', 'drains', 'workplace', 'could', 'contaminate', 'drinking', 'water', 'sources', 'Industries', 'use', 'large', 'varieties', 'quantities', 'chemicals', 'therefore', 'proper', 'disposal', 'extremely', 'important']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Releases and Spills from Stored Chemicals and Petroleum Products: - storage tanks can leak due to age and corrosion. If an underground storage tank leaks, the contents can travel through the soil and reach the groundwater underneath; abandoned underground storage tanks are also dangerous as their location is often unknown. Leaks of aboveground tanks can also contaminate groundwater if there are no adequate barriers in place. Tanker trucks and train cars also pose hazards if they spill/leak.	['Releases', 'Spills', 'Stored', 'Chemicals', 'Petroleum', 'Products', 'storage', 'tanks', 'leak', 'due', 'age', 'corrosion', 'underground', 'storage', 'tank', 'leaks', 'contents', 'travel', 'soil', 'reach', 'groundwater', 'underneath', 'abandoned', 'underground', 'storage', 'tanks', 'also', 'dangerous', 'location', 'often', 'unknown', 'Leaks', 'aboveground', 'tanks', 'also', 'contaminate', 'groundwater', 'adequate', 'barriers', 'place', 'Tanker', 'trucks', 'train', 'cars', 'also', 'pose', 'hazards']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Landfills: - disposal of hazardous chemicals in municipal landfills and unregulated household waste disposal pose threats. Chemicals leach into the ground through precipitation and surface runoff. If landfills are not sealed/capped correctly, there is also a danger of the chemicals leaching into the ground.	['Landfills', 'disposal', 'hazardous', 'chemicals', 'municipal', 'landfills', 'unregulated', 'household', 'waste', 'disposal', 'pose', 'threats', 'Chemicals', 'leach', 'ground', 'precipitation', 'surface', 'runoff', 'landfills', 'correctly', 'also', 'danger', 'chemicals', 'leaching', 'ground']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Surface Impoundments: - shallow ponds/lagoons that store, treat, and dispose of liquid wastes. Required to have liners, but the liners sometimes leak.	['Surface', 'Impoundments', 'shallow', 'store', 'treat', 'dispose', 'liquid', 'wastes', 'Required', 'liners', 'liners', 'sometimes', 'leak']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Sewers and Other Pipelines: - sewer pipes sometimes leak fluids into surrounding soil and groundwater. Pipelines carrying industrial chemicals and oil brine can also leak, especially when the materials being transported are corrosive.	['Sewers', 'Pipelines', 'sewer', 'pipes', 'sometimes', 'leak', 'fluids', 'surrounding', 'soil', 'groundwater', 'Pipelines', 'carrying', 'industrial', 'chemicals', 'oil', 'brine', 'also', 'leak', 'especially', 'materials', 'transported', 'corrosive']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Pesticides and Fertilizer Use: - pesticides and fertilizers (some highly toxic) can enter and contaminate groundwater following normal, registered use. (there’s a bunch of data in the article and I don’t want to put it all here so you can go see for yourself)	['Pesticides', 'Fertilizer', 'Use', 'pesticides', 'fertilizers', 'highly', 'toxic', 'enter', 'contaminate', 'groundwater', 'following', 'normal', 'registered', 'use', 'bunch', 'data', 'article', 'want', 'put', 'go', 'see']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Drainage Wells: - used in wet areas to help drain water and transport it to deeper soils; may contain agricultural chemicals and bacteria.	['Drainage', 'Wells', 'used', 'wet', 'areas', 'help', 'drain', 'water', 'transport', 'deeper', 'soils', 'may', 'contain', 'agricultural', 'chemicals', 'bacteria']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Injection Wells/Floor Drains: - injection wells are used to collect storm water runoff, collect spilled liquids, and dispose of wastes. Floor drain usage by businesses is regulated by the government, and wells that pose potential threats are closed or connected to public sewage systems/storage tanks.	['Injection', 'Drains', 'injection', 'wells', 'used', 'collect', 'storm', 'water', 'runoff', 'collect', 'spilled', 'liquids', 'dispose', 'wastes', 'Floor', 'drain', 'usage', 'businesses', 'regulated', 'government', 'wells', 'pose', 'potential', 'threats', 'closed', 'connected', 'public', 'sewage', 'tanks']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Improperly Constructed Wells: - groundwater contamination results when contaminated surface/ground water is introduced into the well.	['Improperly', 'Constructed', 'Wells', 'groundwater', 'contamination', 'results', 'contaminated', 'water', 'introduced', 'well']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Improperly Abandoned Wells: - contaminants may reach aquifer through these wells is the casing is removed/corroded. Some people dispose of wastes in these wells. These wells may reach into an aquifer.	['Improperly', 'Abandoned', 'Wells', 'contaminants', 'may', 'reach', 'aquifer', 'wells', 'casing', 'people', 'dispose', 'wastes', 'wells', 'wells', 'may', 'reach', 'aquifer']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Active Drinking Water Supply Wells: - construction problems (e.g. faulty casings, inadequate covers) allow outside water/contaminants to enter the well.	['Active', 'Drinking', 'Water', 'Supply', 'Wells', 'construction', 'problems', 'faulty', 'casings', 'inadequate', 'covers', 'allow', 'outside', 'enter', 'well']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Poorly Constructed Irrigation Wells: - can allow contaminants to enter groundwater; often pesticides and fertilizers are used in immediate vicinity of wells on agricultural land.	['Poorly', 'Constructed', 'Irrigation', 'Wells', 'allow', 'contaminants', 'enter', 'groundwater', 'often', 'pesticides', 'fertilizers', 'used', 'immediate', 'vicinity', 'wells', 'agricultural', 'land']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Mining Activities: - precipitation can leach soluble minerals from mine wastes into groundwater below. Mines are also sometimes pumped to keep them dry; pumping can cause contaminated groundwater to move upward, potentially contaminating wells.	['Mining', 'Activities', 'precipitation', 'leach', 'soluble', 'minerals', 'mine', 'wastes', 'groundwater', 'Mines', 'also', 'sometimes', 'pumped', 'keep', 'dry', 'pumping', 'cause', 'contaminated', 'groundwater', 'move', 'upward', 'potentially', 'contaminating', 'wells']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Effects of Groundwater Contamination (for everyone!): - can result in poor drinking water quality, loss of water supply, degraded surface water systems, high cleanup costs, high costs for alternative water supplies, and/or potential health problems. Contamination can remain undetected for long periods of time because groundwater moves slowly, making cleanup difficult. Cleanup, if undertaken, can also be costly and expensive. There are many different cleanup strategies and they are selected based on on-site factors. Drinking contaminated water can result in illnesses such as hepatitis, cholera, giardiasis, or methemoglobinemia (“blue baby syndrome”). Benzene, a component of gasoline, is a human carcinogen.	['Effects', 'Groundwater', 'Contamination', 'everyone', 'result', 'poor', 'drinking', 'water', 'quality', 'loss', 'water', 'supply', 'degraded', 'surface', 'water', 'systems', 'high', 'cleanup', 'costs', 'high', 'costs', 'alternative', 'water', 'supplies', 'potential', 'health', 'problems', 'Contamination', 'remain', 'undetected', 'long', 'periods', 'time', 'groundwater', 'moves', 'slowly', 'making', 'cleanup', 'difficult', 'Cleanup', 'undertaken', 'also', 'costly', 'expensive', 'many', 'different', 'cleanup', 'strategies', 'selected', 'based', 'factors', 'Drinking', 'contaminated', 'water', 'result', 'illnesses', 'hepatitis', 'cholera', 'giardiasis', 'methemoglobinemia', 'blue', 'baby', 'syndrome', 'Benzene', 'component', 'gasoline', 'human', 'carcinogen']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Regulations to Protect Groundwater: - (a lot of acts and organizations that I won’t list so you can read it yourself)	['Regulations', 'Protect', 'Groundwater', 'lot', 'acts', 'organizations', 'list', 'read']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	WATER DESALINATION ARTICLE	['WATER', 'DESALINATION', 'ARTICLE']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Environmental concerns of water desalination include trapping and killing sea life, which negatively affects the marine ecosystem of the area where seawater is drawn in. Subsurface intakes fix this problem by drawing water from beneath dunes, far away from any sea life. 	['Environmental', 'concerns', 'water', 'desalination', 'include', 'trapping', 'killing', 'sea', 'life', 'negatively', 'affects', 'marine', 'ecosystem', 'area', 'seawater', 'drawn', 'Subsurface', 'intakes', 'fix', 'problem', 'drawing', 'water', 'beneath', 'dunes', 'far', 'away', 'sea', 'life']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36		Another environmental concern can include how the brine left over after the desalination process is disposed of. If dumped straight into the ocean, it can kill off organisms on the seabed. Proposed solutions to this include spraying it into the ocean or running it through a very long pipe with holes spaced out.	['Another', 'environmental', 'concern', 'include', 'brine', 'left', 'desalination', 'process', 'disposed', 'dumped', 'straight', 'ocean', 'kill', 'organisms', 'seabed', 'Proposed', 'solutions', 'include', 'spraying', 'ocean', 'running', 'long', 'pipe', 'holes', 'spaced']
5 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	An economic concern of the water desalination process would be the large amount of energy required to pump seawater through membranes to filter out the salt, since a lot of pressure is needed — one solution to this is to power the plant using renewable energy sources (using methane from a landfill is mentioned in the article)	['economic', 'concern', 'water', 'desalination', 'process', 'would', 'large', 'amount', 'energy', 'required', 'pump', 'seawater', 'membranes', 'filter', 'salt', 'since', 'lot', 'pressure', 'needed', 'one', 'solution', 'power', 'plant', 'using', 'renewable', 'energy', 'sources', 'using', 'methane', 'landfill', 'mentioned', 'article']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	NOTE: This is an official document by Indexademics. Unless otherwise stated, this document may not be accredited to individuals or groups other than the club IDX, nor should this document be distributed, sold, or modified for personal use in any way.	['NOTE', 'official', 'document', 'Indexademics', 'Unless', 'otherwise', 'stated', 'document', 'may', 'accredited', 'individuals', 'groups', 'club', 'IDX', 'document', 'distributed', 'sold', 'modified', 'personal', 'use', 'way']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—air pressure: weight of the atmosphere. depends on motion, size, number of molecules.	['pressure', 'weight', 'atmosphere', 'depends', 'motion', 'size', 'number', 'molecules']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36		—temperature increases-> spacing between molecules increases -> density decreases -> air pressure decreases	['spacing', 'molecules', 'increases', 'density', 'decreases', 'air', 'pressure', 'decreases']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—water vapor content increases-> mass decreases (water vapor is lighter than dry air) -> density decreases –> air pressure decreases	['vapor', 'content', 'mass', 'decreases', 'water', 'vapor', 'lighter', 'dry', 'air', 'density', 'decreases', 'air', 'pressure', 'decreases']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36			—warm, humid air = low pressure	['humid', 'air', 'low', 'pressure']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36			—cold, dry air = high pressure	['dry', 'air', 'high', 'pressure']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—wind: horizontal motion of air across earth’s surface	['horizontal', 'motion', 'air', 'across', 'earth', 'surface']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—anemometer: measures wind speed	['measures', 'wind', 'speed']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—wind vane: measures wind direction	['vane', 'measures', 'wind', 'direction']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36		—winds are named for the direction from which they originate	['named', 'direction', 'originate']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—wind is determined by:	['determined']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36			—gravitational force: counteracts centrifugal force	['force', 'counteracts', 'centrifugal', 'force']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—pressure gradient force: drives air from areas of higher pressure to lower pressure	['gradient', 'force', 'drives', 'air', 'areas', 'higher', 'pressure', 'lower', 'pressure']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36				—gradient: rate of change in some property over distance	['rate', 'change', 'property', 'distance']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36				—PGF exists because earth is unevenly heated	['exists', 'earth', 'unevenly', 'heated']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36				—also created by vertical air movement	['created', 'vertical', 'air', 'movement']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—isobar: isoline plotted on a map to connect points of equal pressure	['isoline', 'plotted', 'map', 'connect', 'points', 'equal', 'pressure']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—closer isobars -> higher PGF -> faster winds (and vice versa)	['isobars', 'higher', 'PGF', 'faster', 'winds', 'vice', 'versa']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—coriolis force: deflective force that makes wind traveling in a straight path appear to be deflected in relation to the earth’s surface	['force', 'deflective', 'force', 'makes', 'wind', 'traveling', 'straight', 'path', 'appear', 'deflected', 'relation', 'earth', 'surface']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36			—caused by earth’s rotation	['earth', 'rotation']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36			—on a nonrotating earth, winds would move in a straight line	['nonrotating', 'earth', 'winds', 'would', 'move', 'straight', 'line']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36		—objects deflected to right in northern hemisphere and to the left in southern hemisphere	['deflected', 'right', 'northern', 'hemisphere', 'left', 'southern', 'hemisphere']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36				—weakest at equator and strongest at poles	['equator', 'strongest', 'poles']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—deflection occurs regardless of the direction in which the object is moving	['occurs', 'regardless', 'direction', 'object', 'moving']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—deflection increases as the speed of the moving object increases	['increases', 'speed', 'moving', 'object', 'increases']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—does not affect small-scale motions	['affect', 'motions']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—winds spiral to the right in the northern hemisphere and to the left in the southern hemisphere	['spiral', 'right', 'northern', 'hemisphere', 'left', 'southern', 'hemisphere']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36		—friction force: drags on the wind as it moves across earth’s surface	['force', 'drags', 'wind', 'moves', 'across', 'earth', 'surface']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36			—decreases with height above surface	['height', 'surface']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—without friction, surface winds would move in paths parallel to isobars at high rates of speed	['friction', 'surface', 'winds', 'would', 'move', 'paths', 'parallel', 'isobars', 'high', 'rates', 'speed']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—geostrophic winds: winds that do not flow directly from high to low, instead flowing around the pressure areas, remaining parallel to the isobars.	['winds', 'winds', 'flow', 'directly', 'high', 'low', 'instead', 'flowing', 'around', 'pressure', 'areas', 'remaining', 'parallel', 'isobars']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—cyclone: low pressure	['low', 'pressure']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—counterclockwise in the northern hemisphere and clockwise in the southern hemisphere	['northern', 'hemisphere', 'clockwise', 'southern', 'hemisphere']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—anticyclone: high pressure (cannot be observed)	['high', 'pressure', 'observed']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	— clockwise in the northern hemisphere and anticlockwise in the southern hemisphere	['clockwise', 'northern', 'hemisphere', 'anticlockwise', 'southern', 'hemisphere']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—primary circulation: general worldwide circulation	['circulation', 'general', 'worldwide', 'circulation']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—secondary circulation: migratory high-pressure and low-pressure systems	['circulation', 'migratory', 'systems']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—tertiary circulation: local winds & temporal weather patterns	['circulation', 'local', 'winds', 'temporal', 'weather', 'patterns']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—meridional flows: winds that move n/s along meridians of longitude	['flows', 'winds', 'move', 'along', 'meridians', 'longitude']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—zonal flows: winds that move w/e along parallels	['flows', 'winds', 'move', 'along', 'parallels']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—equatorial low: (10° n - 10° s): forms the ITCZ, which is identified by bands of clouds.	['low', 'n', 'forms', 'ITCZ', 'identified', 'bands', 'clouds']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—subtropical high (20-35° n/s): caused by dynamic factors instead of thermal factors.	['high', 'caused', 'dynamic', 'factors', 'instead', 'thermal', 'factors']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36		—dynamic factor: caused by the physical displacement of air	['factor', 'caused', 'physical', 'displacement', 'air']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—subpolar low (60° n/s): also caused by dynamic factors	['low', 'also', 'caused', 'dynamic', 'factors']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—polar high (90° n/s): weaker than subtropical high.	['high', 'weaker', 'subtropical', 'high']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—trade winds: winds converging at the equatorial low	['winds', 'winds', 'converging', 'equatorial', 'low']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—northeast in northern hemisphere and southeast in southern hemisphere.	['northern', 'hemisphere', 'southeast', 'southern', 'hemisphere']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—hadley cells: from ITCZ to subtropical high. trade winds are caused by air returning from the subtropical high to the ITCZ.	['cells', 'ITCZ', 'subtropical', 'high', 'trade', 'winds', 'caused', 'air', 'returning', 'subtropical', 'high', 'ITCZ']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36		—doldrums: equatorial calms	['equatorial', 'calms']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—horse latitudes: calms at 25° n/s, caused by sinking cool dry air	['latitudes', 'calms', 'caused', 'sinking', 'cool', 'dry', 'air']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—westerlies: surface air diverging within the subtropical high-pressure cells	['surface', 'air', 'diverging', 'within', 'subtropical', 'cells']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36		—stronger in summer, weaker in winter	['summer', 'weaker', 'winter']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36		—less consistent than trade winds	['consistent', 'trade', 'winds']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—polar easterlies: cold + dry winds moving away from the polar region in an anticyclonic direction	['easterlies', 'cold', 'dry', 'winds', 'moving', 'away', 'polar', 'region', 'anticyclonic', 'direction']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—weak and variable	['variable']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—polar front: area between cold air from higher latitudes and warm air from lower latitudes	['front', 'area', 'cold', 'air', 'higher', 'latitudes', 'warm', 'air', 'lower', 'latitudes']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—antarctic high: stronger than the arctic high because of antarctica’s larger landmass	['high', 'stronger', 'arctic', 'high', 'antarctica', 'larger', 'landmass']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—rossby waves: occur along the polar front where colder air meets warmer air. cold air moves southwards and warmer air moves northwards	['waves', 'occur', 'along', 'polar', 'front', 'colder', 'air', 'meets', 'warmer', 'air', 'cold', 'air', 'moves', 'southwards', 'warmer', 'air', 'moves', 'northwards']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—jet stream: upper-level westerly geostrophic winds	['stream', 'westerly', 'geostrophic', 'winds']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36		—irregular, concentrated	['concentrated']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36		—weaken in summer and strengthen in winter	['summer', 'strengthen', 'winter']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36		—polar jet stream: 30°-70° n	['jet', 'stream', 'n']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36		—subtropical jet stream: 20°-50° n	['jet', 'stream', 'n']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—monsoons: seasonally shifting wind systems	['seasonally', 'shifting', 'wind', 'systems']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—Asian monsoon: caused by uneven heating of landmass compared to the ocean in the summer, so hot air from the landmasses blow towards the oceans while cool air from the oceans blow to these landmasses. 	['monsoon', 'caused', 'uneven', 'heating', 'landmass', 'compared', 'ocean', 'summer', 'hot', 'air', 'landmasses', 'blow', 'towards', 'oceans', 'cool', 'air', 'oceans', 'blow', 'landmasses']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—land/sea breeze: local winds produced along most coastlines. Caused by the same thing but on a smaller scale.	['breeze', 'local', 'winds', 'produced', 'along', 'coastlines', 'Caused', 'thing', 'smaller', 'scale']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—mountain/valley breezes: local winds resulting when mountain air cools at night and when valley air gains heat energy during the day.	['breezes', 'local', 'winds', 'resulting', 'mountain', 'air', 'cools', 'night', 'valley', 'air', 'gains', 'heat', 'energy', 'day']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—ocean currents: driven by frictional drag of winds over water	['currents', 'driven', 'frictional', 'drag', 'winds', 'water']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—caused by differences in temperature, salinity, configuration of the continents and ocean floor, and tides	['differences', 'temperature', 'salinity', 'configuration', 'continents', 'ocean', 'floor', 'tides']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—western intensification: surface currents approaching the western bits of oceans and piling up on the eastern shores of continents	['intensification', 'surface', 'currents', 'approaching', 'western', 'bits', 'oceans', 'piling', 'eastern', 'shores', 'continents']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—upwelling current: where surface water is swept away from a coast either by surface divergence or by offshore winds	['current', 'surface', 'water', 'swept', 'away', 'coast', 'either', 'surface', 'divergence', 'offshore', 'winds']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—downwelling current: where excess water gravitates downwards	['current', 'excess', 'water', 'gravitates', 'downwards']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—thermohaline circulation: density differences causing the flow of deep currents	['circulation', 'density', 'differences', 'causing', 'flow', 'deep', 'currents']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36		—slower than surface currents but moves larger volumes of water	['surface', 'currents', 'moves', 'larger', 'volumes', 'water']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—ENSO: El Nino Southern Oscillation: system fluctuations that occurs in a multiyear period. Affects temperatures and air pressure patterns, in turn affecting global winds and climates.	['El', 'Nino', 'Southern', 'Oscillation', 'system', 'fluctuations', 'occurs', 'multiyear', 'period', 'Affects', 'temperatures', 'air', 'pressure', 'patterns', 'turn', 'affecting', 'global', 'winds', 'climates']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36		—normally the eastern waters of the south pacific are cold and the western bit warm.	['eastern', 'waters', 'south', 'pacific', 'cold', 'western', 'bit', 'warm']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36		—sometimes this changes, and the eastern waters warm up, so a low pressure point develops there.	['changes', 'eastern', 'waters', 'warm', 'low', 'pressure', 'point', 'develops']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36		—trade winds normally moving from east to west weaken and can even be replaced by an eastward flow.	['winds', 'normally', 'moving', 'east', 'west', 'weaken', 'even', 'replaced', 'eastward', 'flow']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36		—during El Nino conditions, the thermocline (transition layer between wars/cool waters) lowers in depth, preventing upwelling	['El', 'Nino', 'conditions', 'thermocline', 'transition', 'layer', 'waters', 'lowers', 'depth', 'preventing', 'upwelling']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36		—occurs once every 2-12 years, most commonly 3-5 years.	['every', 'years', 'commonly', 'years']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—La Nina: when the neutral condition’s locations of low/high pressure and warm/cool waters are maintained, but at a more extreme level.	['Nina', 'neutral', 'condition', 'locations', 'pressure', 'waters', 'maintained', 'extreme', 'level']
3 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36		—weaker and less consistent that El Nino	['less', 'consistent', 'El', 'Nino']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	NOTE: This is an official document by Indexademics. Unless otherwise stated, this document may not be accredited to individuals or groups other than the club IDX, nor should this document be distributed, sold, or modified for personal use in any way.	['NOTE', 'official', 'document', 'Indexademics', 'Unless', 'otherwise', 'stated', 'document', 'may', 'accredited', 'individuals', 'groups', 'club', 'IDX', 'document', 'distributed', 'sold', 'modified', 'personal', 'use', 'way']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	KARST TOPOGRAPHY:	['KARST', 'TOPOGRAPHY']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Formation of Karst: - chemical erosion (permeable limestone + weak carbonic acid = soluble bicarbonate ion and calcium ion) (weak carbonic acid formed by H2O and CO2).	['Formation', 'Karst', 'chemical', 'erosion', 'permeable', 'limestone', 'weak', 'carbonic', 'acid', 'soluble', 'bicarbonate', 'ion', 'calcium', 'ion', 'weak', 'carbonic', 'acid', 'formed']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Essential Conditions for Karst Formation: - massive, thickly bedded, highly soluble rocks (e.g. limestone) – aerated zone (so that surface drainage may disappear through sinks to have subsurface drainage so that caves and passages may be formed)								    - joints in impermeable limestone									    - flowing groundwater										    - high humidity (enough rainfall)									    - warm climate											    - green covers (produce organic acid)	['Essential', 'Conditions', 'Karst', 'Formation', 'massive', 'thickly', 'bedded', 'highly', 'soluble', 'rocks', 'limestone', 'aerated', 'zone', 'surface', 'drainage', 'may', 'disappear', 'sinks', 'subsurface', 'drainage', 'caves', 'passages', 'may', 'formed', 'joints', 'impermeable', 'limestone', 'flowing', 'groundwater', 'high', 'humidity', 'enough', 'rainfall', 'warm', 'climate', 'green', 'covers', 'produce', 'organic', 'acid']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Joints: - small cracks in the Earth’s crust, no movement; formed when rocks are compressed or stretched to their breaking point; rarely pose any threat to civilization.	['Joints', 'small', 'cracks', 'Earth', 'crust', 'movement', 'formed', 'rocks', 'compressed', 'stretched', 'breaking', 'point', 'rarely', 'pose', 'threat', 'civilization']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Faults: - larger cracks in the earth’s crust, have movement; formed by constant tectonic movement; can cause deadly earthquakes and tsunamis.	['Faults', 'larger', 'cracks', 'earth', 'crust', 'movement', 'formed', 'constant', 'tectonic', 'movement', 'cause', 'deadly', 'earthquakes', 'tsunamis']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Conditions in Which Karst Don’t Form: - if carbonic rocks form above the water table, the CO2 would escape into atmosphere, so karst wouldn’t be able to form; if the soluble rock is covered by superimposed rock strata, karst may be completely absent because the water and CO2 would be unable to reach the rock.	['Conditions', 'Karst', 'Form', 'carbonic', 'rocks', 'form', 'water', 'table', 'would', 'escape', 'atmosphere', 'karst', 'able', 'form', 'soluble', 'rock', 'covered', 'superimposed', 'rock', 'strata', 'karst', 'may', 'completely', 'absent', 'water', 'would', 'unable', 'reach', 'rock']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Headward Erosion: - the river flows down an overhang; the upper layer of the riverbed is made of resistant strata, but the lower layer is made of less resistant strata; the water erodes the lower part of the cliff, and after a period of time the upper layer collapses, so the overhang retreats.	['Headward', 'Erosion', 'river', 'flows', 'overhang', 'upper', 'layer', 'riverbed', 'made', 'resistant', 'strata', 'lower', 'layer', 'made', 'less', 'resistant', 'strata', 'water', 'erodes', 'lower', 'part', 'cliff', 'period', 'time', 'upper', 'layer', 'collapses', 'overhang', 'retreats']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Stream Piracy (Hijacking): - a stream erodes its riverhead into the path of another stream and changes the flowing path of that stream.	['Stream', 'Piracy', 'Hijacking', 'stream', 'erodes', 'riverhead', 'path', 'another', 'stream', 'changes', 'flowing', 'path', 'stream']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Lifecycle of Erosion in Karst Topography: - early youthful stage (normal surface drainage/streams); late youthful stage (streams start to disappear into swallow holes and become underground streams); mature stage (headward erosion happens on the streams and carves out a long surface hollow); old age stage (the stream carves out valleys in the permeable rock).	['Lifecycle', 'Erosion', 'Karst', 'Topography', 'early', 'youthful', 'stage', 'normal', 'surface', 'late', 'youthful', 'stage', 'streams', 'start', 'disappear', 'swallow', 'holes', 'become', 'underground', 'streams', 'mature', 'stage', 'headward', 'erosion', 'happens', 'streams', 'carves', 'long', 'surface', 'hollow', 'old', 'age', 'stage', 'stream', 'carves', 'valleys', 'permeable', 'rock']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	General Distributions of Karst: - karst regions cover 15% (or 7-12%) of the Earth’s surface; 1/4 of the world’s population depend on water supplied from karst areas.	['General', 'Distributions', 'Karst', 'karst', 'regions', 'cover', 'Earth', 'surface', 'world', 'population', 'depend', 'water', 'supplied', 'karst', 'areas']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	SURFACE KARST LANDFORMS:	['SURFACE', 'KARST', 'LANDFORMS']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Limestone Pavement: - exposed area of limestone; joints are widened by chemical weathering.	['Limestone', 'Pavement', 'exposed', 'area', 'limestone', 'joints', 'widened', 'chemical', 'weathering']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Doline (Sinkhole) Karst: - most common; rolling plains pocked with tens or hundreds of sinkholes, but there are few surface streams or surface valleys.	['Doline', 'Sinkhole', 'Karst', 'common', 'rolling', 'plains', 'pocked', 'tens', 'hundreds', 'sinkholes', 'surface', 'streams', 'surface', 'valleys']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Three major ways of forming sinkholes: 	['Three', 'major', 'ways', 'forming', 'sinkholes']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Solution Doline: thin overburden on carbonate bedrock; the overburden (sand, etc.) fill joints in the rock, creating a funnel-shaped depression in the ground. No subsurface cave system.	['Solution', 'Doline', 'thin', 'overburden', 'carbonate', 'bedrock', 'overburden', 'sand', 'etc', 'fill', 'joints', 'rock', 'creating', 'depression', 'ground', 'subsurface', 'cave', 'system']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Subsidence Doline (Shake Holes): a column of overlying sediments (mostly sand) settles into vacated spaces in the carbonate bedrock below (a process called “piping”). The slow downward erosion eventually forms small surface depressions 1 inch to several feet in depth and diameter.	['Subsidence', 'Doline', 'Shake', 'Holes', 'column', 'overlying', 'sediments', 'mostly', 'sand', 'settles', 'vacated', 'spaces', 'carbonate', 'bedrock', 'process', 'called', 'piping', 'slow', 'downward', 'erosion', 'eventually', 'forms', 'small', 'surface', 'depressions', 'inch', 'several', 'feet', 'depth', 'diameter']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Collapsed Doline: overlying sediments (mostly clay, harder than sand) break off in small bits and fall into joints in the bedrock, leaving a small cavity where the sediment broke off (called “spalling”). As the spalling continues, the covering sediments form a structural arch. The cavity becomes larger and migrates upward by progressive collapse. The cavity eventually breaches the surface, creating sudden and dramatic sinkholes. Compared to the other two, collapsed dolines have steeper edges due to the sudden collapse.	['Collapsed', 'Doline', 'overlying', 'sediments', 'mostly', 'clay', 'harder', 'sand', 'break', 'small', 'bits', 'fall', 'joints', 'bedrock', 'leaving', 'small', 'cavity', 'sediment', 'broke', 'called', 'spalling', 'spalling', 'continues', 'covering', 'sediments', 'form', 'structural', 'arch', 'cavity', 'becomes', 'larger', 'migrates', 'upward', 'progressive', 'collapse', 'cavity', 'eventually', 'breaches', 'surface', 'creating', 'sudden', 'dramatic', 'sinkholes', 'Compared', 'two', 'collapsed', 'dolines', 'steeper', 'edges', 'due', 'sudden', 'collapse']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Disappearing River and Swallow Hole: - a river disappears into a swallow hole.	['Disappearing', 'River', 'Swallow', 'Hole', 'river', 'disappears', 'swallow', 'hole']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Dry Valley (Uvala): - a flat floor and steep walls. (River of resurgence: where a river reappears at the surface).	['Dry', 'Valley', 'Uvala', 'flat', 'floor', 'steep', 'walls', 'River', 'resurgence', 'river', 'reappears', 'surface']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Cockpit Karst: - common in tropical regions; enclosed depressions with multiple sides, and round-topped, conical hills (桂林“峰丛”). Formation: the “solution” theory (heavy rainfall eroded the fissures and washed the debris through the sinkholes eventually out to sea); the “collapse” theory (collapse of cave systems). Typically covered by rain forest; the flat depression area suitable for human habitation and cultivation; it is the early stage of development.	['Cockpit', 'Karst', 'common', 'tropical', 'regions', 'enclosed', 'depressions', 'multiple', 'sides', 'conical', 'hills', '桂林', '峰丛', 'Formation', 'solution', 'theory', 'heavy', 'rainfall', 'eroded', 'fissures', 'washed', 'debris', 'sinkholes', 'eventually', 'sea', 'collapse', 'theory', 'collapse', 'cave', 'systems', 'Typically', 'covered', 'rain', 'forest', 'flat', 'depression', 'area', 'suitable', 'human', 'habitation', 'cultivation', 'early', 'stage', 'development']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Tower Karst: - more common in tropical regions; rare; formed by fast tectonic uplift and tropical karst erosion. Steep-sided forest-covered hills; many have flat tops; it is the latest stage of development.	['Tower', 'Karst', 'common', 'tropical', 'regions', 'rare', 'formed', 'fast', 'tectonic', 'uplift', 'tropical', 'karst', 'erosion', 'hills', 'many', 'flat', 'tops', 'latest', 'stage', 'development']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Natural Chimneys: - a steep, chimney-like feature; too steep for vegetation to grow. Serves as a link between the surface and underground cave systems. Some are hollow, some are not.	['Natural', 'Chimneys', 'steep', 'feature', 'steep', 'vegetation', 'grow', 'Serves', 'link', 'surface', 'underground', 'cave', 'systems', 'hollow']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Natural Bridge: - very, very rare. (No words on the PPT but it’s rare)	['Natural', 'Bridge', 'rare', 'words', 'PPT', 'rare']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	UNDERGROUND LANDFORMS:	['UNDERGROUND', 'LANDFORMS']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Caves and Caverns: - develop at or below zone of saturation. Caves are smaller, have openings aboveground or on mountains, dry. Caverns are larger, have their openings underground, and may continue to be eroded by water.	['Caves', 'Caverns', 'develop', 'zone', 'saturation', 'Caves', 'smaller', 'openings', 'aboveground', 'mountains', 'dry', 'Caverns', 'larger', 'openings', 'underground', 'may', 'continue', 'eroded', 'water']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Stalactites: - grow downward from the top of the cave. Formed by drops of water containing dissolved limestone that seep down through fissures in the cave roof. These drops of water lose carbon and deposit calcite; over time the deposition of calcite forms stalactites hanging down from the roof of the cave. May or may not be hollow inside; are thin and fragile.	['Stalactites', 'grow', 'downward', 'top', 'cave', 'Formed', 'drops', 'water', 'containing', 'dissolved', 'limestone', 'seep', 'fissures', 'cave', 'roof', 'drops', 'water', 'lose', 'carbon', 'deposit', 'calcite', 'time', 'deposition', 'calcite', 'forms', 'stalactites', 'hanging', 'roof', 'cave', 'May', 'may', 'hollow', 'inside', 'thin', 'fragile']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Stalagmites: - grow upward from the floor of the cave. Formed by water droplets falling to the cave floor; these drops also lose carbon and deposit calcite. Over time these droplets form stalagmites that grow upward directly below stalactites. Stalagmites are thicker than stalactites.	['Stalagmites', 'grow', 'upward', 'floor', 'cave', 'Formed', 'water', 'droplets', 'falling', 'cave', 'floor', 'drops', 'also', 'lose', 'carbon', 'deposit', 'calcite', 'time', 'droplets', 'form', 'stalagmites', 'grow', 'upward', 'directly', 'stalactites', 'Stalagmites', 'thicker', 'stalactites']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Pillars/Column: - stalactites and stalagmites that grow toward each other and join to form a pillar/column.	['stalactites', 'stalagmites', 'grow', 'toward', 'join', 'form']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Curtains: - rainwater drips from a long crack in a cave roof form a continuous strip of stalactites.	['Curtains', 'rainwater', 'drips', 'long', 'crack', 'cave', 'roof', 'form', 'continuous', 'strip', 'stalactites']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Soda Straws: - very thin, very small stalactites (look like soda straws!)	['Soda', 'Straws', 'thin', 'small', 'stalactites', 'look', 'like', 'soda', 'straws']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Terraces/Flowstone:	[]
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	 	[]
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Why Karst Matters: - karst controls surface water (e.g. artesian well, base flow). Karst contains tremendous groundwater resources. Karst caves are special habitat. Karst caves are recreational resources (e.g. you can go explore them, which may be a sport?). Karst caves contain cultural resources (e.g. cave paintings). Karst groundwater can be easily polluted. Karst can be hazardous (sinkholes).	['Karst', 'Matters', 'karst', 'controls', 'surface', 'water', 'artesian', 'well', 'base', 'flow', 'Karst', 'contains', 'tremendous', 'groundwater', 'resources', 'Karst', 'caves', 'special', 'habitat', 'Karst', 'caves', 'recreational', 'resources', 'go', 'explore', 'may', 'sport', 'Karst', 'caves', 'contain', 'cultural', 'resources', 'cave', 'paintings', 'Karst', 'groundwater', 'easily', 'polluted', 'Karst', 'hazardous', 'sinkholes']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Drainage patterns:	['Drainage', 'patterns']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Dendritic drainage: most common drainage pattern. Treelike, very efficient energy expenditure since the total length of the branches is minimized. Forms on flat terrain and isn't influenced by faults or folds.	['Dendritic', 'drainage', 'common', 'drainage', 'pattern', 'Treelike', 'efficient', 'energy', 'expenditure', 'since', 'total', 'length', 'branches', 'minimized', 'Forms', 'flat', 'terrain', 'influenced', 'faults', 'folds']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Rectangular drainage: formed by a faulted and jointed landscape — this directs the stream into 90° turns.	['Rectangular', 'drainage', 'formed', 'faulted', 'jointed', 'landscape', 'directs', 'stream', 'turns']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Trellis drainage: characteristic of dipping/folded topography. Seen in parallel mountain ranges, influenced by folded rock structures that very in resistance to erosion. Tributaries join main stream at right angles.	['Trellis', 'drainage', 'characteristic', 'topography', 'Seen', 'parallel', 'mountain', 'ranges', 'influenced', 'folded', 'rock', 'structures', 'resistance', 'erosion', 'Tributaries', 'join', 'main', 'stream', 'right', 'angles']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Annular drainage: occurs on structural domes, with concentric patterns of rock guiding stream courses. Erosion cuts out steps on the dome, where streams start to form.	['Annular', 'drainage', 'occurs', 'structural', 'domes', 'concentric', 'patterns', 'rock', 'guiding', 'stream', 'courses', 'Erosion', 'cuts', 'steps', 'dome', 'streams', 'start', 'form']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Radial drainage: results when streams flow off a central peak/dome, for example a mountain or volcano. Valleys causes by erosion as a result of this drainage pattern are called radial valleys.	['Radial', 'drainage', 'results', 'streams', 'flow', 'central', 'example', 'mountain', 'volcano', 'Valleys', 'causes', 'erosion', 'result', 'drainage', 'pattern', 'called', 'radial', 'valleys']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Centripetal drainage: opposite of radial drainage. Occurs on basins surrounded by highlands. Usually there's a lake at the bottom, but in dry areas there might just be salt flats for most of the year.	['Centripetal', 'drainage', 'opposite', 'radial', 'drainage', 'Occurs', 'basins', 'surrounded', 'highlands', 'Usually', 'lake', 'bottom', 'dry', 'areas', 'might', 'salt', 'flats', 'year']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Parallel drainage: associated with steep slopes, so both the tributary streams and main streams flow directly downwards.	['Parallel', 'drainage', 'associated', 'steep', 'slopes', 'tributary', 'streams', 'main', 'streams', 'flow', 'directly', 'downwards']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	 	[]
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Angular drainage: also formed in jointed landscapes. Water erodes preexisting joints. Where fractures meet, sharp joints form. Secondary fractures can also develop over time.	['Angular', 'drainage', 'also', 'formed', 'jointed', 'landscapes', 'Water', 'erodes', 'preexisting', 'joints', 'fractures', 'meet', 'sharp', 'joints', 'form', 'Secondary', 'fractures', 'also', 'develop', 'time']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Deranged drainage: no clear geometry and no true stream valley. Appears often in glacial regions.	['Deranged', 'drainage', 'clear', 'geometry', 'true', 'stream', 'valley', 'Appears', 'often', 'glacial', 'regions']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Basic fluvial concepts:	['Basic', 'fluvial', 'concepts']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Gradient: the drop in elevation per unit distance. 	['Gradient', 'drop', 'elevation', 'per', 'unit', 'distance']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36		—Formula: rise/run. No unit.	['unit']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Base level: the level below which a stream cannot erode its valley	['Base', 'level', 'level', 'stream', 'erode', 'valley']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Ultimate base level: sea level — average level between high and low tides	['Ultimate', 'base', 'level', 'sea', 'level', 'average', 'level', 'high', 'low', 'tides']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36		—exceptions include when streams empty into closed depressions.	['include', 'streams', 'empty', 'closed', 'depressions']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Local base level: river or lake determining the lower limit of local or regional stream erosion (temporary)	['Local', 'base', 'level', 'river', 'lake', 'determining', 'lower', 'limit', 'local', 'regional', 'stream', 'erosion', 'temporary']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36		—can be some very hard rock/lake/reservoir	['hard']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	Discharge: a stream's volume of flow per unit of time. 	['Discharge', 'stream', 'volume', 'flow', 'per', 'unit', 'time']
6 IDX G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36		—Formula: cross sectional area (m^3) x average velocity of river (m/s). Unit is m^3/s	['cross', 'sectional', 'area', 'x', 'average', 'velocity', 'river', 'Unit']

2 G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36		—in the sun, mass gets turned into energy	['sun', 'mass', 'gets', 'turned', 'energy']

1 G9 GEO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:36	—Geography: science that studies the relationships between natural systems, geographic areas, society, & cultural activities, as well as the interdependence of them over space	['science', 'studies', 'relationships', 'natural', 'systems', 'geographic', 'areas', 'society', 'cultural', 'activities', 'well', 'interdependence', 'space']

1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	1) Sets:	['Sets']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Collection of numbers/objects	['Collection']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	There are different notations for sets:	['different', 'notations', 'sets']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	They are written as: {2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17, 19}	['written']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Definitions:	['Definitions']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Two sets are equal if they contain the same elements	['Two', 'sets', 'equal', 'contain', 'elements']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A subset is if every element of Set A is also an element of Set B. 	['subset', 'every', 'element', 'Set', 'also', 'element', 'Set', 'B']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A proper subset is when a subset doesn’t include the fact that A = B.	['proper', 'subset', 'subset', 'include', 'fact', 'B']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	An empty set is just: { }. A set that contains NO elements.	['empty', 'set', 'set', 'contains', 'elements']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Sets are finite sets if n(A) has a definite value. Where if it has an endless amount, then it’s an infinite set.	['Sets', 'finite', 'sets', 'n', 'definite', 'value', 'endless', 'amount', 'infinite', 'set']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	2) Intersection:	['Intersection']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	The intersection of two sets A & B is the elements that are BOTH in A and B.	['intersection', 'two', 'sets', 'B', 'elements', 'B']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7} intersect {2, 3, 5, 7, 9, 11} = {2, 3, 5, 7}	['intersect']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Union	['Union']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	The union of two sets A & B is basically counting all the elements in both sets.	['union', 'two', 'sets', 'B', 'basically', 'counting', 'elements', 'sets']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	{1, 2, 3} union {4, 5, 6} = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6} 	['union']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	3) Complement of a Set:	['Complement', 'Set']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A universal set (U) is the set of all elements.	['universal', 'set', 'U', 'set', 'elements']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	The complement of a set is the universal set excluding the set that it’s a complement of. 	['complement', 'set', 'universal', 'set', 'excluding', 'set', 'complement']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Example: U =  {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}  and  A = {2, 3, 5},  then A’ = {1, 4}	['Example', 'U']

1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Patterns & Inductive Reasoning-	['Inductive']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Inductive Reasoning: 	['Inductive', 'Reasoning']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Based on patterns you observe, you can use inductive reasoning to tell what the next sequence is.	['Based', 'patterns', 'observe', 'use', 'inductive', 'reasoning', 'tell', 'next', 'sequence']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A conclusion you reach using inductive reasoning is called a conjecture.	['conclusion', 'reach', 'using', 'inductive', 'reasoning', 'called', 'conjecture']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	An example for which the conjecture is incorrect is a counterexample.	['example', 'conjecture', 'incorrect', 'counterexample']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Logic Statements	['Logic', 'Statements']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Conditional Statements	['Conditional', 'Statements']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	An if-then statement is a conditional. The part after “if” is the hypothesis, and the part after “then” is the conclusion.	['statement', 'conditional', 'part', 'hypothesis', 'part', 'conclusion']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A conditional has truth values which are true or false. Based on their hypothesis, you can tell they are true, or are false. (You have to provide a counterexample if it’s false).	['conditional', 'truth', 'values', 'true', 'false', 'Based', 'hypothesis', 'tell', 'true', 'false', 'provide', 'counterexample', 'false']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	The converse just switches up the hypothesis and conclusion. 	['converse', 'switches', 'hypothesis', 'conclusion']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Conditional: If two angles have the same measure, then the angles are congruent.	['Conditional', 'two', 'angles', 'measure', 'angles', 'congruent']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Converse: If two angles are congruent, then the angles have the same measure.	['Converse', 'two', 'angles', 'congruent', 'angles', 'measure']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Biconditionals: Two angles are congruent if and only if they have the same measure.	['Biconditionals', 'Two', 'angles', 'congruent', 'measure']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Biconditionals and Definitions	['Biconditionals', 'Definitions']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	When a conditional and it’s converse are both true, you can combine them as a biconditional. Connecting a hypothesis and it’s conclusion with “if and only if”.	['conditional', 'converse', 'true', 'combine', 'biconditional', 'Connecting', 'hypothesis', 'conclusion']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Inverses and Contrapositives	['Inverses', 'Contrapositives']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	The negation of a statement has the opposite truth value.	['negation', 'statement', 'opposite', 'truth', 'value']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	The inverse of a conditional statement negates both the hypothesis and conclusion.	['inverse', 'conditional', 'statement', 'negates', 'hypothesis', 'conclusion']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A contrapositive is just a converse statement, but both hypothesis and conclusion are negated. 	['contrapositive', 'converse', 'statement', 'hypothesis', 'conclusion', 'negated']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Indirect Reasoning	['Indirect', 'Reasoning']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	All possibilities are considered, and only one is proved false. Which is indirect proof.	['possibilities', 'considered', 'one', 'proved', 'false', 'indirect', 'proof']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Deductive Reasoning	['Deductive', 'Reasoning']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Deductive Reasoning:	['Deductive', 'Reasoning']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	The process of reasoning logically from give statements to a conclusion. If the given statements are true, then it will always produce a true conclusion.	['process', 'reasoning', 'logically', 'give', 'statements', 'conclusion', 'given', 'statements', 'true', 'always', 'produce', 'true', 'conclusion']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Law of Detachment: If a conditional is true and its hypothesis is true, then its conclusion is true. 	['Law', 'Detachment', 'conditional', 'true', 'hypothesis', 'true', 'conclusion', 'true']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A WRONG Statement: 	['WRONG', 'Statement']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Law of Syllogism: Allows you to state a conclusion from two true conditional statements when the conclusion of one statement is the hypothesis of the other statement.	['Law', 'Syllogism', 'Allows', 'state', 'conclusion', 'two', 'true', 'conditional', 'statements', 'conclusion', 'one', 'statement', 'hypothesis', 'statement']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A CORRECT Statement:	['CORRECT', 'Statement']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37		If a number ends in 0, then it’s divisible by 10.	['number', 'ends', 'divisible']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37		If a number is divisible by 10, then it’s divisible by 5.	['number', 'divisible', 'divisible']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37			Conclusion: If a number ends in 0, then it’s divisible by 5.	['Conclusion', 'number', 'ends', 'divisible']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Geometrical Elements	['Geometrical', 'Elements']

1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Point: A location. It has no size, and it is represented by a dot and a capital letter naming it.	['Point', 'location', 'size', 'represented', 'dot', 'capital', 'letter', 'naming']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Line: A series of points that extends in two opposite directions with no end. You can name this with any two points on the line.	['Line', 'series', 'points', 'extends', 'two', 'opposite', 'directions', 'end', 'name', 'two', 'points', 'line']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Collinear Points: Points that are on the same line.	['Collinear', 'Points', 'Points', 'line']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Plane: Flat surface with no thickness. It extends for eternity, containing many lines and points.	['Plane', 'Flat', 'surface', 'thickness', 'extends', 'eternity', 'containing', 'many', 'lines', 'points']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Coplanar: Points and Lines that are on the same plane.	['Coplanar', 'Points', 'Lines', 'plane']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Segments, Rays, Parallel Lines and Planes	['Segments', 'Rays', 'Parallel', 'Lines', 'Planes']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Segment: Part of a line, consisting of two endpoints and all points between them. 	['Segment', 'Part', 'line', 'consisting', 'two', 'endpoints', 'points']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Ray: Part of a line consisting of one endpoint and all points on the one side of the endpoint.	['Ray', 'Part', 'line', 'consisting', 'one', 'endpoint', 'points', 'one', 'side', 'endpoint']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Opposite Rays: Two collinear rays with the same endpoint. They ALWAYS form a line.	['Opposite', 'Rays', 'Two', 'collinear', 'rays', 'endpoint', 'ALWAYS', 'form', 'line']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Parallel Lines: Coplanar lines that do not intersect.	['Parallel', 'Lines', 'Coplanar', 'lines', 'intersect']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Skew Lines: These are noncoplanar. They don’t intersect and are not parallel. 	['Skew', 'Lines', 'noncoplanar', 'intersect', 'parallel']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Parallel Planes: Planes that don’t intersect.	['Parallel', 'Planes', 'Planes', 'intersect']
1 G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Measuring Angles	['Measuring', 'Angles']

4 IDX G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Set: Collection of distinct numbers or objects, each object is called an element or member of the set	['Set', 'Collection', 'distinct', 'numbers', 'objects', 'object', 'called', 'element', 'member', 'set']
4 IDX G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	∈ “is an element of” or “is in”	['element']
4 IDX G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	∉ “is not an element of” or “is not in”	['element']
4 IDX G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	n(A);|A| “the number of elements in set A”	['n', 'number', 'elements', 'set']
4 IDX G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	An element is either in the set or not in the set	['element', 'either', 'set', 'set']
4 IDX G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Elements in a set are distinct, each element can only appear once	['Elements', 'set', 'distinct', 'element', 'appear']
4 IDX G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	No fixed order when we describe the elements in the set	['fixed', 'order', 'describe', 'elements', 'set']
4 IDX G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Two sets are equal if they contain exactly the same elements	['Two', 'sets', 'equal', 'contain', 'exactly', 'elements']
4 IDX G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Empty set represented as {}or ∅	['Empty', 'set', 'represented']
4 IDX G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Subsets: Given sets A and B. For any x∈A  x∈B,  then we call set A is the subset of B	['Subsets', 'Given', 'sets', 'B', 'call', 'set', 'subset', 'B']
4 IDX G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Any set is the subset of itself	['set', 'subset']
4 IDX G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A=B if and only if A⊆B and B⊆A	[]
4 IDX G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	∅ is the subset of any set	['subset', 'set']
4 IDX G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Proper subsets: A proper subset of a set A is a subset of A that is not equal to A. A⊂B	['Proper', 'subsets', 'proper', 'subset', 'set', 'subset', 'equal']
4 IDX G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Union: Set of elements that are in either set A or set B	['Union', 'Set', 'elements', 'either', 'set', 'set', 'B']
4 IDX G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Complement: Set of all elements of U that are NOT elements of A (U=universal set)	['Complement', 'Set', 'elements', 'U', 'elements', 'set']
4 IDX G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Union: ∪ Intersection: ∩	['Union', 'Intersection']
4 IDX G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	1.1 Patterns and Inductive Reasoning	['Patterns', 'Inductive', 'Reasoning']
4 IDX G9 MATH S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Inductive Reasoning: Reasoning that is based on patterns you observe. 6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	9-1 Translations	['Translations']
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Definition of a Translation (Slide):	['Definition', 'Translation', 'Slide']
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A translation is an isometry (a transformation that preserves distances) that moves all points of a figure the same distance in the same direction.	['translation', 'isometry', 'transformation', 'preserves', 'distances', 'moves', 'points', 'figure', 'distance', 'direction']
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Composition of Translations:	['Composition', 'Translations']
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A composition of translations is the result of applying two or more translations in sequence.	['composition', 'translations', 'result', 'applying', 'two', 'translations', 'sequence']
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A translation can be written as ((x, y) (x + a, y + b)).	['translation', 'written', 'x', 'x', 'b']
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	For a figure like (triangle ABC), the image after translation is denoted as (triangle A’B’C’), where (A’), (B’), and (C’) are the new positions of points (A), (B), and (C).	['figure', 'like', 'triangle', 'ABC', 'image', 'translation', 'denoted', 'triangle', 'B', 'C', 'B', 'C', 'new', 'positions', 'points', 'B', 'C']
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	9-2 Reflection	['Reflection']
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	New Term	['New', 'Term']
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	·Reflection	[]
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A reflection is an isometry in which a figure and its image have opposite orientation.	['reflection', 'isometry', 'figure', 'image', 'opposite', 'orientation']
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	All reflection has its own reflection line.	['reflection', 'reflection', 'line']
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	·how to draw reflection	['draw', 'reflection']
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	1 .Draw lines perpendicular to the reflection line, passing through the points.	['lines', 'perpendicular', 'reflection', 'line', 'passing', 'points']
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	2 .Measure the distance from the points to the reflection line.	['distance', 'points', 'reflection', 'line']
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	3 .Mark the reflected point on the opposite side of the line at the same distance.	['reflected', 'point', 'opposite', 'side', 'line', 'distance']
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	4 .Connect the Reflected Points	['Reflected', 'Points']
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	E.g. 	[]
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	·some universal law of reflection	['universal', 'law', 'reflection']
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	9-3 Rotation	['Rotation']
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	New terms	['New', 'terms']
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	·Rotation	[]
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Rotation is a transformation that turns a figure around a fixed point by a specified angle and direction.	['Rotation', 'transformation', 'turns', 'figure', 'around', 'fixed', 'point', 'specified', 'angle', 'direction']
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	·the center of rotation	['center', 'rotation']
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	The center of rotation is the fixed point about which a figure is rotated. Every point on the figure moves along a circular path around this point during rotation.	['center', 'rotation', 'fixed', 'point', 'figure', 'rotated', 'Every', 'point', 'figure', 'moves', 'along', 'circular', 'path', 'around', 'point', 'rotation']
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	·the angle of rotation	['angle', 'rotation']
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	The angle of rotation is the measure (in degrees or radians) by which a figure is turned around the center of rotation. It determines how "far" the figure rotates.	['angle', 'rotation', 'measure', 'degrees', 'radians', 'figure', 'turned', 'around', 'center', 'rotation', 'determines', 'far', 'figure', 'rotates']
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	·clockwise & counterclockwise	['counterclockwise']
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Rotation in the same direction/opposite as the movement of a clock’s hands (↷/↶). Mathematically, this is a negative/positive angle.	['Rotation', 'movement', 'clock', 'hands', 'Mathematically', 'angle']
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	How to draw rotation	['draw', 'rotation']
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	1 .Locate the center of rotation	['center', 'rotation']
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	2 .Turn each point by the angle of rotation in clockwise/counterclockwise(as counterclockwise if not mentioned)	['point', 'angle', 'rotation', 'counterclockwise', 'mentioned']
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	3 .Connect the points to complete image	['points', 'complete', 'image']
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	E.g.	[]
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	How to find the center of rotation	['find', 'center', 'rotation']
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	1 .Select two pairs of points (original and rotated).	['two', 'pairs', 'points', 'original', 'rotated']
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	2 .Draw two segments connecting original and rotated points	['two', 'segments', 'connecting', 'original', 'rotated', 'points']
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	3 .Construct a perpendicular bisector of each segment	['perpendicular', 'bisector', 'segment']
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	4 .The connected point of two perpendicular bisectors is the center of rotation	['connected', 'point', 'two', 'perpendicular', 'bisectors', 'center', 'rotation']

6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Review Questions	['Review', 'Questions']

6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Line/Reflectional Symmetry: A figure can be reflected over a line to map onto itself.	['Symmetry', 'figure', 'reflected', 'line', 'map', 'onto']
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Rotational Symmetry: A figure can be rotated around a point (less than360) to map onto itself.	['Rotational', 'Symmetry', 'figure', 'rotated', 'around', 'point', 'less', 'map', 'onto']
6 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Point Symmetry: A 180 rotation maps the figure onto itself.	['Point', 'Symmetry', 'rotation', 'maps', 'figure', 'onto']
