5 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	·Th 8-1(Pythagorean Theorem) In a right triangle, the sum of the squares of the lengths of the legs is equal to the square of the length of the hypotenuse. Just a²+b²=c²。	['Pythagorean', 'Theorem', 'right', 'triangle', 'sum', 'squares', 'lengths', 'legs', 'equal', 'square', 'length', 'hypotenuse']
5 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	·Th 8-2(Converse of the Pythagorean Theorem) If the square of the length of 	['Converse', 'Pythagorean', 'Theorem', 'square', 'length']
5 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	one side of a triangle is equal to the sum of the squares of the lengths of the other	['one', 'side', 'triangle', 'equal', 'sum', 'squares', 'lengths']
5 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	two sides, just a²+b²=c², then the triangle is a right triangle.	['two', 'sides', 'triangle', 'right', 'triangle']
5 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	·Th 8-3 If the square of the length of one side of triangle is greater than the 	['square', 'length', 'one', 'side', 'triangle', 'greater']
5 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	sum of the squares of the lengths of the other two sides, just a²+b²<c²,then the 	['sum', 'squares', 'lengths', 'two', 'sides']
5 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	triangle is a obtuse triangle.	['triangle', 'obtuse', 'triangle']
5 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	·Th 8-4 If the square of the length of one side of a triangle is smaller than the sum of the squares of the length of the other two sides, just a²+b²>c², then the triangle is acute triangle. 5 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	 Tangent ratio is defined as the ratio of the length of the opposite side to the length of the adjacent side relative to a given acute angle in a right triangle. For example, the tangent ratio of the angle A in the right picture is equals to ratio of a to b. BUT, it depends on the measure of the angle rather than the size of the sides.	['Tangent', 'ratio', 'defined', 'ratio', 'length', 'opposite', 'side', 'length', 'adjacent', 'side', 'relative', 'given', 'acute', 'angle', 'right', 'triangle', 'example', 'tangent', 'ratio', 'angle', 'right', 'picture', 'equals', 'ratio', 'b', 'depends', 'measure', 'angle', 'rather', 'size', 'sides']
5 IDX G9 MATH S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Plus, with the tangent ratio of one angle, we can find the length of its opposite side by tangent ratio*hypotenuse and find the length of its adjacent side by hypotenuse/tangent ratio. Just a=tan(m∠a)*c, b=in the right picture. 3 IDX G9 MATH H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Euclidean Theorem: In Rt ABC with C = 90, if CD  AB at D, then CD2 = AD * BD, AC2 = AD * AB, BC2 = BD * AB.	['Euclidean', 'Theorem', 'Rt', 'ABC', 'C', 'CD', 'AB', 'AD', 'BD', 'AD', 'AB', 'BD', 'AB']

3 IDX G9 MATH H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Triangle exterior angle bisector theorem: In ABC, if AD bisects the exterior angle of A, AD  BC = D, then  (with converse).	['Triangle', 'exterior', 'angle', 'bisector', 'theorem', 'ABC', 'AD', 'bisects', 'exterior', 'angle', 'AD', 'BC', 'converse']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	IDX G9 MATH H+ STUDY GUIDE ISSUE 1	['IDX', 'MATH', 'STUDY', 'GUIDE', 'ISSUE']

1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	1.Sets and Venn Diagrams	['Venn', 'Diagrams']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Sets:	['Sets']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Definitions:	['Definitions']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Set: A collection of distinct objects, considered as an object in its own right.	['collection', 'distinct', 'objects', 'considered', 'object', 'right']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Element or Member: An object that makes up the set.	['Member', 'object', 'makes', 'set']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Subset: A set A is a subset of set B if every element of A is also an element of B.	['set', 'subset', 'set', 'B', 'every', 'element', 'also', 'element', 'B']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Universal Set: The set of all possible elements from which subsets are formed.	['Set', 'set', 'possible', 'elements', 'subsets', 'formed']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Empty Set (Null Set): A set that does not contain any elements.	['Set', 'Null', 'Set', 'set', 'contain', 'elements']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Formulas & Symbols:	['Formulas', 'Symbols']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Intersection ⋂: A ∩ B is the set containing elements common to both set A and 	 set B. Also written in the form	['B', 'set', 'containing', 'elements', 'common', 'set', 'set', 'B', 'Also', 'written', 'form']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Union ⋃: A ∪ B is the set containing all elements of A and B.	['B', 'set', 'containing', 'elements', 'B']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Difference -: A - B is the set containing elements that are in A but not in B.	['B', 'set', 'containing', 'elements', 'B']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Cardinality |A|: Number of elements in the set A.	['Number', 'elements', 'set']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Element (∈): If set A contains a certain element, it is symbolized as x ∈ A. It 	 reads x is an element of A.	['set', 'contains', 'certain', 'element', 'symbolized', 'x', 'reads', 'x', 'element']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Not an Element (∉): If set A does not contain a certain element, it is symbolized 	as x ∉ A. It reads x is not an element of A.	['Element', 'set', 'contain', 'certain', 'element', 'symbolized', 'x', 'reads', 'x', 'element']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Subset (⊂ or ⊆): A set A is a subset of set B if every element of A is also an 	element of B. It is symbolized as A ⊂ B or A ⊆ B. A ⊂ B means A is a proper 	subset of B (B has elements not in A), while A ⊆ B can also mean A equals B.	['set', 'subset', 'set', 'B', 'every', 'element', 'also', 'element', 'B', 'symbolized', 'B', 'B', 'B', 'means', 'proper', 'subset', 'B', 'B', 'elements', 'B', 'also', 'mean', 'equals', 'B']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Superset (⊃ or ⊇): A set B is a superset of set A if every element of A is also an 	element of B. It is represented as B ⊃ A or B ⊇ A. This can be understood as the 	opposite of a subset in which the second set is a subset of the first set and not 	the other way around.	['set', 'B', 'superset', 'set', 'every', 'element', 'also', 'element', 'B', 'represented', 'B', 'B', 'understood', 'opposite', 'subset', 'second', 'set', 'subset', 'first', 'set', 'way', 'around']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Intersection (⋂): A ∩ B is the set containing elements common to both set A 	and B.	['B', 'set', 'containing', 'elements', 'common', 'set', 'B']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Union (⋃): A ∪ B is the set containing all elements in either A, B, or both.	['B', 'set', 'containing', 'elements', 'either', 'B']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Complement ('): The complement of set A, denoted by A', is the set of elements 	in the universal set that are not in A. (In textbooks its also denoted as a bar on 	top of the name of the set, but it couldn’t be entered on a computer so I went 	with the other representation.)	['complement', 'set', 'denoted', 'set', 'elements', 'universal', 'set', 'textbooks', 'also', 'denoted', 'bar', 'top', 'name', 'set', 'entered', 'computer', 'went', 'representation']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Difference (-): The difference of set A and B, denoted by A - B, is the set of all 	elements which are in A but not in B. This could also be achieved through 	operations: For a set C C=A-B when for every n∈C, n∈A, n∉B or 	['difference', 'set', 'B', 'denoted', 'B', 'set', 'elements', 'B', 'could', 'also', 'achieved', 'operations', 'set', 'C', 'every']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	C={n丨n∈A, n∉B}	[]
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Laws (For sets A, B and C):	['Laws', 'sets', 'B', 'C']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	1.Commutative Laws of Sets:	['Laws', 'Sets']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A ∪ B = B ∪ A (Union of sets)	['B', 'B', 'Union', 'sets']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A ∩ B = B ∩ A (Intersection of sets)	['B', 'B', 'Intersection', 'sets']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	2.Associative Laws of Sets:	['Laws', 'Sets']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	(A ∪ B) ∪ C = A ∪ (B ∪ C)	['B', 'C', 'B', 'C']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	(A ∩ B) ∩ C = A ∩ (B ∩ C)	['B', 'C', 'B', 'C']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	3.Distributive Laws of Sets:	['Laws', 'Sets']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A ∪ (B ∩ C) = (A ∪ B) ∩ (A ∪ C)	['B', 'C', 'B', 'C']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A ∩ (B ∪ C) = (A ∩ B) ∪ (A ∩ C)	['B', 'C', 'B', 'C']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	4.Identity Laws of Sets:	['Laws', 'Sets']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A ∪ ∅ = A (Empty set is the identity element for union)	['Empty', 'set', 'identity', 'element', 'union']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A ∩ U = A (Universal set is the identity for intersection)	['U', 'Universal', 'set', 'identity', 'intersection']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	5.Complement Laws of Sets:	['Laws', 'Sets']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A ∪ A' = U (Union of a set and its complement is Universal set)	['U', 'Union', 'set', 'complement', 'Universal', 'set']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A ∩ A' = ∅ (Intersection of a set and its complement is an empty set)	['Intersection', 'set', 'complement', 'empty', 'set']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	6.Idempotent Laws of Sets:	['Laws', 'Sets']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A ∪ A = A	[]
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A ∩ A = A	[]
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	7.Null Laws of Sets:	['Laws', 'Sets']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A ∪ U = U (A union with Universal set is a Universal set)	['U', 'U', 'union', 'Universal', 'set', 'Universal', 'set']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A ∩ ∅ = ∅ (A intersection with an empty set is an empty set)	['intersection', 'empty', 'set', 'empty', 'set']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	8.Absorption Laws of Sets:	['Laws', 'Sets']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A ∪ (A ∩ B) = A	['B']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A ∩ (A ∪ B) = A	['B']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	9.Difference Laws:	['Laws']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A - B = A ∩ B' (Difference of A and B is the intersection of A and the 	complement of B)	['B', 'B', 'Difference', 'B', 'intersection', 'complement', 'B']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	10.De Morgan's Laws***:	['Morgan', 'Laws']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	(A ∪ B)' = A' ∩ B'	['B', 'B']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	(A ∩ B)' = A' ∪ B'	['B', 'B']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Venn Diagrams:	['Venn', 'Diagrams']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Definitions:	['Definitions']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Venn Diagram: A diagram that shows all possible logical relations 	between a 	finite collection of different sets.	['Diagram', 'diagram', 'shows', 'possible', 'logical', 'relations', 'finite', 'collection', 'different', 'sets']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Circle: Each set is represented by a circle usually inside a rectangular 	field 	(Universal Set).	['set', 'represented', 'circle', 'usually', 'inside', 'rectangular', 'field', 'Universal', 'Set']

1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-n(A ∪ B) = n(A) + n(B) - n(A ∩ B)	['B', 'n', 'n', 'B', 'n', 'B']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-n(A') = n(U) - n(A): Number of elements not in set A.	['n', 'U', 'n', 'Number', 'elements', 'set']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Inductive and Deductive Reasoning:	['Inductive', 'Deductive', 'Reasoning']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Inductive Reasoning: A type of logical thinking that involves forming 	generalizations based on specific incidents you've experienced, observations 	you've made, or facts you know to be true or false.	['Reasoning', 'type', 'logical', 'thinking', 'involves', 'forming', 'generalizations', 'based', 'specific', 'incidents', 'experienced', 'observations', 'made', 'facts', 'know', 'true', 'false']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Deductive Reasoning: A type of logical thinking where you start with a general 	fact, rule, or premise and then deduce or infer certain specific details or 	conclusions.	['Reasoning', 'type', 'logical', 'thinking', 'start', 'general', 'fact', 'rule', 'premise', 'deduce', 'infer', 'certain', 'specific', 'details', 'conclusions']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Logic Statements	['Logic', 'Statements']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Proposition: Also known as a statement, a proposition is a declarative sentence that 	is either true or false but not both.	['Also', 'known', 'statement', 'proposition', 'declarative', 'sentence', 'either', 'true', 'false']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Compound Proposition: This is a combination of two or more propositions using 	logical operators. They include conjunctions, disjunctions, implications, and 	biconditionals.	['Proposition', 'combination', 'two', 'propositions', 'using', 'logical', 'operators', 'include', 'conjunctions', 'disjunctions', 'implications', 'biconditionals']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Conjunction: A conjunction is a compound proposition that uses the logical 	operator AND. For the conjunction p ∧ q to be true, both p and q must be true.	['conjunction', 'compound', 'proposition', 'uses', 'logical', 'operator', 'conjunction', 'p', 'q', 'true', 'p', 'q', 'must', 'true']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Disjunction: A disjunction is a compound proposition that uses the logical operator 	OR. For the disjunction p ∨ q, it is enough for either p or q to be true for the entire 	disjunction to be true.	['disjunction', 'compound', 'proposition', 'uses', 'logical', 'operator', 'disjunction', 'p', 'q', 'enough', 'either', 'p', 'q', 'true', 'entire', 'disjunction', 'true']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Negation: The negation of a proposition p is "not p", denoted as ~p or ¬p. If p is 	true, then ~p is false, and vice versa.	['negation', 'proposition', 'p', 'p', 'denoted', 'p', 'true', 'false', 'vice', 'versa']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Conditional Statement (Implication): This is a compound proposition of the form "if 	p then q" represented as p → q. It is false only when p is true and q is false; 	otherwise, it is true.	['Statement', 'Implication', 'compound', 'proposition', 'form', 'p', 'q', 'represented', 'p', 'q', 'false', 'p', 'true', 'q', 'false', 'otherwise', 'true']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Biconditional Statement: A biconditional statement of the form "p if and only if q" is 	true when p and q have the same truth values, and false when they are different. It is 	represented as p ↔ q or p ≡ q.	['Statement', 'biconditional', 'statement', 'form', 'p', 'q', 'true', 'p', 'q', 'truth', 'values', 'false', 'different', 'represented', 'p', 'q', 'p', 'q']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Contradiction: A compound proposition that is always false regardless of the truth 	values of the individual propositions that constitute it.	['compound', 'proposition', 'always', 'false', 'regardless', 'truth', 'values', 'individual', 'propositions', 'constitute']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Contingency: A compound proposition that could be either true or false depending 	on the truth values of its constituent propositions.	['compound', 'proposition', 'could', 'either', 'true', 'false', 'depending', 'truth', 'values', 'constituent', 'propositions']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Satisfiability: A proposition is satisfiable if there is at least one assignment of truth values to its variables that makes it true.	['proposition', 'satisfiable', 'least', 'one', 'assignment', 'truth', 'values', 'variables', 'makes', 'true']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Sufficient: When given A, we can know B then A is sufficient for B	['given', 'know', 'B', 'sufficient', 'B']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Neccesary: When given A, we can know B then B is neccesary for A.	['given', 'know', 'B', 'B', 'neccesary']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Operations:	['Operations']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	In a conditional statement of the form "if p then q", also written as "p → q", we have different forms created by switching or negating the hypothesis and conclusion:	['conditional', 'statement', 'form', 'p', 'q', 'also', 'written', 'p', 'q', 'different', 'forms', 'created', 'switching', 'negating', 'hypothesis', 'conclusion']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Converse: The converse of "if p then q" is "if q then p", or q → p. This is formed by 	switching the hypothesis and the conclusion.	['converse', 'p', 'q', 'q', 'p', 'q', 'formed', 'switching', 'hypothesis', 'conclusion']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Inverse: The inverse of "if p then q" is "if not p then not q", or ¬p → ¬q. This is 		formed by negating both the hypothesis and conclusion.	['inverse', 'p', 'q', 'p', 'q', 'formed', 'negating', 'hypothesis', 'conclusion']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Contrapositive: The contrapositive of "if p then q" is "if not q then not p", or ¬q → 	¬p. This is formed by both switching and negating the hypothesis and conclusion.	['contrapositive', 'p', 'q', 'q', 'p', 'formed', 'switching', 'negating', 'hypothesis', 'conclusion']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	In terms of the truth values, there are certain relationships that always hold true:	['terms', 'truth', 'values', 'certain', 'relationships', 'always', 'hold', 'true']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-A statement and its contrapositive are logically equivalent. This means that they are 	both either true or false. If "if p then q" is true, then "if not q then not p" is also true, and vice versa.	['statement', 'contrapositive', 'logically', 'equivalent', 'means', 'either', 'true', 'false', 'p', 'q', 'true', 'q', 'p', 'also', 'true', 'vice', 'versa']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Similarly, a converse and an inverse are logically equivalent. This means that they are both either true or false. If "if q then p" is true, then "if not p then not q" is also true, and vice versa.	['converse', 'inverse', 'logically', 'equivalent', 'means', 'either', 'true', 'false', 'q', 'p', 'true', 'p', 'q', 'also', 'true', 'vice', 'versa']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Geometric Theorms and Postulates:	['Geometric', 'Theorms', 'Postulates']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Ruler Postulate: The points on a line can be paired with the real numbers in such a way that any given point can always be paired with zero and any other with a 	positive number.	['Postulate', 'points', 'line', 'paired', 'real', 'numbers', 'way', 'given', 'point', 'always', 'paired', 'zero', 'positive', 'number']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Segment Addition Postulate: If B is between A and C, then AB + BC = AC.	['Addition', 'Postulate', 'B', 'C', 'AB', 'BC', 'AC']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Protractor Postulate: Consider OA and OB to be opposite rays in a plane. Then we 	can 	measure angles AOB for every rotation about point O.	['Postulate', 'Consider', 'OA', 'OB', 'opposite', 'rays', 'plane', 'measure', 'angles', 'AOB', 'every', 'rotation', 'point']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Angle Addition Postulate: If point B lies in the interior of ∠AOC, then ∠AOB + 		∠BOC = ∠AOC.	['Addition', 'Postulate', 'point', 'B', 'lies', 'interior']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Parallel Postulate (Euclidean geometry): Given a line and a point not on the line, 	there is exactly one line through the point that is parallel to the given line.	['Postulate', 'Euclidean', 'geometry', 'Given', 'line', 'point', 'line', 'exactly', 'one', 'line', 'point', 'parallel', 'given', 'line']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Vertical Angles Theorem: Vertical angles are always congruent.	['Angles', 'Theorem', 'Vertical', 'angles', 'always', 'congruent']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Linear Pair Postulate: If two angles form a linear pair, then they are supplementary 	(their sum is 180°).	['Pair', 'Postulate', 'two', 'angles', 'form', 'linear', 'pair', 'supplementary', 'sum']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Alternate Interior Angles Theorem: If two parallel lines are cut by a transversal, then 	the alternate interior angles are congruent.	['Interior', 'Angles', 'Theorem', 'two', 'parallel', 'lines', 'cut', 'transversal', 'alternate', 'interior', 'angles', 'congruent']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Triangle Angle-Sum Theorem: The sum of the interior angles in any triangle is 180°.	['Theorem', 'sum', 'interior', 'angles', 'triangle']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Isosceles Triangle Theorem: If two sides of a triangle are congruent (the triangle is 	isosceles), then the angles opposite those sides are congruent.	['Triangle', 'Theorem', 'two', 'sides', 'triangle', 'congruent', 'triangle', 'isosceles', 'angles', 'opposite', 'sides', 'congruent']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-Corresponding Angles Postulate: If two parallel lines are cut by a transversal, then 	the pairs of corresponding angles are congruent.	['Angles', 'Postulate', 'two', 'parallel', 'lines', 'cut', 'transversal', 'pairs', 'corresponding', 'angles', 'congruent']
1 G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	*The converses of the alternate-interior angle theorm, corresponding angles postulate and other paralell lines theorms and postulates all hold up.	['converses', 'angle', 'theorm', 'corresponding', 'angles', 'postulate', 'paralell', 'lines', 'theorms', 'postulates', 'hold']

6 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A radius is a segment that has one endpoint at the cneter and ther other endpoint on the circle	['radius', 'segment', 'one', 'endpoint', 'cneter', 'ther', 'endpoint', 'circle']

6 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	a diameter is a segment that contains the center of a circle and has both endpoints on the circle	['diameter', 'segment', 'contains', 'center', 'circle', 'endpoints', 'circle']
6 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A central angle is an angle whose vertex is the center of the circle	['central', 'angle', 'angle', 'whose', 'vertex', 'center', 'circle']

5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Isometries	['Isometries']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Transformation:	['Transformation']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	a transformation of a geometric figure is a change in its position, shape, or size.	['transformation', 'geometric', 'figure', 'change', 'position', 'shape', 'size']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	The original figure is the preimage. The resulting figure is an image.(the preimage and image must be similar)	['original', 'figure', 'preimage', 'resulting', 'figure', 'image', 'preimage', 'image', 'must', 'similar']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	An isometry is a transformation in which the preimage and image are congruent	['isometry', 'transformation', 'preimage', 'image', 'congruent']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A transformation maps a figure onto its image and may be described with arrow(--->)notation. Prime (')notation is sometimes used to identify image points	['transformation', 'maps', 'figure', 'onto', 'image', 'may', 'described', 'arrow', 'notation', 'Prime', 'notation', 'sometimes', 'used', 'identify', 'image', 'points']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Notice that you list corresponding points of the preimage and image in the sameorder, as youvdo for corresponding points of congruent or similar figures.	['Notice', 'list', 'corresponding', 'points', 'preimage', 'image', 'sameorder', 'youvdo', 'corresponding', 'points', 'congruent', 'similar', 'figures']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Translation:	['Translation']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	a translation(or slide) is an isometry that maps all points of a figure the same distance in the same direction.	['translation', 'slide', 'isometry', 'maps', 'points', 'figure', 'distance', 'direction']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A composition of translation is a combination of two or more transformations. In composition, each transformation is performed on the image of the preceding transformation	['composition', 'translation', 'combination', 'two', 'transformations', 'composition', 'transformation', 'performed', 'image', 'preceding', 'transformation']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Reflection:	['Reflection']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A reflection (or fip) is an isometry in which a figure and its image have opposite orientations. Thus, a reflected image in a mirror appears “backwards.”	['reflection', 'fip', 'isometry', 'figure', 'image', 'opposite', 'orientations', 'Thus', 'reflected', 'image', 'mirror', 'appears', 'backwards']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	You can use the following two rules to reflect a figure across a line r.	['use', 'following', 'two', 'rules', 'reflect', 'figure', 'across', 'line', 'r']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-If a point A is on line r, then the image of A is A itself (that is,A'=A)	['point', 'line', 'r', 'image']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-If a point B is not on line r, then r is the perpendicular bisector of BB'	['point', 'B', 'line', 'r', 'r', 'perpendicular', 'bisector', 'BB']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Rotation:	['Rotation']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	To describe a rotation , you need to know the center of rotation (a point), the angle of rotation (a positive number of degrees)and whether the rotation is clockwise or counterclockwise.Unless stated otherwise.rotations in this book are counterclockwise.	['describe', 'rotation', 'need', 'know', 'center', 'rotation', 'point', 'angle', 'rotation', 'positive', 'number', 'degrees', 'whether', 'rotation', 'clockwise', 'stated', 'book', 'counterclockwise']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	You can use the following two rules to rotate a figure through x° about a point R:	['use', 'following', 'two', 'rules', 'rotate', 'figure', 'point', 'R']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-The image of R is itself (that is,R'= R)	['image', 'R', 'R']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-For any point V,Rv'= RV and m/VRV'= x.	['point', 'V', 'RV', 'x']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A regular polygon has a center that is equidistant from its vertices. Segments that connect the center to the vertices divide the polygon into congruent triangles. You can use this fact to find rotation images of regular polygons.	['regular', 'polygon', 'center', 'equidistant', 'vertices', 'Segments', 'connect', 'center', 'vertices', 'divide', 'polygon', 'congruent', 'triangles', 'use', 'fact', 'find', 'rotation', 'images', 'regular', 'polygons']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Composition of Reflections:	['Composition', 'Reflections']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Glide Reflections:	['Glide', 'Reflections']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	If two figures are congruent and have opposite orientations (but are not simply reflections of each other), then there is a slide and a reflection that will map one onto the other.	['two', 'figures', 'congruent', 'opposite', 'orientations', 'simply', 'reflections', 'slide', 'reflection', 'map', 'one', 'onto']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A glide reflection is the composition of a glide (translation) and areflection across a line parallel to the direction of translation. 	['glide', 'reflection', 'composition', 'glide', 'translation', 'areflection', 'across', 'line', 'parallel', 'direction', 'translation']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Symmetry	['Symmetry']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Reflectional Symmetry:	['Reflectional', 'Symmetry']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A figure has symmetry if there is an isometry that maps the figure onto itself. 	['figure', 'symmetry', 'isometry', 'maps', 'figure', 'onto']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	If the isometry is the reflection of a plane figure, the figure has reflectional symmetry or line symmetry.	['isometry', 'reflection', 'plane', 'figure', 'figure', 'reflectional', 'symmetry', 'line', 'symmetry']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Rotational Symmetry:	['Rotational', 'Symmetry']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A figure that has rotational symmetry is its own image for some rotation of 180or less.	['figure', 'rotational', 'symmetry', 'image', 'rotation', 'less']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A figure that has point symmetry has 180° rotational symmetry. 	['figure', 'point', 'symmetry', 'rotational', 'symmetry']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	 A square has 90° and 180° rotational symmetry with the center of rotation at the center of the square. Thus, a square also has point symmetry.	['square', 'rotational', 'symmetry', 'center', 'rotation', 'center', 'square', 'Thus', 'square', 'also', 'point', 'symmetry']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Dilation	['Dilation']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A dilation is a transformation whose preimage and image are similar. Thus, adilation is a similarity transformation. It is not, in general, an isometry.	['dilation', 'transformation', 'whose', 'preimage', 'image', 'similar', 'Thus', 'adilation', 'similarity', 'transformation', 'general', 'isometry']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Every dilation has a center and a scale factor n,n >0. The scale factor describes the size change from the original figure to the image.	['Every', 'dilation', 'center', 'scale', 'factor', 'n', 'n', 'scale', 'factor', 'describes', 'size', 'change', 'original', 'figure', 'image']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	To find a dilation with center C and scale factor n,you can use the following two rules.	['find', 'dilation', 'center', 'C', 'scale', 'factor', 'n', 'use', 'following', 'two', 'rules']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-The image of C is itself (that is,C'= C).	['image', 'C', 'C']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	-'For any point R,R'is on CR and CR'= n·CR	['point', 'R', 'CR']
5 IDX G9 MATH H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	The dilation is an enlargement if the scale factor is greater than 1.The dilation is a reduction if the scale factor is between 0 and 1.	['dilation', 'enlargement', 'scale', 'factor', 'greater', 'dilation', 'reduction', 'scale', 'factor']

5 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37		•Projectile Motion: An object moving through the air under the influence of gravity alone.	['Motion', 'object', 'moving', 'air', 'influence', 'gravity', 'alone']
5 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37		•Trajectory: The curved path followed by a projectile (parabolic in ideal cases).	['curved', 'path', 'followed', 'projectile', 'parabolic', 'ideal', 'cases']

5 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37		•Horizontal motion: Constant velocity.	['motion', 'Constant', 'velocity']

5 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Section 6.2: Circular Motion	['Section', 'Circular', 'Motion']
5 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Key Concepts:	['Key', 'Concepts']
5 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37		•	Uniform Circular Motion (UCM): Movement at constant speed around a circle.	['Uniform', 'Circular', 'Motion', 'UCM', 'Movement', 'constant', 'speed', 'around', 'circle']
5 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37		•	Velocity: Always tangential to the circle.	['Velocity', 'Always', 'tangential', 'circle']
5 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37		•	Acceleration: Always directed toward the center (centripetal acceleration).	['Acceleration', 'Always', 'directed', 'toward', 'center', 'centripetal', 'acceleration']
5 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37		•	Centripetal Force: The net force required to keep an object moving in a circle.	['Centripetal', 'Force', 'net', 'force', 'required', 'keep', 'object', 'moving', 'circle']

5 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	6. A passenger in a turning car feels pushed outward—explain why.	['passenger', 'turning', 'car', 'feels', 'pushed']

5 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37		•	There is no actual outward force; this is an inertial effect due to the passenger’s resistance to changing motion.	['actual', 'outward', 'force', 'inertial', 'effect', 'due', 'passenger', 'resistance', 'changing', 'motion']
5 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37		•	The car applies a friction force inward to keep the passenger moving in a circle.	['car', 'applies', 'friction', 'force', 'inward', 'keep', 'passenger', 'moving', 'circle']
5 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Steps to Explain:	['Steps', 'Explain']

5 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	2.	Identify the real force: The inward force (friction from the seat or door) keeps the passenger moving in a circle.	['Identify', 'real', 'force', 'inward', 'force', 'friction', 'seat', 'door', 'keeps', 'passenger', 'moving', 'circle']

4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	5.1 Vectors	['Vectors']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Vectors Revisited	['Vectors', 'Revisited']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Scalars vs. Vectors:	['Scalars', 'Vectors']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Scalar: A quantity with only magnitude (e.g., mass, speed, time).	['Scalar', 'quantity', 'magnitude', 'mass', 'speed', 'time']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Vector: A quantity with both magnitude and direction (e.g., velocity, force, displacement).	['Vector', 'quantity', 'magnitude', 'direction', 'velocity', 'force', 'displacement']

4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Connect the tail of one vector to the tip of the previous one.	['Connect', 'tail', 'one', 'vector', 'tip', 'previous', 'one']

4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	5.2 Friction	['Friction']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	What is Friction?	['Friction']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Friction Force: A force that opposes the motion or the tendency of motion between two surfaces.	['Friction', 'Force', 'force', 'opposes', 'motion', 'tendency', 'motion', 'two', 'surfaces']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Caused by: Irregularities in the surfaces in contact.	['Caused', 'Irregularities', 'surfaces', 'contact']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Direction: Always parallel to the surface and opposite to the direction of motion or the tendency of motion.	['Direction', 'Always', 'parallel', 'surface', 'opposite', 'direction', 'motion', 'tendency', 'motion']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Factors Affecting Friction	['Factors', 'Affecting', 'Friction']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Nature of Surfaces:	['Nature', 'Surfaces']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Smooth vs. Rough Surfaces:	['Smooth', 'vs', 'Rough', 'Surfaces']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Rough surfaces create more friction because they interlock more.	['Rough', 'surfaces', 'create', 'friction', 'interlock']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Smooth surfaces create less friction.	['Smooth', 'surfaces', 'create', 'less', 'friction']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Normal Force:	['Normal', 'Force']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	The greater the normal force (the force pushing the surfaces together), the greater the friction.	['greater', 'normal', 'force', 'force', 'pushing', 'surfaces', 'together', 'greater', 'friction']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Key Points:	['Key', 'Points']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Friction increases when surfaces are rougher and when more force is applied to press the surfaces together.	['Friction', 'increases', 'surfaces', 'rougher', 'force', 'applied', 'press', 'surfaces', 'together']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Static vs. Kinetic Friction	['Static', 'vs', 'Kinetic', 'Friction']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Static Friction ():	['Static', 'Friction']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Acts when two surfaces are not moving relative to each other, but there is a tendency for motion.	['Acts', 'two', 'surfaces', 'moving', 'relative', 'tendency', 'motion']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Maximum static friction (): The maximum force before an object begins to move.	['Maximum', 'static', 'friction', 'maximum', 'force', 'object', 'begins', 'move']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Equation: 	['Equation']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	 is the coefficient of static friction, and  is the normal force.	['coefficient', 'static', 'friction', 'normal', 'force']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Kinetic Friction ():	['Kinetic', 'Friction']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Acts when two surfaces are sliding past each other.	['Acts', 'two', 'surfaces', 'sliding', 'past']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	The friction is generally lower than static friction for the same surfaces.	['friction', 'generally', 'lower', 'static', 'friction', 'surfaces']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Equation: 	['Equation']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	 is the coefficient of kinetic friction.	['coefficient', 'kinetic', 'friction']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Measuring Friction	['Measuring', 'Friction']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	When pushing an object:	['pushing', 'object']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	If the object is at rest but force is applied, static friction will match the applied force up to a maximum value.	['object', 'rest', 'force', 'applied', 'static', 'friction', 'match', 'applied', 'force', 'maximum', 'value']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Once the applied force exceeds the maximum static friction, the object will start moving, and kinetic friction will take over.	['applied', 'force', 'exceeds', 'maximum', 'static', 'friction', 'object', 'start', 'moving', 'kinetic', 'friction', 'take']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Example:	['Example']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	For a 10 kg box with a coefficient of static friction  and kinetic friction , we can calculate friction under different applied forces:	['kg', 'box', 'coefficient', 'static', 'friction', 'kinetic', 'friction', 'calculate', 'friction', 'different', 'applied', 'forces']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	No force applied (0 N): No friction (object stays at rest).	['force', 'applied', 'N', 'friction', 'object', 'stays', 'rest']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Applied force of 20 N: Static friction equals 20 N (object at rest).	['Applied', 'force', 'N', 'Static', 'friction', 'equals', 'N', 'object', 'rest']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Applied force of 39.2 N: Static friction equals 39 .2N, which is the max static friction (object at rest ).	['Applied', 'force', 'N', 'Static', 'friction', 'equals', 'max', 'static', 'friction', 'object', 'rest']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Applied force of 40 N: Object starts moving (kinetic friction ).	['Applied', 'force', 'N', 'Object', 'starts', 'moving', 'kinetic', 'friction']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Important Relationships	['Important', 'Relationships']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Static Friction vs. Kinetic Friction:	['Static', 'Friction', 'vs', 'Kinetic', 'Friction']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Static friction is generally higher than kinetic friction for the same surfaces.	['Static', 'friction', 'generally', 'higher', 'kinetic', 'friction', 'surfaces']

4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	5.4 Force and Motion in Two Dimensions	['Force', 'Motion', 'Two', 'Dimensions']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	1. Equilibrium Revisited	['Equilibrium', 'Revisited']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Equilibrium: An object is in equilibrium when the net force acting on it is zero. This can happen when the object is at rest or moving with constant velocity.	['Equilibrium', 'object', 'equilibrium', 'net', 'force', 'acting', 'zero', 'happen', 'object', 'rest', 'moving', 'constant', 'velocity']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Example:	['Example']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	If three vectors form a closed triangle, the net force is zero, and the object is in equilibrium. The equilibrant is a force that balances the other forces. It has the same magnitude as the resultant but acts in the opposite direction.	['three', 'vectors', 'form', 'closed', 'triangle', 'net', 'force', 'zero', 'object', 'equilibrium', 'equilibrant', 'force', 'balances', 'forces', 'magnitude', 'resultant', 'acts', 'opposite', 'direction']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	2. Equilibrant Force	['Equilibrant', 'Force']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	For Two Forces:	['Two', 'Forces']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	The equilibrant is equal in magnitude but opposite in direction to one of the forces.	['equilibrant', 'equal', 'magnitude', 'opposite', 'direction', 'one', 'forces']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	For Three or More Forces:	['Three', 'Forces']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Find the resultant of the first two forces. The equilibrant is equal in magnitude to the resultant but in the opposite direction.	['Find', 'resultant', 'first', 'two', 'forces', 'equilibrant', 'equal', 'magnitude', 'resultant', 'opposite', 'direction']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Example:	['Example']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A force of 1000 N at 15° North of East requires an equilibrant force of 1000 N at 15° South of West to maintain equilibrium.	['force', 'N', 'North', 'East', 'requires', 'equilibrant', 'force', 'N', 'South', 'West', 'maintain', 'equilibrium']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	3. Motion Along a Level Surface	['Motion', 'Along', 'Level', 'Surface']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Constant Speed Motion:	['Constant', 'Speed', 'Motion']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	The applied force equals the friction force. If the force doubles, the object accelerates, with friction remaining constant.	['applied', 'force', 'equals', 'friction', 'force', 'force', 'doubles', 'object', 'accelerates', 'friction', 'remaining', 'constant']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	4. Motion Along an Inclined Plane	['Motion', 'Along', 'Inclined', 'Plane']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Forces on an Incline:	['Forces', 'Incline']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	The gravitational force splits into two components:	['gravitational', 'force', 'splits', 'two', 'components']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Parallel to the slope (causing motion),	['Parallel', 'slope', 'causing', 'motion']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Perpendicular to the slope (affecting the normal force).	['Perpendicular', 'slope', 'affecting', 'normal', 'force']
4 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Check Your Understanding	['Check', 'Understanding']

2 G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	An object remains at rest or in constant motion unless acted upon by a net external force.	['object', 'remains', 'rest', 'constant', 'motion', 'unless', 'acted', 'upon', 'net', 'external', 'force']
2 G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Inertia: The resistance of an object to change in its motion; directly proportional to mass.	['Inertia', 'resistance', 'object', 'change', 'motion', 'directly', 'proportional', 'mass']
2 G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Newton’s Second Law (Law of Acceleration):	['Newton', 'Second', 'Law', 'Law', 'Acceleration']
2 G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	The acceleration of an object is directly proportional to the net force acting on it and inversely proportional to its mass.	['acceleration', 'object', 'directly', 'proportional', 'net', 'force', 'acting', 'inversely', 'proportional', 'mass']

6 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	1. Newton’s Thought Experiment	['Newton', 'Thought', 'Experiment']
6 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37		•	A cannonball is a projectile.	['cannonball', 'projectile']
6 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37		•	If the speed is not large enough, it will follow a parabolic trajectory and fall back to the ground.	['speed', 'large', 'enough', 'follow', 'parabolic', 'trajectory', 'fall', 'back', 'ground']
6 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37		•	If the speed reaches orbital velocity, it will enter an orbit around the Earth.	['speed', 'reaches', 'orbital', 'velocity', 'enter', 'orbit', 'around', 'Earth']
6 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37		•	At this point, the curvature of the cannonball’s path matches the curvature of the Earth.	['point', 'curvature', 'cannonball', 'path', 'matches', 'curvature', 'Earth']
6 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37		•	If the speed is greater than orbital velocity but less than escape velocity, the cannonball will follow an elliptical orbit around the Earth.	['speed', 'greater', 'orbital', 'velocity', 'less', 'escape', 'velocity', 'cannonball', 'follow', 'elliptical', 'orbit', 'around', 'Earth']
6 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37		•	If the speed is very high, the cannonball will follow a parabolic trajectory (exactly at escape velocity) or a hyperbolic trajectory, leaving the Earth.	['speed', 'high', 'cannonball', 'follow', 'parabolic', 'trajectory', 'exactly', 'escape', 'velocity', 'hyperbolic', 'trajectory', 'leaving', 'Earth']

6 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Summary	['Summary']
6 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37		1.	Orbital motion is maintained by gravitational force acting as a centripetal force.	['Orbital', 'motion', 'maintained', 'gravitational', 'force', 'acting', 'centripetal', 'force']
6 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37		2.	Orbital speed depends on the orbital radius; it decreases as altitude increases.	['Orbital', 'speed', 'depends', 'orbital', 'radius', 'decreases', 'altitude', 'increases']
6 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37		3.	Escape velocity is the minimum speed required to leave a celestial body’s gravitational pull; it does not depend on mass but depends on the celestial body’s mass and radius.	['Escape', 'velocity', 'minimum', 'speed', 'required', 'leave', 'celestial', 'body', 'gravitational', 'pull', 'depend', 'mass', 'depends', 'celestial', 'body', 'mass', 'radius']
6 IDX G9 PHY S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37		4.	The orbital period is proportional to the 3/2 power of the orbital radius.	['orbital', 'period', 'proportional', 'power', 'orbital', 'radius']

4 IDX G9 PHY H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Newton’s First Law: An object at rest stays at rest and an object in motion stays in motion with the same speed and in the same direction unless acted upon by an unbalanced force. 5 IDX G9 PHY S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Friction Problems	['Friction', 'Problems']
5 IDX G9 PHY S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	· Friction:	['Friction']
5 IDX G9 PHY S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	·Definition: Friction is a force that resists the relative motion or tendency of such motion of two surfaces in contact. So, the direction of friction is always towards the opposite of the motion.	['Friction', 'force', 'resists', 'relative', 'motion', 'tendency', 'motion', 'two', 'surfaces', 'contact', 'direction', 'friction', 'always', 'towards', 'opposite', 'motion']
5 IDX G9 PHY S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	·Two types which have learned:	['types', 'learned']
5 IDX G9 PHY S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	·static friction () .This type of friction acts on objects when they are at rest and prevents them from starting to move. It must be overcome by an applied force to initiate motion.	['friction', 'type', 'friction', 'acts', 'objects', 'rest', 'prevents', 'starting', 'move', 'must', 'overcome', 'applied', 'force', 'initiate', 'motion']
5 IDX G9 PHY S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	·kinetic friction(). Also known as dynamic friction, this acts on objects that are already in motion. It opposes the movement and is generally weaker than static friction.	['friction', 'Also', 'known', 'dynamic', 'friction', 'acts', 'objects', 'already', 'motion', 'opposes', 'movement', 'generally', 'weaker', 'static', 'friction']
5 IDX G9 PHY S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	·Formula:	[]
5 IDX G9 PHY S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	·=,	[]
5 IDX G9 PHY S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	·=	[]

5 IDX G9 PHY S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	"Centrifugal force": Not a real force—it is the sensation of inertia pushing outward.	['Centrifugal', 'force', 'real', 'sensation', 'inertia', 'pushing', 'outward']

5 IDX G9 ENG H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Summary:	['Summary']
5 IDX G9 ENG H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Ch 1:	['Ch']
5 IDX G9 ENG H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	George and Lennie, two migrant workers, are traveling to a new ranch in California. They stop by a river to rest for the night, revealing their close but complicated friendship. George looks after Lennie, who has a mental disability and loves to pet soft things. Lennie accidentally kills a mouse by petting it too hard, and George scolds him. Lennie dreams of tending rabbits on a farm they hope to own, while George reminds him to return to this spot if he ever gets into trouble.	['George', 'Lennie', 'two', 'migrant', 'workers', 'traveling', 'new', 'ranch', 'California', 'stop', 'river', 'rest', 'night', 'revealing', 'close', 'complicated', 'friendship', 'George', 'looks', 'Lennie', 'mental', 'disability', 'loves', 'pet', 'soft', 'things', 'Lennie', 'accidentally', 'kills', 'mouse', 'petting', 'hard', 'George', 'scolds', 'Lennie', 'dreams', 'tending', 'rabbits', 'farm', 'hope', 'George', 'reminds', 'return', 'spot', 'ever', 'gets', 'trouble']
5 IDX G9 ENG H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Ch 2:	['Ch']
5 IDX G9 ENG H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	George and Lennie arrive at the ranch, where they meet the boss, who is suspicious of Lennie’s silence. They also encounter Curley, the boss’s aggressive son, who immediately dislikes Lennie. Curley’s flirtatious wife appears, making George wary. The old swamper Candy introduces them to other workers, including Slim, a respected mule driver, and Carlson, who complains about Candy’s old dog. 	['George', 'Lennie', 'arrive', 'ranch', 'meet', 'boss', 'suspicious', 'Lennie', 'silence', 'also', 'encounter', 'Curley', 'boss', 'aggressive', 'son', 'immediately', 'dislikes', 'Lennie', 'Curley', 'flirtatious', 'wife', 'appears', 'making', 'George', 'wary', 'old', 'swamper', 'Candy', 'introduces', 'workers', 'including', 'Slim', 'respected', 'mule', 'driver', 'Carlson', 'complains', 'Candy', 'old', 'dog']
5 IDX G9 ENG H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Ch 3:	['Ch']
5 IDX G9 ENG H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Slim gives Lennie a puppy, and George opens up to him about their past, including how Lennie got them in trouble in Weed by grabbing a woman’s dress. Meanwhile, Carlson complains about Candy’s old, sick dog, arguing that it would be more merciful to put it down. Candy reluctantly agrees, and Carlson takes the dog outside and shoots it, leaving the bunkhouse in uneasy silence. Candy overhears George and Lennie discussing their dream farm and offers his life savings to help make it a reality. Meanwhile, Carlson convinces Candy to let him shoot his old dog, symbolizing the harsh reality of the world. Curley picks a fight with Lennie, who, after George tells him to defend himself, crushes Curley’s hand.	['Slim', 'gives', 'Lennie', 'puppy', 'George', 'opens', 'past', 'including', 'Lennie', 'got', 'trouble', 'Weed', 'grabbing', 'woman', 'dress', 'Meanwhile', 'Carlson', 'complains', 'Candy', 'old', 'sick', 'dog', 'arguing', 'would', 'merciful', 'put', 'Candy', 'reluctantly', 'agrees', 'Carlson', 'takes', 'dog', 'outside', 'shoots', 'leaving', 'bunkhouse', 'uneasy', 'silence', 'Candy', 'overhears', 'George', 'Lennie', 'discussing', 'dream', 'farm', 'offers', 'life', 'savings', 'help', 'make', 'reality', 'Meanwhile', 'Carlson', 'convinces', 'Candy', 'let', 'shoot', 'old', 'dog', 'symbolizing', 'harsh', 'reality', 'world', 'Curley', 'picks', 'fight', 'Lennie', 'George', 'tells', 'defend', 'crushes', 'Curley', 'hand']
5 IDX G9 ENG H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Ch 4:	['Ch']
5 IDX G9 ENG H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	While most men are in town, Lennie visits Crooks, the Black stable hand, who lives alone due to segregation. Crooks initially mocks Lennie’s dream but later expresses his own loneliness. Candy joins them, and for a moment, the dream farm seems possible. However, Curley’s wife arrives and belittles them, reminding Crooks of his low status. After she leaves, Crooks withdraws from their dream, realizing it is unlikely to happen.	['men', 'town', 'Lennie', 'visits', 'Crooks', 'Black', 'stable', 'hand', 'lives', 'alone', 'due', 'segregation', 'Crooks', 'initially', 'mocks', 'Lennie', 'dream', 'later', 'expresses', 'loneliness', 'Candy', 'joins', 'moment', 'dream', 'farm', 'seems', 'possible', 'However', 'Curley', 'wife', 'arrives', 'belittles', 'reminding', 'Crooks', 'low', 'status', 'leaves', 'Crooks', 'withdraws', 'dream', 'realizing', 'unlikely', 'happen']
5 IDX G9 ENG H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Ch 5:	['Ch']
5 IDX G9 ENG H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Lennie accidentally kills his puppy in the barn and is distraught. Curley’s wife enters and talks about her unfulfilled dreams of being an actress. She allows Lennie to touch her soft hair, but when he grabs too hard, she panics. In his fear, Lennie accidentally breaks her neck and kills her. Realizing he has done something terrible, he remembers George’s instructions and flees to the river. Candy discovers the body and tells George, who understands their dream is now lost. Curley leads a mob to hunt Lennie down. 5 IDX G9 ENG H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Ch 6:	['Ch']
5 IDX G9 ENG H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Lennie hides by the river, imagining George scolding him and hallucinating his Aunt Clara and a giant rabbit. George arrives and, seeing no way out, tells Lennie once more about their dream farm to comfort him. As the mob closes in, George mercifully shoots Lennie in the back of the head. Slim understands George’s pain and comforts him, while the other men fail to grasp the significance of what has happened. 1 G9 ENG H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Q: What cultural anxieties do the Cyclops embody?	['Q', 'cultural', 'anxieties', 'Cyclops', 'embody']
1 G9 ENG H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A: (Answer may vary) Hospitality (Xenia): In ancient Greece, hospitality, or xenia, was a sacred social custom. In ancient Greece, hosts were expected to provide travellers with food, shelter, and protection, while guests were expected to show gratitude and respect. When Odysseus and his men arrive at Polyphemus' cave, they expect the Cyclops to follow this norm. However, Polyphemus disregards xenia by capturing Odysseus and his men, eating some of them, and imprisoning the rest.	['Answer', 'may', 'vary', 'Hospitality', 'Xenia', 'ancient', 'Greece', 'hospitality', 'xenia', 'sacred', 'social', 'custom', 'ancient', 'Greece', 'hosts', 'expected', 'provide', 'travellers', 'food', 'shelter', 'protection', 'guests', 'expected', 'show', 'gratitude', 'respect', 'Odysseus', 'men', 'arrive', 'Polyphemus', 'cave', 'expect', 'Cyclops', 'follow', 'norm', 'However', 'Polyphemus', 'disregards', 'xenia', 'capturing', 'Odysseus', 'men', 'eating', 'imprisoning', 'rest']

1 G9 ENG H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	A: (Answer may vary) The text emphasises Penelope's intelligence and resourcefulness. The text portrays her as a woman who actively engages her mind and uses her wit to navigate challenges. Penelope also expresses empathy and remorse for the hanged maids, shedding light on the injustices faced by marginalised women in the story. 1 G9 ENG H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	The narrative and events	['narrative', 'events']
1 G9 ENG H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	The poem depicts the myth of Perseus slaying Medusa, focusing on the climactic moment when Perseus beheads her. Medusa, with her "gelid mass of serpents" representing her deadly, snake-covered head, is asleep. Perseus uses a mirroring shield to view her reflection, avoiding her petrifying gaze. He strikes her, severing her head, and immediately feels an overwhelming, violent urge to destroy more. The narrative hints at Perseus’s triumph, but also reveals the disturbing emotional transformation that accompanies his act.	['poem', 'depicts', 'myth', 'Perseus', 'slaying', 'Medusa', 'focusing', 'climactic', 'moment', 'Perseus', 'beheads', 'Medusa', 'gelid', 'mass', 'serpents', 'representing', 'deadly', 'head', 'asleep', 'Perseus', 'uses', 'mirroring', 'shield', 'view', 'reflection', 'avoiding', 'petrifying', 'gaze', 'strikes', 'severing', 'head', 'immediately', 'feels', 'overwhelming', 'violent', 'urge', 'destroy', 'narrative', 'hints', 'Perseus', 'triumph', 'also', 'reveals', 'disturbing', 'emotional', 'transformation', 'accompanies', 'act']

1 G9 ENG H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Determination: Perseus successfully accomplishes a difficult task with precision and skill.	['Determination', 'Perseus', 'successfully', 'accomplishes', 'difficult', 'task', 'precision', 'skill']
1 G9 ENG H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Violent Instincts: After beheading Medusa, Perseus experiences a shift in his emotional state. ['Violent', 'Instincts', 'beheading', 'Medusa', 'Perseus', 'experiences', 'shift', 'emotional', 'state', 'thirst', 'destruction', 'thirsted', 'destroy', 'suggests', 'act', 'killing', 'awakened', 'darker', 'savage', 'side']

1 G9 ENG H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	How might the myth subconsciously impact attitudes toward women? 	['might', 'myth', 'subconsciously', 'impact', 'attitudes', 'toward', 'women']
1 G9 ENG H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	The myth's portrayal of these monsters can contribute to a subconscious framing of women as dangerous or untrustworthy. The Sirens, in particular, symbolize the idea that women's beauty and allure can lead to destruction, reinforcing the stereotype that women are temptresses who lure men to their doom. Scylla's transformation into a monster may echo societal views that demonize women who exhibit anger or power, suggesting that female rage is monstrous. This might create a narrative that associates femininity with danger, perpetuating fears and mistrust.	['myth', 'portrayal', 'monsters', 'contribute', 'subconscious', 'framing', 'women', 'dangerous', 'untrustworthy', 'Sirens', 'particular', 'symbolize', 'idea', 'women', 'beauty', 'allure', 'lead', 'destruction', 'reinforcing', 'stereotype', 'women', 'temptresses', 'lure', 'men', 'doom', 'Scylla', 'transformation', 'monster', 'may', 'echo', 'societal', 'views', 'demonize', 'women', 'exhibit', 'anger', 'power', 'suggesting', 'female', 'rage', 'monstrous', 'might', 'create', 'narrative', 'associates', 'femininity', 'danger', 'perpetuating', 'fears', 'mistrust']

4 IDX G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Character Analysis	['Character', 'Analysis']
4 IDX G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Dr. Henry Jekyll 	['Henry', 'Jekyll']
4 IDX G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Dr. Jekyll is presented as a fine Victorian gentleman --- well mannered, respected, and having a wide circle of friends. Central to the plot progression is his belief of human good vs. evil duality, and his intention to separate the two. Jekyll’s ability to transform into Mr. Hyde allowed him to live a double life, where he can engage in malevolent atrocities and unleash his beasty nature with no damage to his reputation. As Jekyll gradually lost control over the transformation process, he became increasing isolated and depressed, illustrating his struggle against the sinister side of his nature.	['Jekyll', 'presented', 'fine', 'Victorian', 'gentleman', 'well', 'mannered', 'respected', 'wide', 'circle', 'friends', 'Central', 'plot', 'progression', 'belief', 'human', 'good', 'evil', 'duality', 'intention', 'separate', 'two', 'Jekyll', 'ability', 'transform', 'Hyde', 'allowed', 'live', 'double', 'life', 'engage', 'malevolent', 'atrocities', 'unleash', 'beasty', 'nature', 'damage', 'reputation', 'Jekyll', 'gradually', 'lost', 'control', 'transformation', 'process', 'became', 'increasing', 'isolated', 'depressed', 'illustrating', 'struggle', 'sinister', 'side', 'nature']
4 IDX G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Mr. Edward Hyde	['Edward', 'Hyde']
4 IDX G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37		Since his first appearance in the novel, Hyde is constantly dehumanized, being described with terms such as “Savage”, “Snarled”, “Ape-like”, “Hardly human”, illustrating his animosity and separation from civilized society. Central to Hyde’s characterization is descriptions of his “deformed” looks, while never specifying on specifics of the deformation, giving a sense of uncertainty and mystery. Throughout the story, Hyde attacked two innocent victims, the first being an attack while the latter being a murder.  Hyde leaves an impression of horror to other characters, perhaps indicating people’s fear of their malicious side. 	['Since', 'first', 'appearance', 'novel', 'Hyde', 'constantly', 'dehumanized', 'described', 'terms', 'Savage', 'Snarled', 'Hardly', 'human', 'illustrating', 'animosity', 'separation', 'civilized', 'society', 'Central', 'Hyde', 'characterization', 'descriptions', 'deformed', 'looks', 'never', 'specifying', 'specifics', 'deformation', 'giving', 'sense', 'uncertainty', 'mystery', 'Throughout', 'story', 'Hyde', 'attacked', 'two', 'innocent', 'victims', 'first', 'attack', 'latter', 'murder', 'Hyde', 'leaves', 'impression', 'horror', 'characters', 'perhaps', 'indicating', 'people', 'fear', 'malicious', 'side']
4 IDX G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Mr. Gabriel John Utterson	['Gabriel', 'John', 'Utterson']
4 IDX G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37		Mr. Utterson is the character where most of the third-person narration took place, slowing unveiling the truth behind Mr. Jekyll. His rational, calm, and objective narrative allowed the reader to perceive the story independently. He is a kind polite character, a respectable lawyer, and a trustworthy friend and advisor of Mr. Jekyll. Utterson stimulated most of the plot progression, by investigating the matter, leading the police into the house, and etc. The novel ends with Utterson reading the letters left by Jekyll and Lanyon, yet his reaction was never mentioned, adding a mysterious atmosphere at the end.	['Utterson', 'character', 'narration', 'took', 'place', 'slowing', 'unveiling', 'truth', 'behind', 'Jekyll', 'rational', 'calm', 'objective', 'narrative', 'allowed', 'reader', 'perceive', 'story', 'independently', 'kind', 'polite', 'character', 'respectable', 'lawyer', 'trustworthy', 'friend', 'advisor', 'Jekyll', 'Utterson', 'stimulated', 'plot', 'progression', 'investigating', 'matter', 'leading', 'police', 'house', 'etc', 'novel', 'ends', 'Utterson', 'reading', 'letters', 'left', 'Jekyll', 'Lanyon', 'yet', 'reaction', 'never', 'mentioned', 'adding', 'mysterious', 'atmosphere', 'end']
4 IDX G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Dr. Hastie Lanyon	['Hastie', 'Lanyon']
4 IDX G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Mr. Lanyon, a close friend of Jekyll, believes Jekyll’s experiments are morally objectionable and unscientific, describing the experiments as “Unscientific Balderdash”. Being traditional and conventional, when he witnessed Hyde’s transformation into Jekyll with his own eyes, his entire scientific world view on which his life had been built upon had been mercilessly shattered. The shock that such as monstrous beast lies within the gentleman had deeply disgusted Lanyon, leading the cease of his friendship with Jekyll.	['Lanyon', 'close', 'friend', 'Jekyll', 'believes', 'Jekyll', 'experiments', 'morally', 'objectionable', 'unscientific', 'describing', 'experiments', 'Unscientific', 'Balderdash', 'traditional', 'conventional', 'witnessed', 'Hyde', 'transformation', 'Jekyll', 'eyes', 'entire', 'scientific', 'world', 'view', 'life', 'built', 'upon', 'mercilessly', 'shattered', 'shock', 'monstrous', 'beast', 'lies', 'within', 'gentleman', 'deeply', 'disgusted', 'Lanyon', 'leading', 'cease', 'friendship', 'Jekyll']

This results a stark contrast to his murder by Hyde, helping to characterize Hyde as someone who opposes traditional Victorian values. 4 IDX G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Themes	['Themes']
4 IDX G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Duality	['Duality']
4 IDX G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	The duality of human nature is one of the most central themes of the novel. This idea is presented primarily on the character of Jekyll, as on the surface he is presented as a respectable and well-manner Victorian era model gentleman, conflicted by his sinister inner desires. He wishes to be respectable doctor following the highest moral standards, yet yearns to engage in the most terrible atrocities of mankind.	['duality', 'human', 'nature', 'one', 'central', 'themes', 'novel', 'idea', 'presented', 'primarily', 'character', 'Jekyll', 'surface', 'presented', 'respectable', 'Victorian', 'era', 'model', 'gentleman', 'conflicted', 'sinister', 'inner', 'desires', 'wishes', 'respectable', 'doctor', 'following', 'highest', 'moral', 'standards', 'yet', 'yearns', 'engage', 'terrible', 'atrocities', 'mankind']
4 IDX G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	The theme of Duality is also presented in the setting of the story --- London. There are contrasting descriptions of the presence of areas of degradation and poverty next to wealthy ones. The front door of Jekyll’s house was presented as having “a great air of wealthy and comfort”, whereas the back door left an impression of  “Sordid negligence”.	['theme', 'Duality', 'also', 'presented', 'setting', 'story', 'London', 'contrasting', 'descriptions', 'presence', 'areas', 'degradation', 'poverty', 'next', 'wealthy', 'ones', 'front', 'door', 'Jekyll', 'house', 'presented', 'great', 'air', 'wealthy', 'comfort', 'whereas', 'back', 'door', 'left', 'impression', 'Sordid', 'negligence']
4 IDX G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Good vs. Evil	['Good', 'vs', 'Evil']
4 IDX G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	The theme of good vs. evil is present throughout the story. In Jekyll’s view, “man is not truly one, but truly two”. He acknowledges both his good and evil side, and the atrocities committed by Hyde illustrates the consequences to giving into one’s evil side. Hyde was associated with Christian ideas about Hell and Satan and Jekyll repeatedly refers to him as “my devil”. Through the novel, it is proposed that the inherent evil aspect of man is merely suppressed by society.	['theme', 'good', 'evil', 'present', 'throughout', 'story', 'Jekyll', 'view', 'man', 'truly', 'one', 'truly', 'two', 'acknowledges', 'good', 'evil', 'side', 'atrocities', 'committed', 'Hyde', 'illustrates', 'consequences', 'giving', 'one', 'evil', 'side', 'Hyde', 'associated', 'Christian', 'ideas', 'Hell', 'Satan', 'Jekyll', 'repeatedly', 'refers', 'devil', 'novel', 'proposed', 'inherent', 'evil', 'aspect', 'man', 'merely', 'suppressed', 'society']
4 IDX G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Reputation	['Reputation']
4 IDX G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37		The novel also contains the theme of reputation, as Jekyll separated Hyde from himself, in order to experience of the pleasure of unleashing animosity while maintaining his reputation. During Utterson’s investigations, he never announced his suspicions about Jekyll publicly, partially to maintain his friend’s reputation, despite realizing Hyde’s depravity. At the end of the novel, even after Jekyll’s death, Utterson announced, “I would say nothing of this paper. If your master has fled or is dead, we may at least save his credit”	['novel', 'also', 'contains', 'theme', 'reputation', 'Jekyll', 'separated', 'Hyde', 'order', 'experience', 'pleasure', 'unleashing', 'animosity', 'maintaining', 'reputation', 'Utterson', 'investigations', 'never', 'announced', 'suspicions', 'Jekyll', 'publicly', 'partially', 'maintain', 'friend', 'reputation', 'despite', 'realizing', 'Hyde', 'depravity', 'end', 'novel', 'even', 'Jekyll', 'death', 'Utterson', 'announced', 'would', 'say', 'nothing', 'paper', 'master', 'fled', 'dead', 'may', 'least', 'save', 'credit']
4 IDX G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	Historic Context	['Historic', 'Context']
4 IDX G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37		The novella was written in the 19th century, a period of rapid industrialization in Britain. The result was the hasty growth of population, from 1 million in 1800 to 6.7 million in 1900, leading to massive poverty and social gaps. This inequality was demonstrated in the novel by the setting of London and contrasting descriptions of neighborhoods.	['novella', 'written', 'century', 'period', 'rapid', 'industrialization', 'Britain', 'result', 'hasty', 'growth', 'population', 'million', 'million', 'leading', 'massive', 'poverty', 'social', 'gaps', 'inequality', 'demonstrated', 'novel', 'setting', 'London', 'contrasting', 'descriptions', 'neighborhoods']
4 IDX G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37		The novel demonstrated traditional Victorian values, as many characters, such as Utterson, the initial Jekyll, Lanyon, Enfield … are models of Victorian gentleman, attempting to suppress their internal bestiality.	['novel', 'demonstrated', 'traditional', 'Victorian', 'values', 'many', 'characters', 'Utterson', 'initial', 'Jekyll', 'Lanyon', 'Enfield', 'models', 'Victorian', 'gentleman', 'attempting', 'suppress', 'internal', 'bestiality']
4 IDX G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37		During this era, the science of physiognomy was popular. It was an idea that the study one’s physical appearance could determine aspects about their internal morality. This idea is clearly demonstrated on Hyde. Stevenson’s portrayal of Hyde heavily focused on his wicked physical appearances, supporting the theory of physiognomy.	['era', 'science', 'physiognomy', 'popular', 'idea', 'study', 'one', 'physical', 'appearance', 'could', 'determine', 'aspects', 'internal', 'morality', 'idea', 'clearly', 'demonstrated', 'Hyde', 'Stevenson', 'portrayal', 'Hyde', 'heavily', 'focused', 'wicked', 'physical', 'appearances', 'supporting', 'theory', 'physiognomy']
4 IDX G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	The Picture of Dorian Gray	['Picture', 'Dorian', 'Gray']
4 IDX G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	1. What is the symbol of Dorian’s picture? What are some things to note?	['symbol', 'Dorian', 'picture', 'things', 'note']
4 IDX G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37		Dorian’s picture is the *Faustian Bargain* in this book. He makes a deal with the devil to preserve his beauty and instead let his picture grow old for him. There is more than just “aging” when it comes to the picture’s transformation. The picture first changes after Dorian leaves Sibyl, where it’s noted that the picture visibly looks crueler. Over time, the picture grows more and more ugly, as a reflection of Dorian’s corrupting soul. It’s also to note that the picture agonizes Dorian because Dorian has to deal with the fact that he is pretty damaged. Dorian’s attitude towards the picture keeps shifting throughout chapters. At some moments he is interested in how the picture functions and in other times he wants to burn the thing. Either way, the picture eventually is too much for him to bear, so that why he attempts to destroy it. But the picture symbolizes Dorian’s soul, which is why when Dorian destroys the picture, he simultaneously kills himself. It’s interesting to note that Dorian never considered suicide, he just was selfish enough to lead himself to it.	['Dorian', 'picture', 'Faustian', 'Bargain', 'book', 'makes', 'deal', 'devil', 'preserve', 'beauty', 'instead', 'let', 'picture', 'grow', 'old', 'aging', 'comes', 'picture', 'transformation', 'picture', 'first', 'changes', 'Dorian', 'leaves', 'Sibyl', 'noted', 'picture', 'visibly', 'looks', 'crueler', 'time', 'picture', 'grows', 'ugly', 'reflection', 'Dorian', 'corrupting', 'soul', 'also', 'note', 'picture', 'agonizes', 'Dorian', 'Dorian', 'deal', 'fact', 'pretty', 'damaged', 'Dorian', 'attitude', 'towards', 'picture', 'keeps', 'shifting', 'throughout', 'chapters', 'moments', 'interested', 'picture', 'functions', 'times', 'wants', 'burn', 'thing', 'Either', 'way', 'picture', 'eventually', 'much', 'bear', 'attempts', 'destroy', 'picture', 'symbolizes', 'Dorian', 'soul', 'Dorian', 'destroys', 'picture', 'simultaneously', 'kills', 'interesting', 'note', 'Dorian', 'never', 'considered', 'suicide', 'selfish', 'enough', 'lead']
4 IDX G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	2. How is the theme of secrecy presented in the novel?	['theme', 'secrecy', 'presented', 'novel']
4 IDX G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37		There are two important details to remember for secrecy:	['two', 'important', 'details', 'remember', 'secrecy']
4 IDX G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37		First, consider light and dark imagery in the novel. In the later chapters, whenever Dorian confronts his picture, it is during the night. It’s also during nighttime that Dorian is usually mentally unstable. So, we see him keep up this mask in the daytime in front of Lord Henry and Gladys, but then goes pretty insane at night. 4 IDX G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37		Secondly, Dorian tries to redeem himself a lot in the last two chapters. Frankly, it’s useless. But it’s very interesting to see him bring up people like Hetty Merton who he essentially sees as a replacement for Sibyl Vane. It’s important to note that he’s using these characters and these actions to gaslight himself to think that he is redeemable. But even so, it’s obvious that he is never actually improving. For example, he starts *redeem* himself as early as the night he left Sibyl Vane. But that for one, was because he couldn’t stand his ugly portrait, and also the next day he woke up really relaxed and lazy, which showed that he never even cared in the first place. Later on, he tries to say that he’s getting better through his attitude towards Hetty, but his so-called improvement is just himself ghosting Hetty, which shows nothing in reality. 2 G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	General Questions (Mainly on Romeo and Juliet)	['General', 'Questions', 'Mainly', 'Romeo', 'Juliet']
2 G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	1. What does Juliet say when finding out that Romeo is a Montague?	['Juliet', 'say', 'finding', 'Romeo', 'Montague']
2 G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	There are two quotes you can specifically look into.	['two', 'quotes', 'specifically', 'look']
2 G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	The first one being “O Romeo, Romeo! Wherefore art thou Romeo?” (Shakespeare 2.2.33)	['first', 'one', 'Romeo', 'Romeo', 'Wherefore', 'art', 'thou', 'Romeo', 'Shakespeare']
2 G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	“Wherefore” here doesn’t mean “where are you Romeo”, it means “Why are you Romeo”. This shows that Juliet is incredibly miserable that the man she loves is a Montague, and this shows the “star crossed lovers” archetype even more.	['Wherefore', 'mean', 'Romeo', 'means', 'Romeo', 'shows', 'Juliet', 'incredibly', 'miserable', 'man', 'loves', 'Montague', 'shows', 'star', 'crossed', 'lovers', 'archetype', 'even']
2 G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	The second one being (the more famous line) “What’s in a name? That which we call a rose / By any other word would smell as sweet” (Shakespeare 2.2. 43-44). 	['second', 'one', 'famous', 'line', 'name', 'call', 'rose', 'word', 'would', 'smell', 'sweet', 'Shakespeare']
2 G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	She here expresses that a name doesn’t matter to her, as Romeo would be who he is regardless of what he is called. This tells us that she’s willing to love Romeo nevertheless, as she pushes the family feud away from their relationship because she thinks it doesn’t change anything.	['expresses', 'name', 'matter', 'Romeo', 'would', 'regardless', 'called', 'tells', 'us', 'willing', 'love', 'Romeo', 'nevertheless', 'pushes', 'family', 'feud', 'away', 'relationship', 'thinks', 'change', 'anything']
2 G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	2. What does the introduction about Friar Lawrence tell us?	['introduction', 'Friar', 'Lawrence', 'tell', 'us']
2 G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	“Within the infant rind of this weak flower / Poison hath residence and medicine power” (Shakespeare 2.3. 22-23). 	['Within', 'infant', 'rind', 'weak', 'flower', 'Poison', 'hath', 'residence', 'medicine', 'power', 'Shakespeare']
2 G9 ENG H+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:37	We can see through many lines similar to this one in his monologue about the relationship on plants being not completely good and not completely bad, which is a hint to the poisonous vials that Romeo and Juliet drinks later on. It’s also through this section that we are told Friar Lawrence is really experienced with different herbs and plants, foreshadowing that he’d be the one to give the suggestion to drink the vial to Juliet.
