5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	 	[]
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Electron dot structure will be used to show how chemical bonds form in chemical reaction	['Electron', 'dot', 'structure', 'used', 'show', 'chemical', 'bonds', 'form', 'chemical', 'reaction']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	II. The Octet Rule	['II', 'Octet', 'Rule']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Noble gases, such as neon and argon, are nonreactive in chemical reactions	['Noble', 'gases', 'neon', 'argon', 'nonreactive', 'chemical', 'reactions']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Atoms of each of the noble gases (except helium) have eight electrons in their highest occupied energy levels and the general electron configuration of ns^2np^6	['Atoms', 'noble', 'gases', 'except', 'helium', 'eight', 'electrons', 'highest', 'occupied', 'energy', 'levels', 'general', 'electron', 'configuration']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The octet rule states that in forming compounds, atoms tend to achieve the electron configuration of a noble gas	['octet', 'rule', 'states', 'forming', 'compounds', 'atoms', 'tend', 'achieve', 'electron', 'configuration', 'noble', 'gas']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Atoms of metal tend to lose their valence electrons, leaving a complete octet in the next-lowest energy level	['Atoms', 'metal', 'tend', 'lose', 'valence', 'electrons', 'leaving', 'complete', 'octet', 'energy', 'level']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Atoms of some nonmetals tend to gain electron or share electrons with another nonmetal atom or atoms to achieve a complete octet	['Atoms', 'nonmetals', 'tend', 'gain', 'electron', 'share', 'electrons', 'another', 'nonmetal', 'atom', 'atoms', 'achieve', 'complete', 'octet']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The octet rule applies to atoms in most compounds	['octet', 'rule', 'applies', 'atoms', 'compounds']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	III. Formation of ions	['III', 'Formation', 'ions']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Ion – an atom that is no longer neutral because it has lost or gained electrons	['Ion', 'atom', 'longer', 'neutral', 'lost', 'gained', 'electrons']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	A positively charged ion, or cation, is produced when an atom loses one or more valence electrons	['positively', 'charged', 'ion', 'cation', 'produced', 'atom', 'loses', 'one', 'valence', 'electrons']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	A negatively charged ion, or anion, is produced when an atom gains one or more valence electrons	['negatively', 'charged', 'ion', 'anion', 'produced', 'atom', 'gains', 'one', 'valence', 'electrons']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The name of the anion typically ends in -ide.	['name', 'anion', 'typically', 'ends']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The ions produced when atoms of chlorine and other halogens gain electrons are called halide ions	['ions', 'produced', 'atoms', 'chlorine', 'halogens', 'gain', 'electrons', 'called', 'halide', 'ions']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Transition Metal Cations	['Transition', 'Metal', 'Cations']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The charges of cations of the transition metals may vary	['charges', 'cations', 'transition', 'metals', 'may', 'vary']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Ionic Bonds and Ionic Compounds	['Ionic', 'Bonds', 'Ionic', 'Compounds']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Formation of Ionic Compounds	['Formation', 'Ionic', 'Compounds']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	An ionic compound is a compound composed of cations and anions	['ionic', 'compound', 'compound', 'composed', 'cations', 'anions']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Although they are composed of ions, ionic compounds are electrically neutral	['Although', 'composed', 'ions', 'ionic', 'compounds', 'electrically', 'neutral']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	If ionic bonds occur between metals and the nonmetal oxygen, oxides form	['ionic', 'bonds', 'occur', 'metals', 'nonmetal', 'oxygen', 'oxides', 'form']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Most other ionic compounds are called salts	['ionic', 'compounds', 'called', 'salts']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Binary ionic compounds contain a metallic cation and a nonmetallic anion	['Binary', 'ionic', 'compounds', 'contain', 'metallic', 'cation', 'nonmetallic', 'anion']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Ionic compounds are electrically neutral, so the charges of cations and anions must be balance	['Ionic', 'compounds', 'electrically', 'neutral', 'charges', 'cations', 'anions', 'must', 'balance']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The electrostatic forces that hold ions together in ionic compounds are called ionic bonds	['electrostatic', 'forces', 'hold', 'ions', 'together', 'ionic', 'compounds', 'called', 'ionic', 'bonds']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	A chemical formula shows the numbers of atoms of each element in the smallest representative unit of a substance	['chemical', 'formula', 'shows', 'numbers', 'atoms', 'element', 'smallest', 'representative', 'unit', 'substance']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	A formula unit is the lowest whole-number ratio of ions in an ionic compound	['formula', 'unit', 'lowest', 'ratio', 'ions', 'ionic', 'compound']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	For sodium chloride, the lowest whole-number ratio of the ions is 1:1 (one Na+ ion to each Cl- ion)	['sodium', 'chloride', 'lowest', 'ratio', 'ions', 'one', 'ion', 'ion']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Although ionic charges are used to derive the correct formula, they are not shown when you write the formula unit of the compound.  The formula unit of sodium chloride is NaCl.	['Although', 'ionic', 'charges', 'used', 'derive', 'correct', 'formula', 'shown', 'write', 'formula', 'unit', 'compound', 'formula', 'unit', 'sodium', 'chloride', 'NaCl']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The coordination number of an ion is the number of ions of opposite charge that surround the ion in a crystal	['coordination', 'number', 'ion', 'number', 'ions', 'opposite', 'charge', 'surround', 'ion', 'crystal']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	In NaCl, each ion has a coordination number of 6.	['NaCl', 'ion', 'coordination', 'number']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The coordination number of Na+ is 6 because each Na+ ion is surrounded by six Cl- ions.	['coordination', 'number', 'ion', 'surrounded', 'six', 'ions']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The coordination number of Cl- is also 6 because each Cl- ion is surrounded by six Na+ ions.	['coordination', 'number', 'also', 'ion', 'surrounded', 'six', 'ions']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Properties of ionic compounds	['Properties', 'ionic', 'compounds']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Most ionic compounds are crystalline solids at room temperature	['ionic', 'compounds', 'crystalline', 'solids', 'room', 'temperature']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The component ions in such crystals are arranged in repeating three-dimensional patterns	['component', 'ions', 'crystals', 'arranged', 'repeating', 'patterns']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Each ion is attracted strongly to each of its neighbors, and repulsions are minimized	['ion', 'attracted', 'strongly', 'neighbors', 'repulsions', 'minimized']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Property 1: the large attractive forces result in a very stable structure	['Property', 'large', 'attractive', 'forces', 'result', 'stable', 'structure']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Property 2: the network of attractions that extends throughout an ionic crystal gives these compounds their high melting point.	['Property', 'network', 'attractions', 'extends', 'throughout', 'ionic', 'crystal', 'gives', 'compounds', 'high', 'melting', 'point']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Property 3: Ionic crystals are strong, but brittle.	['Property', 'Ionic', 'crystals', 'strong', 'brittle']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	When ionic crystals are struck, the cations and anions are shifted from their fixed positions. Repulsions between ions of like charge cause the crystal to shatter.	['ionic', 'crystals', 'struck', 'cations', 'anions', 'shifted', 'fixed', 'positions', 'Repulsions', 'ions', 'like', 'charge', 'cause', 'crystal', 'shatter']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Property 4: Ionic solid is poor conductor. But it can conduct electricity in molten (liquid) state and aqueous state (dissolved in water)	['Property', 'Ionic', 'solid', 'poor', 'conductor', 'conduct', 'electricity', 'molten', 'liquid', 'state', 'aqueous', 'state', 'dissolved', 'water']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Ions has fixed position in solid state without freedom to move around	['Ions', 'fixed', 'position', 'solid', 'state', 'without', 'freedom', 'move', 'around']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Ionic compounds can conduct an electric current when melted or dissolved in water.	['Ionic', 'compounds', 'conduct', 'electric', 'current', 'melted', 'dissolved', 'water']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S ALT.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	When they melted, the orderly crystal structure breaks down. When dissolved, the ions are free to move about in the solution.	['melted', 'orderly', 'crystal', 'structure', 'breaks', 'dissolved', 'ions', 'free', 'move', 'solution']

3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38					-positive exponent: move decimal place rightwards	['exponent', 'move', 'decimal', 'place', 'rightwards']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38					-negative exponent: move decimal place leftwards	['exponent', 'move', 'decimal', 'place', 'leftwards']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38			-Scientific notation calculations	['notation', 'calculations']

3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	-e.g. (5.4x103) + (0.80x104) = (5.4x103) + (8.0x103) =13.4x103=1.34x104	[]
3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38				-multiplication and division: add/subtract the exponents	['division', 'exponents']

3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		-Accuracy: measure of the closeness of a measurement to its truth value.	['measure', 'closeness', 'measurement', 'truth', 'value']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		-Precision: measure of how close a measurement is to another.	['measure', 'close', 'measurement', 'another']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38			-For example:	['example']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	-Four of five repetitions of a measurement were numerically identical, and the fifth varied from the others in value by less than 1% - Precision	['five', 'repetitions', 'measurement', 'numerically', 'identical', 'fifth', 'varied', 'others', 'value', 'less', 'Precision']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	-Eight measurements were spread over a wide range - Precision	['measurements', 'spread', 'wide', 'range', 'Precision']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- A single measurement is within 1% of the correct value – Accuracy	['single', 'measurement', 'within', 'correct', 'value', 'Accuracy']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		-Error: the difference between the experimental value and the accepted value	['difference', 'experimental', 'value', 'accepted', 'value']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	-Percent error is calculated by the formula: 1error1 (absolute value)/accepted value times 100%.	['error', 'calculated', 'formula', 'absolute', 'value', 'value', 'times']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	-Significant digits: all the digits of a measurement that are known, plus the last digit that is estimated.	['digits', 'digits', 'measurement', 'known', 'plus', 'last', 'digit', 'estimated']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		-How to determine how many SF: 	['determine', 'many', 'SF']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	-If the decimal point is present, start counting the first nonzero number from left to right till the end.	['decimal', 'point', 'present', 'start', 'counting', 'first', 'nonzero', 'number', 'left', 'right', 'till', 'end']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	-If decimal point is absent, start counting the first nonzero number from right to left till the end.	['decimal', 'point', 'absent', 'start', 'counting', 'first', 'nonzero', 'number', 'right', 'left', 'till', 'end']

3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Chapter 5(After midterms)	['Chapter', 'midterms']

3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	-The principal quantum number, n, always equal the number of sublevels within that principal energy level.	['principal', 'quantum', 'number', 'n', 'always', 'equal', 'number', 'sublevels', 'within', 'principal', 'energy', 'level']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38					[]

3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		-Electron arrangement in atoms	['arrangement', 'atoms']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	-the way in which electrons are arranged in various orbitals around the nuclei of atoms are called electron configurations.	['way', 'electrons', 'arranged', 'various', 'orbitals', 'around', 'nuclei', 'atoms', 'called', 'electron', 'configurations']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	-electron configuration is the most stable arrangement of the electrons, indicating the ground state of an atom.	['configuration', 'stable', 'arrangement', 'electrons', 'indicating', 'ground', 'state', 'atom']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		-Four rules/principles	[]
3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38			-Aufbau Principle	['Principle']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38				-electrons occupy the orbitals of lowest energy first	['occupy', 'orbitals', 'lowest', 'energy', 'first']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38			-Energy ranking:	['ranking']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38			-Pauli Exclusion Principle	['Exclusion', 'Principle']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38				-an atomic orbital may describe at most two electrons with the opposite spin.	['atomic', 'orbital', 'may', 'describe', 'two', 'electrons', 'opposite', 'spin']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		-Spin is a quantum mechanical property of electrons that are either clockwise	['quantum', 'mechanical', 'property', 'electrons', 'either', 'clockwise']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	or counterclockwise.	['counterclockwise']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	-When electrons with opposite spins occupy an orbital, that orbital is said to be paired.	['electrons', 'opposite', 'spins', 'occupy', 'orbital', 'orbital', 'said', 'paired']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38			-Hund’s rule	['rule']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	-electrons occupy orbitals of the same energy in a way that makes the number of electrons with the same spin direction as large as possible.	['occupy', 'orbitals', 'energy', 'way', 'makes', 'number', 'electrons', 'spin', 'direction', 'large', 'possible']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		-e.g. three electrons would occupy three orbitals with equal energy	['three', 'electrons', 'would', 'occupy', 'three', 'orbitals', 'equal', 'energy']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		-Condensed Electron Configurations 	['Electron', 'Configurations']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	-the electron configuration of the nearest noble-gas element (last element of each horizontal period) of lower atomic number is represented by its chemical symbol in brackets.	['electron', 'configuration', 'nearest', 'element', 'last', 'element', 'horizontal', 'period', 'lower', 'atomic', 'number', 'represented', 'chemical', 'symbol', 'brackets']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		-exceptional electron configurations	['electron', 'configurations']

3 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38			-their electron configuration will be:	['electron', 'configuration']

4 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	𝑚×10^𝑛        𝑚: coefficient(1≤𝑚<10)     𝑛:exponent	['𝑚', 'coefficient', '𝑛', 'exponent']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	304,000,000=3.04×107304,000,000=3.04×10^7← no decimal points, count from right to left, significant figures are 304	['decimal', 'points', 'count', 'right', 'left', 'significant', 'figures']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	30,400,000.=3.0400000×10730,400,000.=3.0400000×10^7 ← with decimal points, count from left to right	['decimal', 'points', 'count', 'left', 'right']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Addition/Subtraction: exponents must be the same	['exponents', 'must']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Multiplication: multiply the coefficients and add the exponents	['Multiplication', 'multiply', 'coefficients', 'add', 'exponents']

4 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	II. Accuracy and Precision	['II', 'Accuracy', 'Precision']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Accuracy is a measure of how close a measurement comes to the actual or true value of whatever is measured	['Accuracy', 'measure', 'close', 'measurement', 'comes', 'actual', 'true', 'value', 'whatever', 'measured']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Precision is a measure of how close a series of measurements are to one another, irrespective of the actual value	['Precision', 'measure', 'close', 'series', 'measurements', 'one', 'another', 'irrespective', 'actual', 'value']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Possible outcomes: 1. Good accuracy, good precision	['Possible', 'outcomes', 'Good', 'accuracy', 'good', 'precision']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	             2. Poor accuracy, good precision	['Poor', 'accuracy', 'good', 'precision']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	             3. Poor accuracy, poor precision	['Poor', 'accuracy', 'poor', 'precision']

4 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Reliable Results should be both highly precise and accurate	['Reliable', 'Results', 'highly', 'precise', 'accurate']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Give about the same result again and again; close to accepted value	['Give', 'result', 'close', 'accepted', 'value']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	III. Error	['III', 'Error']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Error is the difference between the experimental value and the accepted value	['Error', 'difference', 'experimental', 'value', 'accepted', 'value']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Error – exponential value ---- accepted value	['Error', 'exponential', 'value', 'accepted', 'value']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Percent error of a measurement is the absolute value of the error divided by the accepted value, multiplied by 100%	['Percent', 'error', 'measurement', 'absolute', 'value', 'error', 'divided', 'accepted', 'value', 'multiplied']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Percent error = | error | / accepted value · 100%	['Percent', 'error', 'error', 'accepted', 'value']

4 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Electrons move in certain circular orbits with allowed energy state around the nucleus designated by a quantum number n (n=1,2,3…)	['Electrons', 'move', 'certain', 'circular', 'orbits', 'allowed', 'energy', 'state', 'around', 'nucleus', 'designated', 'quantum', 'number', 'n']

4 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Particles of matter should behave like waves and exhibit a wavelength, just as waves of light behave like particles of matter	['Particles', 'matter', 'behave', 'like', 'waves', 'exhibit', 'wavelength', 'waves', 'light', 'behave', 'like', 'particles', 'matter']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle	['Heisenberg', 'Uncertainty', 'Principle']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The position and velocity of a moving object cannot be measured and known at the same time	['position', 'velocity', 'moving', 'object', 'measured', 'known', 'time']

4 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Determines allowed energies an electron can have and the probability to find the electron in various locations around the nucleus of an atom	['Determines', 'allowed', 'energies', 'electron', 'probability', 'find', 'electron', 'various', 'locations', 'around', 'nucleus', 'atom']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	An atomic orbital is represented pictorially as a region of space in which there is a high probability of finding an electron	['atomic', 'orbital', 'represented', 'pictorially', 'region', 'space', 'high', 'probability', 'finding', 'electron']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Atomic Orbitals	['Atomic', 'Orbitals']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Represented by letters: s, p, d, f (also called sublevels)	['Represented', 'letters', 'p', 'f', 'also', 'called', 'sublevels']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Each principle energy level (n) has n sublevels	['principle', 'energy', 'level', 'n', 'n', 'sublevels']

4 IDX G9 CHEM S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Electrons occupy orbitals of the same energy in a way that makes the number of electrons with the same spin direction as large as possible	['Electrons', 'occupy', 'orbitals', 'energy', 'way', 'makes', 'number', 'electrons', 'spin', 'direction', 'large', 'possible']

4 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Energy is only absorbed or emitted to move an electron from one “allowed” energy state to another.	['Energy', 'absorbed', 'emitted', 'move', 'electron', 'one', 'allowed', 'energy', 'state', 'another']
4 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Electron on the other allowable energy levels are excited states.	['Electron', 'allowable', 'energy', 'levels', 'excited', 'states']
4 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Ground State: The lowest energy state (n=1).	['Ground', 'State', 'lowest', 'energy', 'state']
4 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Excited States: Higher energy levels (n=2, 3, ...).	['Excited', 'States', 'Higher', 'energy', 'levels']
4 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Photon Emission: When an electron drops to a lower energy level, it emits a photon corresponding to the energy difference.	['Photon', 'Emission', 'electron', 'drops', 'lower', 'energy', 'level', 'emits', 'photon', 'corresponding', 'energy', 'difference']
4 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Bohr's model effectively explains hydrogen's spectrum but fails for multi-electron atoms and does not account for electron behavior in circular orbits. 4 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Hydrogen’s Line Spectrum	['Hydrogen', 'Line', 'Spectrum']

4 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Atom emits a photon corresponding to the difference between the energy levels associated with two orbits. 4 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	In the late 1790s, Antoine Lavoisier compiled a list of 23 known elements. By 1870, approximately 70 elements were recognized.	['late', 'Antoine', 'Lavoisier', 'compiled', 'list', 'known', 'elements', 'approximately', 'elements', 'recognized']
4 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	1860: Chemists agreed on a method for determining atomic masses.	['Chemists', 'agreed', 'method', 'determining', 'atomic', 'masses']
4 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	1864: John Newlands proposed the "octave" rule, where properties repeat every eighth element.	['John', 'Newlands', 'proposed', 'octave', 'rule', 'properties', 'repeat', 'every', 'eighth', 'element']

4 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Mendeleev observed periodic patterns in chemical and physical properties when elements were ordered by atomic mass.	['Mendeleev', 'observed', 'periodic', 'patterns', 'chemical', 'physical', 'properties', 'elements', 'ordered', 'atomic', 'mass']

4 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	7.2 Effective Nuclear Charge	['Effective', 'Nuclear', 'Charge']
4 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	In multi-electron atoms, electrons are attracted to the nucleus but also repelled by other electrons.	['atoms', 'electrons', 'attracted', 'nucleus', 'also', 'repelled', 'electrons']
4 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The nuclear charge experienced by an electron depends on attraction and repulsion factors.	['nuclear', 'charge', 'experienced', 'electron', 'depends', 'attraction', 'repulsion', 'factors']
4 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Valence electrons experience less attraction due to core electron repulsion.	['Valence', 'electrons', 'experience', 'less', 'attraction', 'due', 'core', 'electron', 'repulsion']
4 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Shielding effect: Inner electrons repel outer (valence) electrons, decreasing attraction from nuclear charge (Z).	['Shielding', 'effect', 'Inner', 'electrons', 'repel', 'outer', 'valence', 'electrons', 'decreasing', 'attraction', 'nuclear', 'charge', 'Z']
4 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Effective nuclear charge (Zeff) is the charge felt by outermost electrons after accounting for shielding.	['Effective', 'nuclear', 'charge', 'Zeff', 'charge', 'felt', 'outermost', 'electrons', 'accounting', 'shielding']
4 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Zeff for outermost electrons is smaller than for inner electrons due to screening effects.	['Zeff', 'outermost', 'electrons', 'smaller', 'inner', 'electrons', 'due', 'screening', 'effects']
4 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Inner electrons have a greater impact on screening than outermost electrons.	['Inner', 'electrons', 'greater', 'impact', 'screening', 'outermost', 'electrons']
4 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Zeff decreases in the order: s, p, d, f for electrons on the same principal energy level.	['Zeff', 'decreases', 'order', 'p', 'f', 'electrons', 'principal', 'energy', 'level']
4 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Zeff increases from left to right across a period.	['Zeff', 'increases', 'left', 'right', 'across', 'period']
4 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Going down a column, Zeff increases slightly due to less effective screening by diffuse core electron clouds.	['Going', 'column', 'Zeff', 'increases', 'slightly', 'due', 'less', 'effective', 'screening', 'diffuse', 'core', 'electron', 'clouds']

6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	8.4 Bond Polarity and Electronegativity	['Bond', 'Polarity', 'Electronegativity']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Polarity of the Bond	['Polarity', 'Bond']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- Polarity refers to a separation of positive and negative charge.	['Polarity', 'refers', 'separation', 'positive', 'negative', 'charge']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Bond Polarity: a measure of how equally or unequally the electrons in any covalent bond 	  are shared.	['Bond', 'Polarity', 'measure', 'equally', 'unequally', 'electrons', 'covalent', 'bond', 'shared']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- Nonpolar covalent bond is one in which the electrons are shared equally, as in Cl2 & N2 	['Nonpolar', 'covalent', 'bond', 'one', 'electrons', 'shared', 'equally']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- In a polar covalent bond, electrons are shared unequally, one of the atoms exerts a 	 	  greater attraction for the bonding electrons than the other	['polar', 'covalent', 'bond', 'electrons', 'shared', 'unequally', 'one', 'atoms', 'exerts', 'greater', 'attraction', 'bonding', 'electrons']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- Element with greater electronegativity has greater attractive force in chemical bonding. 	['Element', 'greater', 'electronegativity', 'greater', 'attractive', 'force', 'chemical', 'bonding']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- If the difference in relative ability to attract electrons (electronegativity) is large enough, 	  an ionic bond is formed 	['difference', 'relative', 'ability', 'attract', 'electrons', 'electronegativity', 'large', 'enough', 'ionic', 'bond', 'formed']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Bond Type By Electronegativity 	['Bond', 'Type', 'Electronegativity']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Dipole moments (Polarity of molecule)	['Dipole', 'moments', 'Polarity', 'molecule']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Molecular polarity is dependent on bond polarity and the molecular geometry. 	['Molecular', 'polarity', 'dependent', 'bond', 'polarity', 'molecular', 'geometry']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- E.g. Water is a polar molecule, but carbon dioxide is not	['Water', 'polar', 'molecule', 'carbon', 'dioxide']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38			[]
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Polar Molecule (dipole)– A molecule has one end with a positive charge and another end 	  with a negative charge.	['Polar', 'Molecule', 'dipole', 'molecule', 'one', 'end', 'positive', 'charge', 'another', 'end', 'negative', 'charge']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Nonpolar Molecule – A molecule that does not have positive or negative ends.	['Nonpolar', 'Molecule', 'molecule', 'positive', 'negative', 'ends']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	For a simple molecule	['simple', 'molecule']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- A molecule only contains nonpolar bonds is usually nonpolar (exception: O3 polar 	 	  molecule)	['molecule', 'contains', 'nonpolar', 'bonds', 'usually', 'nonpolar', 'exception', 'polar', 'molecule']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- If it contains polar bond and the molecular shape is symmetrical (positive and 	  negative charge center at the same place), it is nonpolar molecule.	['contains', 'polar', 'bond', 'molecular', 'shape', 'symmetrical', 'positive', 'negative', 'charge', 'center', 'place', 'nonpolar', 'molecule']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- A polar molecule usually contain polar bonds and an asymmetrical structure 	['polar', 'molecule', 'usually', 'contain', 'polar', 'bonds', 'asymmetrical', 'structure']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	8.5 Drawing Lewis Structures	['Drawing', 'Lewis', 'Structures']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Molecular formula: shows all the numbers of atoms in one molecule, i.e. NH3 (g)	['Molecular', 'formula', 'shows', 'numbers', 'atoms', 'one', 'molecule', 'g']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Structural formula: uses letter symbols and bonds to show relative positions for atoms, AKA Lewis structures.	['Structural', 'formula', 'uses', 'letter', 'symbols', 'bonds', 'show', 'relative', 'positions', 'atoms', 'AKA', 'Lewis', 'structures']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Writing Lewis Structures	['Writing', 'Lewis', 'Structures']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Sum valence electrons	['Sum', 'valence', 'electrons']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Identify central atom	['Identify', 'central', 'atom']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Complete octets of surrounding atoms	['Complete', 'octets', 'surrounding', 'atoms']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Place leftover electrons in central atom	['Place', 'leftover', 'electrons', 'central', 'atom']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	If central atom’s octet is not fulfilled, add bonds. If there are leftover atoms after completing all octets, put them around the central atom (d-orbital, can be more than 8 electrons)	['central', 'atom', 'octet', 'fulfilled', 'add', 'bonds', 'leftover', 'atoms', 'completing', 'octets', 'put', 'around', 'central', 'atom', 'electrons']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Add the charge if it’s an ion 	['Add', 'charge', 'ion']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Examples	['Examples']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	ClO4-  7 + 6*4 + 1 = 32 electrons = 16 pairs				['electrons', 'pairs']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	CO32-  4 + 3*6 + 2 = 24 electrons = 12 pairs	['electrons', 'pairs']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	OCl2  6 + 7*2 = 20 electrons = 10 pairs	['electrons', 'pairs']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	BrCl3  7 + 7*3 = 28 electrons = 14 pairs	['electrons', 'pairs']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Other Structures	['Structures']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Molecular geometry: showing the arrangement in a 3D form of the structure 	['Molecular', 'geometry', 'showing', 'arrangement', 'form', 'structure']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Example	['Example']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	PBr3  trigonal pyramidal	['trigonal', 'pyramidal']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	✩ nonbonded electrons repel more than bonded electrons, affecting the molecular geometry	['nonbonded', 'electrons', 'repel', 'bonded', 'electrons', 'affecting', 'molecular', 'geometry']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Formal Charge	['Formal', 'Charge']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Used to find the best Lewis structure, which is the one that	['Used', 'find', 'best', 'Lewis', 'structure', 'one']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Has the fewest charges (as close to zero as possible) 	['fewest', 'charges', 'close', 'zero', 'possible']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Puts a negative charge on the most electronegative atom	['Puts', 'negative', 'charge', 'electronegative', 'atom']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Valence electrons – (bonding electrons/2) – non-bonding electrons	['Valence', 'electrons', 'bonding', 'electrons']
6 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Example	['Example']

5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	7.3 Sizes of Atoms and Ions	['Sizes', 'Atoms', 'Ions']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Sizes of Atoms:	['Sizes', 'Atoms']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- The bonding atomic radius is defined as one-half of the distance between covalently 	   bond nuclei. 	['bonding', 'atomic', 'radius', 'defined', 'distance', 'covalently', 'bond', 'nuclei']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- Across a period, from left to right, smaller radius	['Across', 'period', 'left', 'right', 'smaller', 'radius']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38			- Atoms’ nuclei gain more proton, increase the effective nuclear charge, which 		  exerts a stronger pull on electrons in the same principle energy level.	['Atoms', 'nuclei', 'gain', 'proton', 'increase', 'effective', 'nuclear', 'charge', 'exerts', 'stronger', 'pull', 'electrons', 'principle', 'energy', 'level']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- Down a group, larger radius	['group', 'larger', 'radius']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38			- Atoms have more principle energy level, which larger orbitals means that the 		  valence electrons are further from the nucleus.	['Atoms', 'principle', 'energy', 'level', 'larger', 'orbitals', 'means', 'valence', 'electrons', 'nucleus']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Sizes of Ions:	['Sizes', 'Ions']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- Ionic size depends on:	['Ionic', 'size', 'depends']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	nuclear charge	['nuclear', 'charge']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	number of electron	['number', 'electron']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	orbitals in which electrons reside	['orbitals', 'electrons', 'reside']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- Cations (positive charge ions) are smaller than their parent atoms	['Cations', 'positive', 'charge', 'ions', 'smaller', 'parent', 'atoms']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38			- Outermost electron removed & repulsion reduced	['Outermost', 'electron', 'removed', 'repulsion', 'reduced']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- Antions (negative charge ions) are larger than their parent atoms	['Antions', 'negative', 'charge', 'ions', 'larger', 'parent', 'atoms']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38			- Electron added & repulsion increase	['Electron', 'added', 'repulsion', 'increase']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- Ionic size increase down group	['Ionic', 'size', 'increase', 'group']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- In isoelectronic series, ions with same number of electrons, ionic size decreases with 	  an increasing nuclear charge.	['isoelectronic', 'series', 'ions', 'number', 'electrons', 'ionic', 'size', 'decreases', 'increasing', 'nuclear', 'charge']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	7.4 Ionization	['Ionization']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Ionization Energy:	['Ionization', 'Energy']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Amount of energy required to remove an electron (valence electron first) from the 	    	  ground state of a gaseous state of a gaseous atom or ion (akways positive). (Minimum 	  energy required to remove an electron)	['Amount', 'energy', 'required', 'remove', 'electron', 'valence', 'electron', 'first', 'ground', 'state', 'gaseous', 'state', 'gaseous', 'atom', 'ion', 'akways', 'positive', 'Minimum', 'energy', 'required', 'remove', 'electron']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- First ionization energy, second ionization energy, etc.	['First', 'ionization', 'energy', 'second', 'ionization', 'energy', 'etc']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- Requires more energy to remove each successive electron	['Requires', 'energy', 'remove', 'successive', 'electron']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	First ionization energy: energy required to move 1st electron	['First', 'ionization', 'energy', 'energy', 'required', 'move', 'electron']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Down a group, less ionization energy	['group', 'less', 'ionization', 'energy']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- Zeff issame, valence electrons further away from nucleus	['Zeff', 'issame', 'valence', 'electrons', 'away', 'nucleus']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Across period, ionization energy increase (harder to remove electron)	['Across', 'period', 'ionization', 'energy', 'increase', 'harder', 'remove', 'electron']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Zeff increase	['Zeff', 'increase']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Exceptions: discontinueties 	['Exceptions', 'discontinueties']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Group 5A to 6A (double occupied orbitals)	['Group', 'double', 'occupied', 'orbitals']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Group 2A to 3A (electron taken from s orbital which is more attracted to 	 	  nucleus)	['Group', 'electron', 'taken', 'orbital', 'attracted', 'nucleus']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	When all valence electrons have been removed (it takes from noble gas core), the ionization energy takes a quantum leap. 	['valence', 'electrons', 'removed', 'takes', 'noble', 'gas', 'core', 'ionization', 'energy', 'takes', 'quantum', 'leap']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	7.5 Electron Affinity	['Electron', 'Affinity']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Electron affinity:	['Electron', 'affinity']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- Energy change when adding an electron to gaseous atom.	['Energy', 'change', 'adding', 'electron', 'gaseous', 'atom']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- The more negative of the electron affinity, the greater attraction to the added electron 	['negative', 'electron', 'affinity', 'greater', 'attraction', 'added', 'electron']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- Electron affinity are more exothermic across period and down a group (easier to gain 	  electron, more negative)	['Electron', 'affinity', 'exothermic', 'across', 'period', 'group', 'easier', 'gain', 'electron', 'negative']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- Exception:	['Exception']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Group 2A: Added electron goes to p orbital, takes more energy going to higher energy level	['Group', 'Added', 'electron', 'goes', 'p', 'orbital', 'takes', 'energy', 'going', 'higher', 'energy', 'level']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Group 5A: Has no empty orbital, extra electron goes to occupied electron orbitals, which creates repulsion	['Group', 'empty', 'orbital', 'extra', 'electron', 'goes', 'occupied', 'electron', 'orbitals', 'creates', 'repulsion']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Electronegativity:	['Electronegativity']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- The ability of an atom to attract electrons when the atom is in a compound 	['ability', 'atom', 'attract', 'electrons', 'atom', 'compound']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Pauling scale: 0.7 - 4.0	['Pauling', 'scale']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- Down a group, decreases 	['group', 'decreases']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Valence shell are getting less strongly held by the nucleus. Harder for the atom to attract one electron.	['Valence', 'shell', 'getting', 'less', 'strongly', 'held', 'nucleus', 'Harder', 'atom', 'attract', 'one', 'electron']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- Across period, increases	['Across', 'period', 'increases']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Attractions from the nucleus is getting greater. Getting easier for atom to attract one electron.	['Attractions', 'nucleus', 'getting', 'greater', 'Getting', 'easier', 'atom', 'attract', 'one', 'electron']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	7.6 Metal, Nonmetals, and Metalloids	['Metal', 'Nonmetals', 'Metalloids']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Across preiod, metallic characters decrease	['Across', 'preiod', 'metallic', 'characters', 'decrease']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Down a group, metallic characters increase	['group', 'metallic', 'characters', 'increase']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Metals:	['Metals']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- Elements that are generally shiny, malleable, and ductile 	['Elements', 'generally', 'shiny', 'malleable', 'ductile']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- Good conducters	['Good', 'conducters']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- Metals tend to form anions	['Metals', 'tend', 'form', 'anions']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- Compounds for between metals and nonmetals tend to be ionic 	['Compounds', 'metals', 'nonmetals', 'tend', 'ionic']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- Metal oxides tend to be basic 	['Metal', 'oxides', 'tend', 'basic']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Nonmetals:	['Nonmetals']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- Occupies the upper right side of periodic table	['Occupies', 'upper', 'right', 'side', 'periodic', 'table']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- Generally gases or brittle, dull-looking solids	['Generally', 'gases', 'brittle', 'solids']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- Poor conducter 	['Poor', 'conducter']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- Subtances containing only nonmetals are molecular compounds 	['Subtances', 'containing', 'nonmetals', 'molecular', 'compounds']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- Most nonmetal oxides are acidic	['nonmetal', 'oxides', 'acidic']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Metalloids:	['Metalloids']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- Elememts with physical & chemical properties of both metal and nonmetal	['Elememts', 'physical', 'chemical', 'properties', 'metal', 'nonmetal']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- fairly poor conducter 	['fairly', 'poor', 'conducter']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Chapter 8: Basic Concepts of Chemical Bonding	['Chapter', 'Basic', 'Concepts', 'Chemical', 'Bonding']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Coulomb’s law: 	['Coulomb', 'law']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	formation of chemical bond — Chapter 8: Basic Concepts of Chemical Bonding	['formation', 'chemical', 'bond', 'Chapter', 'Basic', 'Concepts', 'Chemical', 'Bonding']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Coulomb’s law: 	['Coulomb', 'law']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	formation of chemical bond —> more stable —> less potential energy	['formation', 'chemical', 'bond', 'stable', 'less', 'potential', 'energy']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	chemical bond: the electrostatic attraction force that holds two atoms together	['chemical', 'bond', 'electrostatic', 'attraction', 'force', 'holds', 'two', 'atoms', 'together']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	8.1 Lewis Symbols and the Octet Rule	['Lewis', 'Symbols', 'Octet', 'Rule']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	octet rule: all electrons tend to have 8 electrons in the outermost shell (stable octet)	['octet', 'rule', 'electrons', 'tend', 'electrons', 'outermost', 'shell', 'stable', 'octet']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	attained through losing, gaining, or sharing electrons	['attained', 'losing', 'gaining', 'sharing', 'electrons']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	lewis symbol: an element’s chemical symbol with a dot for each valence electron	['lewis', 'symbol', 'element', 'chemical', 'symbol', 'dot', 'valence', 'electron']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	8.2 Ionic Bonds	['Ionic', 'Bonds']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	ionic bond: attraction between cations and anions	['ionic', 'bond', 'attraction', 'cations', 'anions']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	usually metals and nonmetals, i.e. NaCl (Na+Cl-)	['usually', 'metals', 'nonmetals', 'NaCl']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	elements with low electronegativity (metals, H) tend to form cations	['elements', 'low', 'electronegativity', 'metals', 'H', 'tend', 'form', 'cations']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	lose electrons because number valence electrons is a lot less than 8	['lose', 'electrons', 'number', 'valence', 'electrons', 'lot', 'less']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	usually exothermic	['usually', 'exothermic']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	elements with high electronegativity (nonmetals) tend to form anions	['elements', 'high', 'electronegativity', 'nonmetals', 'tend', 'form', 'anions']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	charge of monoatomic anion = |8 - number of electrons|	['charge', 'monoatomic', 'anion', 'number']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	exothermic process	['exothermic', 'process']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	representative elements (Mg, Al, etc.): charge of ion = number of valence electrons (group number)	['representative', 'elements', 'Mg', 'Al', 'etc', 'charge', 'ion', 'number', 'valence', 'electrons', 'group', 'number']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	transition elements (Cr, Fe): various elements with different charges, reference the packet	['transition', 'elements', 'Cr', 'Fe', 'various', 'elements', 'different', 'charges', 'reference', 'packet']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	1B to 4A periods 4-6: pseudo-noble gas notation, relatively stable	['periods', 'gas', 'notation', 'relatively', 'stable']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	structure of ionic compounds	['structure', 'ionic', 'compounds']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	do not exist as discrete units but as collections of charged ions in patterns	['exist', 'discrete', 'units', 'collections', 'charged', 'ions', 'patterns']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	formula unit: lowest whole number ration of ions in an ionic compound (chemical formula)	['formula', 'unit', 'lowest', 'whole', 'number', 'ration', 'ions', 'ionic', 'compound', 'chemical', 'formula']
5 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	properties of ionic compounds	['properties', 'ionic', 'compounds']

3 IDX G9 CHEM H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	If the number right next to the last sig. fig. is less than 5, don’t change the last significant figure.	['number', 'right', 'next', 'last', 'sig', 'fig', 'less', 'change', 'last', 'significant', 'figure']

5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Determine the number of valence electrons(eg. H has 1)	['Determine', 'number', 'valence', 'electrons', 'eg', 'H']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	draw 1 dot for 1 valence electron(for H, since only 1 valence, only need to draw 1)	['draw', 'dot', 'valence', 'electron', 'H', 'since', 'valence', 'need', 'draw']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	for most cases (exceptions are not considered in the test), valence electrons should be as spread out on the four sides of the letter as possible (hunds rule)	['cases', 'exceptions', 'considered', 'test', 'valence', 'electrons', 'spread', 'four', 'sides', 'letter', 'possible', 'hunds', 'rule']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Table for lewis symbols:	['Table', 'lewis', 'symbols']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	8.2 Ionic Bonding	['Ionic', 'Bonding']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Because of the octet rule, atoms want to gain/lose electrons to form noble gas configuration	['octet', 'rule', 'atoms', 'want', 'electrons', 'form', 'noble', 'gas', 'configuration']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Losing electrons == cation (+)	['Losing', 'electrons', 'cation']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Gaining electrons == anion (-)	['Gaining', 'electrons', 'anion']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Eg: for Halogens (group 17), because they have 7 valence and need 1 more to achieve valence, they often appear as anions (1-)	['Eg', 'Halogens', 'group', 'valence', 'need', 'achieve', 'valence', 'often', 'appear', 'anions']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Tip for the test: Check the periodic table before you do bonding questions !	['Tip', 'test', 'Check', 'periodic', 'table', 'bonding', 'questions']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	PPT slide demonstrating how cations form	['PPT', 'slide', 'demonstrating', 'cations', 'form']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	For elements from group 1B through 4A in periods 4 through 6, they form the ions by forming a pseudo-noble gas notation which is relatively stable as well.	['elements', 'group', 'periods', 'form', 'ions', 'forming', 'gas', 'notation', 'relatively', 'stable', 'well']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Eg. Zn, Pb, Ag,…	['Eg', 'Zn', 'Pb', 'Ag']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Ionic Compounds:	['Ionic', 'Compounds']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Ionic compounds can be described as simply the bond between cations and anions. The cations give electrons to the anions, creating an electrostatic force that bonds the two together.	['Ionic', 'compounds', 'described', 'simply', 'bond', 'cations', 'anions', 'cations', 'give', 'electrons', 'anions', 'creating', 'electrostatic', 'force', 'bonds', 'two', 'together']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Tip for the test: When asked to explain trends of ionic bonds, refer to the Coulomb’s Law	['Tip', 'test', 'asked', 'explain', 'trends', 'ionic', 'bonds', 'refer', 'Coulomb', 'Law']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Ionic Compounds must be neutral(balance of charges in cations and anions).	['Ionic', 'Compounds', 'must', 'neutral', 'balance', 'charges', 'cations', 'anions']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The chemical formula of an ionic compound refers to a ratio known as a formula unit (the lowest whole-number ratio of ions in an ionic compound).	['chemical', 'formula', 'ionic', 'compound', 'refers', 'ratio', 'known', 'formula', 'unit', 'lowest', 'ratio', 'ions', 'ionic', 'compound']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Ionic compounds exist in groups. When they are grouped together, the pattern is always +-+-+-..., making it look like a lattice, which we referr to as lattice structures.	['Ionic', 'compounds', 'exist', 'groups', 'grouped', 'together', 'pattern', 'always', 'making', 'look', 'like', 'lattice', 'referr', 'lattice', 'structures']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Properties of Ionic Compounds:	['Properties', 'Ionic', 'Compounds']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Ionic compound has a high melting point and hardness	['Ionic', 'compound', 'high', 'melting', 'point', 'hardness']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Ionic compounds are brittle.	['Ionic', 'compounds', 'brittle']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Solid ionic compounds do not conduct electricity but molten ionic compounds or aqueous solutions of ionic compounds do.	['Solid', 'ionic', 'compounds', 'conduct', 'electricity', 'molten', 'ionic', 'compounds', 'aqueous', 'solutions', 'ionic', 'compounds']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Critical thinking: Why do ionic compounds in aqueous solutions/molten state conduct electricity?	['Critical', 'thinking', 'ionic', 'compounds', 'aqueous', 'state', 'conduct', 'electricity']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	So, since we already know what lattice structures are, what is lattice energy then?	['since', 'already', 'know', 'lattice', 'structures', 'lattice', 'energy']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	-lattice energy is the energy required to completely separate ions in 1 mole of solid ionic structure to its gaseous ions.	['energy', 'energy', 'required', 'completely', 'separate', 'ions', 'mole', 'solid', 'ionic', 'structure', 'gaseous', 'ions']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Critical thinking: How would lattice energy increase?	['Critical', 'thinking', 'would', 'lattice', 'energy', 'increase']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	8.3 Covalent Bonds	['Covalent', 'Bonds']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Review: What is the definition of valence electrons?	['Review', 'definition', 'valence', 'electrons']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Covalent bonds are where electrons are shared between elements for the sake that both of them can achieve octet.	['Covalent', 'bonds', 'electrons', 'shared', 'elements', 'sake', 'achieve', 'octet']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	It occurs when atoms have quite high electronegativities	['occurs', 'atoms', 'quite', 'high', 'electronegativities']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Critical thinking: so what properties do elements involved in covalent bonds have?	['Critical', 'thinking', 'properties', 'elements', 'involved', 'covalent', 'bonds']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Here are the different number of covalent bonds(general trends):	['different', 'number', 'covalent', 'bonds', 'general', 'trends']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Critical Thinking: What conclusion can you draw from this trend?	['Critical', 'Thinking', 'conclusion', 'draw', 'trend']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Types of Bonds (by shape)	['Types', 'Bonds', 'shape']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Sigma bonds and Pi bonds	['Sigma', 'bonds', 'Pi', 'bonds']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Sigma bonds have overlap of electrons focused on the intermolecular axis.	['Sigma', 'bonds', 'overlap', 'electrons', 'focused', 'intermolecular', 'axis']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The electron density is focused in the middle	['electron', 'density', 'focused', 'middle']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Pi bonds only occur in p orbitals, and is where the p shells overlap vertically, forming two sausage-shaped clouds of electrons parallel to the intermolecular axis	['Pi', 'bonds', 'occur', 'p', 'orbitals', 'p', 'shells', 'overlap', 'vertically', 'forming', 'two', 'clouds', 'electrons', 'parallel', 'intermolecular', 'axis']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Pi bonds have less energy because they have more repulsion	['Pi', 'bonds', 'less', 'energy', 'repulsion']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Covalent bonds can exist in double or triple bonds.	['Covalent', 'bonds', 'exist', 'double', 'triple', 'bonds']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Single bonds consist of 1 sigma	['Single', 'bonds', 'consist', 'sigma']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Double bonds consist of 1 sigma + 1 pi	['Double', 'bonds', 'consist', 'sigma', 'pi']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Triple bonds consist of 1 sigma + 2 pi	['Triple', 'bonds', 'consist', 'sigma', 'pi']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	8.4 Bond Polarity and Electronegativity	['Bond', 'Polarity', 'Electronegativity']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Bond polarity is a measure of how equally or unequally the electrons in any covalent bond are shared. 	['Bond', 'polarity', 'measure', 'equally', 'unequally', 'electrons', 'covalent', 'bond', 'shared']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	A nonpolar covalent bond is one in which the electrons are shared equally, as in Cl2 and N2. 	['nonpolar', 'covalent', 'bond', 'one', 'electrons', 'shared', 'equally']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	In a polar covalent bond, one of the atoms exerts a	['polar', 'covalent', 'bond', 'one', 'atoms', 'exerts']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	greater attraction for the bonding electrons than the other. 	['greater', 'attraction', 'bonding', 'electrons']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	If the difference in relative ability to attract electrons is large enough, an ionic bond is formed.	['difference', 'relative', 'ability', 'attract', 'electrons', 'large', 'enough', 'ionic', 'bond', 'formed']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Electronegativity:	['Electronegativity']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	In general, electronegativity values  decrease top to bottom，increase left to right.	['general', 'electronegativity', 'values', 'decrease', 'top', 'left', 'right']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Test tip: DONT explain questions through direct trends, instead focus on reasons behind the trends, which requires critical thinking	['Test', 'tip', 'DONT', 'explain', 'questions', 'direct', 'trends', 'instead', 'focus', 'reasons', 'behind', 'trends', 'requires', 'critical', 'thinking']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Polarity refers to a separation of positive and negative charge.  In a nonpolar bond, the bonding electrons are shared equally (diatomic molecules, for example)	['Polarity', 'refers', 'separation', 'positive', 'negative', 'charge', 'nonpolar', 'bond', 'bonding', 'electrons', 'shared', 'equally', 'diatomic', 'molecules', 'example']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	In a polar bond, electrons are shared unequally.	['polar', 'bond', 'electrons', 'shared', 'unequally']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Can use electronegativity difference (pauling scale) to determine the type of bond:	['use', 'electronegativity', 'difference', 'pauling', 'scale', 'determine', 'type', 'bond']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Dipole moments: 	['Dipole', 'moments']
5 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	A positive to negative partial charge in an atom is measured as its dipole moment.	['positive', 'negative', 'partial', 'charge', 'atom', 'measured', 'dipole', 'moment']

4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Chapter 6: Electronic Structure of Atoms	['Chapter', 'Electronic', 'Structure', 'Atoms']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	6.1 Wave Nature of Light	['Wave', 'Nature', 'Light']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Review	['Review']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Light is a kind of electromagnetic radiation.  An electromagnetic wave consists of electric and magnetic fields oscillating at right angles.	['Light', 'kind', 'electromagnetic', 'radiation', 'electromagnetic', 'wave', 'consists', 'electric', 'magnetic', 'fields', 'oscillating', 'right', 'angles']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The distance between corresponding points on adjacent waves is the wavelength ().	['distance', 'corresponding', 'points', 'adjacent', 'waves', 'wavelength']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The number of waves passing a given point per unit of time is the frequency ().	['number', 'waves', 'passing', 'given', 'point', 'per', 'unit', 'time', 'frequency']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The SI unit for frequency is Hertz, or Hz	['SI', 'unit', 'frequency', 'Hertz', 'Hz']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The electromagnetic spectrum separates waves into different levels 	['electromagnetic', 'spectrum', 'separates', 'waves', 'different', 'levels']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Wavelength, frequecy, and energy of waves of the visible light spectrum are arranged as following: violet < indigo < blue < green < yellow < orange < red.	['Wavelength', 'frequecy', 'energy', 'waves', 'visible', 'light', 'spectrum', 'arranged', 'following', 'violet', 'indigo', 'blue', 'green', 'yellow', 'orange', 'red']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Wave model does not explain how light can form when temperature increases (neon lights)	['Wave', 'model', 'explain', 'light', 'form', 'temperature', 'increases', 'neon', 'lights']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Quantum: the smallest amount of energy (in chemistry)	['Quantum', 'smallest', 'amount', 'energy', 'chemistry']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Formula for 1 quantum of energy: E = hv	['Formula', 'quantum', 'energy', 'E', 'hv']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Photoelectric effect: electrons are ejected when light shines on a metal.	['Photoelectric', 'effect', 'electrons', 'ejected', 'light', 'shines', 'metal']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Kinetic Energy of electron ejected: KE = Ephoton — Ethreshold	['Kinetic', 'Energy', 'electron', 'ejected', 'KE', 'Ephoton', 'Ethreshold']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Hydrogen Line Spectrum: Electrons can be excited to higher energy levels when it absorb energy. When the atom is in an excited state, the electron can drop from a higher energy level to a lower energy level. As a result, the atom emits a photon corresponding to the difference between the energy levels associated with two orbits. only certain frequencies of radiation can be emitted. 	['Hydrogen', 'Line', 'Spectrum', 'Electrons', 'excited', 'higher', 'energy', 'levels', 'absorb', 'energy', 'atom', 'excited', 'state', 'electron', 'drop', 'higher', 'energy', 'level', 'lower', 'energy', 'level', 'result', 'atom', 'emits', 'photon', 'corresponding', 'difference', 'energy', 'levels', 'associated', 'two', 'orbits', 'certain', 'frequencies', 'radiation', 'emitted']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	6.4 Wave Nature of Matter	['Wave', 'Nature', 'Matter']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Louis de Broglie theorized that if light can have material properties, matter should exhibit wave properties.	['Louis', 'de', 'Broglie', 'theorized', 'light', 'material', 'properties', 'matter', 'exhibit', 'wave', 'properties']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Formula	['Formula']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle: The position and the velocity of a moving electron at one point cannot be measured at the same time	['Heisenberg', 'Uncertainty', 'Principle', 'position', 'velocity', 'moving', 'electron', 'one', 'point', 'measured', 'time']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	6.5 Quantum Mechanics (VERY IMPORTANT)	['Quantum', 'Mechanics', 'IMPORTANT']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Schrödinger found the quantum mechanical model	['Schrödinger', 'found', 'quantum', 'mechanical', 'model']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	There are three properties of the model	['three', 'properties', 'model']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The energy of electron is quantized (Bohr model)	['energy', 'electron', 'quantized', 'Bohr', 'model']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Electrons exhibit wavelike behavior (de Broglie)	['Electrons', 'exhibit', 'wavelike', 'behavior', 'de', 'Broglie']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The exact position as well as momentum/velocity of an electron at any given point is impossible to know (Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle)	['exact', 'position', 'well', 'electron', 'given', 'point', 'impossible', 'know', 'Heisenberg', 'Uncertainty', 'Principle']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Solutions to the Schrödinger equation lead to a mathematical expression, called an atomic orbital.	['Solutions', 'Schrödinger', 'equation', 'lead', 'mathematical', 'expression', 'called', 'atomic', 'orbital']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	An atomic orbital is represented pictorially as a region of space in which there is a high probability of finding an electron.	['atomic', 'orbital', 'represented', 'pictorially', 'region', 'space', 'high', 'probability', 'finding', 'electron']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	There are differences between the bohr model and the quantum mechanical model: The bohr model explains how electrons exist in fixed orbits and pathways, while the quantum mechanical model is where electrons exist in a probability-based region of the atom	['differences', 'bohr', 'model', 'quantum', 'mechanical', 'model', 'bohr', 'model', 'explains', 'electrons', 'exist', 'fixed', 'orbits', 'pathways', 'quantum', 'mechanical', 'model', 'electrons', 'exist', 'region', 'atom']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	6.6 Representation of Orbitals	['Representation', 'Orbitals']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The quantum mechanical model provides theory of the existence of different atomic orbitals	['quantum', 'mechanical', 'model', 'provides', 'theory', 'existence', 'different', 'atomic', 'orbitals']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The atomic orbitals can be classified as: S, P, D, and F	['atomic', 'orbitals', 'classified', 'P', 'F']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Each orbital can hold up to no more than 2 electrons each	['orbital', 'hold', 'electrons']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	For every principle energy level (in the section later), there is 1, 3, 5,7 orbitals for the s,p,d,f shells, as the orientation of the shells may be different in a 3d plane	['every', 'principle', 'energy', 'level', 'section', 'later', 'orbitals', 'p', 'f', 'shells', 'orientation', 'shells', 'may', 'different', 'plane']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The principal quantum number, n, always equals the number of sublevels within that principal energy level.	['principal', 'quantum', 'number', 'n', 'always', 'equals', 'number', 'sublevels', 'within', 'principal', 'energy', 'level']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Critical thinking question: how does the size and shape of the orbitals change as the principal quantum number changes in a hydrogen molecule? What about in a multi-electron system?	['Critical', 'thinking', 'question', 'size', 'shape', 'orbitals', 'change', 'principal', 'quantum', 'number', 'changes', 'hydrogen', 'molecule', 'system']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	6.7 Electron Structure of Atoms (Notice that there is a difference in structure of hydrogen atom and a multi-electron atom)	['Electron', 'Structure', 'Atoms', 'Notice', 'difference', 'structure', 'hydrogen', 'atom', 'atom']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Degenerate orbitals: orbitals with the same energy	['Degenerate', 'orbitals', 'orbitals', 'energy']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The electron structure of atoms are involved in a pattern, going from s to p to d then to f, as the charges of each orbital increase with the principal quantum number	['electron', 'structure', 'atoms', 'involved', 'pattern', 'going', 'p', 'f', 'charges', 'orbital', 'increase', 'principal', 'quantum', 'number']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	In the quantum mechanical model’s electron configuration, there are three rules that you need to follow. THESE RULES ARE IMPORTANT AND DEFINITELY WILL BE ON THE TEST	['quantum', 'mechanical', 'model', 'electron', 'configuration', 'three', 'rules', 'need', 'follow', 'RULES', 'IMPORTANT', 'DEFINITELY', 'TEST']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The Aufbau Principle: Electrons occupy orbitals of the lower energy first	['Aufbau', 'Principle', 'Electrons', 'occupy', 'orbitals', 'lower', 'energy', 'first']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	As mentioned, the charge of the orbitals are arranged as the following in the same principle quantum level: s<p<d<f	['mentioned', 'charge', 'orbitals', 'arranged', 'following', 'principle', 'quantum', 'level', 'p', 'f']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The Pauli Exclusion Principle: No two electrons in the same atom can have the same quantum number.	['Pauli', 'Exclusion', 'Principle', 'two', 'electrons', 'atom', 'quantum', 'number']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Translation: the quantum number is divided into many portions. You can understand it as there are different conditions to identify an electron. For example, an electron can be identified by its pqn, its type of orbital, its direction of spin, etc.	['Translation', 'quantum', 'number', 'divided', 'many', 'portions', 'understand', 'different', 'conditions', 'identify', 'electron', 'example', 'electron', 'identified', 'pqn', 'type', 'orbital', 'direction', 'spin', 'etc']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	As a result, no electron of the same orbital can have the same direction of spin, and each orbital can only hold 2 electrons	['result', 'electron', 'orbital', 'direction', 'spin', 'orbital', 'hold', 'electrons']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The Hund’s Rule: For degenerate orbitals, the lowest energy is attained when the number of electrons with the same spin is maximized.	['Hund', 'Rule', 'degenerate', 'orbitals', 'lowest', 'energy', 'attained', 'number', 'electrons', 'spin', 'maximized']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Translation: to keep the electron configuration accurate and stable, for each orbital of the same energy, the number of electrons with the same spin must be greatest	['Translation', 'keep', 'electron', 'configuration', 'accurate', 'stable', 'orbital', 'energy', 'number', 'electrons', 'spin', 'must', 'greatest']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Electron configuration: the arrangement of electrons into the different subshells of different energy levels in a quantum mechanical model	['Electron', 'configuration', 'arrangement', 'electrons', 'different', 'subshells', 'different', 'energy', 'levels', 'quantum', 'mechanical', 'model']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The electrons, as the Aufbau principle writes, are arraged from lower to higher energy levels	['electrons', 'Aufbau', 'principle', 'writes', 'arraged', 'lower', 'higher', 'energy', 'levels']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The first number is the principal quantum number, the letter is the orbital type, and the “exponential” on the right is the number of electrons in each subshell	['first', 'number', 'principal', 'quantum', 'number', 'letter', 'orbital', 'type', 'exponential', 'right', 'number', 'electrons', 'subshell']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	(Note: The configuration of electrons is very difficult to explain and requires lots of practice to understand. You should know how to do your homework.)	['Note', 'configuration', 'electrons', 'difficult', 'explain', 'requires', 'lots', 'practice', 'understand', 'know', 'homework']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Abbreviated configuration: The configuration of electrons of elements can be written as the closest noble gas element (must be smaller than the element itself) added with the additional subshells following it. Example: Cl:  [Ne] 3s2 3p5	['Abbreviated', 'configuration', 'configuration', 'electrons', 'elements', 'written', 'closest', 'noble', 'gas', 'element', 'must', 'smaller', 'element', 'added', 'additional', 'subshells', 'following', 'Example', 'Cl', 'Ne']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The inner-shell electrons are referred to as the core electrons.	['electrons', 'referred', 'core', 'electrons']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The electrons given after the noble-gas core are called the outer-shell electrons. The outer-shell electrons include the electrons involved in chemical bonding, which are called the valence electrons.	['electrons', 'given', 'core', 'called', 'electrons', 'electrons', 'include', 'electrons', 'involved', 'chemical', 'bonding', 'called', 'valence', 'electrons']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	For the elements with atomic number 30 or less, all of the outer-shell electrons are valence electrons.  	['elements', 'atomic', 'number', 'less', 'electrons', 'valence', 'electrons']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Electron configuration of ions: First write configuration of the element’s neutral state, then decide whether to loose or gain electrons based on whether it is a cation or an anion. 4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Some actual electron configurations differ from those assigned using the aufbau principle because although half-filled sublevels are not as stable as filled sublevels, they are more stable than other configurations. 4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Uncertainty and Significant Figures	['Uncertainty', 'Significant', 'Figures']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Uncertainty: Measurements in chemistry might be inaccurate by eye. This will create uncertainty or being unsure of the exact value of something. 4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Error = experimental value – accepted value	['Error', 'experimental', 'value', 'accepted', 'value']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Can be negative	['negative']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Systematic error:	['Systematic', 'error']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	incorrectly zeroed balance	['incorrectly', 'zeroed', 'balance']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	poorly calibrated or badly made instruments	['poorly', 'calibrated', 'badly', 'made', 'instruments']

4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	improper conditions	['improper', 'conditions']

4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Systematic errors cannot be reduced by repetition.	['Systematic', 'errors', 'reduced', 'repetition']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Poor precision in measurements is associated with random uncertainty. 	['Poor', 'precision', 'measurements', 'associated', 'random', 'uncertainty']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Error associated with estimating the last digit of a reading is called random uncertainty. Random uncertainties arise mostly from limitations in the instrument. 	['Error', 'associated', 'estimating', 'last', 'digit', 'reading', 'called', 'random', 'uncertainty', 'Random', 'uncertainties', 'arise', 'mostly', 'limitations', 'instrument']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	This type of error is such that the value recorded is sometimes higher than the true value, sometimes lower.	['type', 'error', 'value', 'recorded', 'sometimes', 'higher', 'true', 'value', 'sometimes', 'lower']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Repeating the measurement a number of times and averaging the results reduces the effect of random uncertainty.	['Repeating', 'measurement', 'number', 'times', 'averaging', 'results', 'reduces', 'effect', 'random', 'uncertainty']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Usually，only one significant figure should be kept.	['one', 'significant', 'figure', 'kept']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Percentage uncertainty: The percentage uncertainty changes with the amount of material that you are measuring. 4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	1790s: Antoine Lavoisier compiled a list of 23 elements known at the time; by 1870, there were approximately 70 known elements	['Antoine', 'Lavoisier', 'compiled', 'list', 'elements', 'known', 'time', 'approximately', 'known', 'elements']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	1860s: Chemists developed and agreed upon a method of determining the atomic mass of elements	['Chemists', 'developed', 'agreed', 'upon', 'method', 'determining', 'atomic', 'mass', 'elements']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	1864: John Newlands observed the repetition of properties in every eight elements. This demonstrates a periodic change because it repeats a specific manner.	['John', 'Newlands', 'observed', 'repetition', 'properties', 'every', 'eight', 'elements', 'demonstrates', 'periodic', 'change', 'repeats', 'specific', 'manner']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	1869: Dmitri Mendeleev and Lothar Meyer both demonstrated connection between atomic mass and elemental properties. Mendeleev was given more credit because he was the earliest one to publish his organization plan and demonstrated how it was useful	['Dmitri', 'Mendeleev', 'Lothar', 'Meyer', 'demonstrated', 'connection', 'atomic', 'mass', 'elemental', 'properties', 'Mendeleev', 'given', 'credit', 'earliest', 'one', 'publish', 'organization', 'plan', 'demonstrated', 'useful']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Mendeleev noticed that when the elements were ordered by increasing atomic mass, there was a repetition, or periodic pattern, in their chemical and physical properties.	['Mendeleev', 'noticed', 'elements', 'ordered', 'increasing', 'atomic', 'mass', 'repetition', 'periodic', 'pattern', 'chemical', 'physical', 'properties']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	He showed that the properties of the elements repeat in an orderly way from row to row of the table.	['showed', 'properties', 'elements', 'repeat', 'orderly', 'way', 'row', 'row', 'table']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Elements in vertical columns showed similar properties.	['Elements', 'vertical', 'columns', 'showed', 'similar', 'properties']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Mendeleev correctly predicted the existence and properties of undiscovered elements.	['Mendeleev', 'correctly', 'predicted', 'existence', 'properties', 'undiscovered', 'elements']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	In order to group elements with similar properties in the same columns, Mendeleev had to leave some blank spaces in his table.  	['order', 'group', 'elements', 'similar', 'properties', 'columns', 'Mendeleev', 'leave', 'blank', 'spaces', 'table']
4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	By noting the trends in the properties of known elements, he was able to predict the properties of the yet-to-be discovered elements scandium, gallium, and germanium (which he called eka-silicon）. 4 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	In 1913, Henry Moseley’s arrangement of elements by atomic number resulted in a clear periodic pattern of properties.	['Henry', 'Moseley', 'arrangement', 'elements', 'atomic', 'number', 'resulted', 'clear', 'periodic', 'pattern', 'properties']
