3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	6.1 Wave Nature of Light	['Wave', 'Nature', 'Light']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Review	['Review']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Light is a kind of electromagnetic radiation.  An electromagnetic wave consists of electric and magnetic fields oscillating at right angles.	['Light', 'kind', 'electromagnetic', 'radiation', 'electromagnetic', 'wave', 'consists', 'electric', 'magnetic', 'fields', 'oscillating', 'right', 'angles']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The distance between corresponding points on adjacent waves is the wavelength ().	['distance', 'corresponding', 'points', 'adjacent', 'waves', 'wavelength']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The number of waves passing a given point per unit of time is the frequency ().	['number', 'waves', 'passing', 'given', 'point', 'per', 'unit', 'time', 'frequency']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The SI unit for frequency is Hertz, or Hz	['SI', 'unit', 'frequency', 'Hertz', 'Hz']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The electromagnetic spectrum separates waves into different levels 	['electromagnetic', 'spectrum', 'separates', 'waves', 'different', 'levels']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Wavelength, frequecy, and energy of waves of the visible light spectrum are arranged as following: violet < indigo < blue < green < yellow < orange < red.	['Wavelength', 'frequecy', 'energy', 'waves', 'visible', 'light', 'spectrum', 'arranged', 'following', 'violet', 'indigo', 'blue', 'green', 'yellow', 'orange', 'red']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Wave model does not explain how light can form when temperature increases (neon lights)	['Wave', 'model', 'explain', 'light', 'form', 'temperature', 'increases', 'neon', 'lights']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Quantum: the smallest amount of energy (in chemistry)	['Quantum', 'smallest', 'amount', 'energy', 'chemistry']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Formula for 1 quantum of energy: E = hv	['Formula', 'quantum', 'energy', 'E', 'hv']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Photoelectric effect: electrons are ejected when light shines on a metal.	['Photoelectric', 'effect', 'electrons', 'ejected', 'light', 'shines', 'metal']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Kinetic Energy of electron ejected: KE = Ephoton — Ethreshold	['Kinetic', 'Energy', 'electron', 'ejected', 'KE', 'Ephoton', 'Ethreshold']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Hydrogen Line Spectrum: Electrons can be excited to higher energy levels when it absorb energy. When the atom is in an excited state, the electron can drop from a higher energy level to a lower energy level. As a result, the atom emits a photon corresponding to the difference between the energy levels associated with two orbits. only certain frequencies of radiation can be emitted. 	['Hydrogen', 'Line', 'Spectrum', 'Electrons', 'excited', 'higher', 'energy', 'levels', 'absorb', 'energy', 'atom', 'excited', 'state', 'electron', 'drop', 'higher', 'energy', 'level', 'lower', 'energy', 'level', 'result', 'atom', 'emits', 'photon', 'corresponding', 'difference', 'energy', 'levels', 'associated', 'two', 'orbits', 'certain', 'frequencies', 'radiation', 'emitted']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	6.4 Wave Nature of Matter	['Wave', 'Nature', 'Matter']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Louis de Broglie theorized that if light can have material properties, matter should exhibit wave properties.	['Louis', 'de', 'Broglie', 'theorized', 'light', 'material', 'properties', 'matter', 'exhibit', 'wave', 'properties']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Formula	['Formula']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle: The position and the velocity of a moving electron at one point cannot be measured at the same time	['Heisenberg', 'Uncertainty', 'Principle', 'position', 'velocity', 'moving', 'electron', 'one', 'point', 'measured', 'time']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	6.5 Quantum Mechanics (VERY IMPORTANT)	['Quantum', 'Mechanics', 'IMPORTANT']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Schrödinger found the quantum mechanical model	['Schrödinger', 'found', 'quantum', 'mechanical', 'model']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	There are three properties of the model	['three', 'properties', 'model']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The energy of electron is quantized (Bohr model)	['energy', 'electron', 'quantized', 'Bohr', 'model']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Electrons exhibit wavelike behavior (de Broglie)	['Electrons', 'exhibit', 'wavelike', 'behavior', 'de', 'Broglie']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The exact position as well as momentum/velocity of an electron at any given point is impossible to know (Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle)	['exact', 'position', 'well', 'electron', 'given', 'point', 'impossible', 'know', 'Heisenberg', 'Uncertainty', 'Principle']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Solutions to the Schrödinger equation lead to a mathematical expression, called an atomic orbital.	['Solutions', 'Schrödinger', 'equation', 'lead', 'mathematical', 'expression', 'called', 'atomic', 'orbital']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	An atomic orbital is represented pictorially as a region of space in which there is a high probability of finding an electron.	['atomic', 'orbital', 'represented', 'pictorially', 'region', 'space', 'high', 'probability', 'finding', 'electron']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	There are differences between the bohr model and the quantum mechanical model: The bohr model explains how electrons exist in fixed orbits and pathways, while the quantum mechanical model is where electrons exist in a probability-based region of the atom	['differences', 'bohr', 'model', 'quantum', 'mechanical', 'model', 'bohr', 'model', 'explains', 'electrons', 'exist', 'fixed', 'orbits', 'pathways', 'quantum', 'mechanical', 'model', 'electrons', 'exist', 'region', 'atom']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	6.6 Representation of Orbitals	['Representation', 'Orbitals']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The quantum mechanical model provides theory of the existence of different atomic orbitals	['quantum', 'mechanical', 'model', 'provides', 'theory', 'existence', 'different', 'atomic', 'orbitals']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The atomic orbitals can be classified as: S, P, D, and F	['atomic', 'orbitals', 'classified', 'P', 'F']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Each orbital can hold up to no more than 2 electrons each	['orbital', 'hold', 'electrons']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	For every principle energy level (in the section later), there is 1, 3, 5,7 orbitals for the s,p,d,f shells, as the orientation of the shells may be different in a 3d plane	['every', 'principle', 'energy', 'level', 'section', 'later', 'orbitals', 'p', 'f', 'shells', 'orientation', 'shells', 'may', 'different', 'plane']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The principal quantum number, n, always equals the number of sublevels within that principal energy level.	['principal', 'quantum', 'number', 'n', 'always', 'equals', 'number', 'sublevels', 'within', 'principal', 'energy', 'level']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Critical thinking question: how does the size and shape of the orbitals change as the principal quantum number changes in a hydrogen molecule? What about in a multi-electron system?	['Critical', 'thinking', 'question', 'size', 'shape', 'orbitals', 'change', 'principal', 'quantum', 'number', 'changes', 'hydrogen', 'molecule', 'system']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	6.7 Electron Structure of Atoms (Notice that there is a difference in structure of hydrogen atom and a multi-electron atom)	['Electron', 'Structure', 'Atoms', 'Notice', 'difference', 'structure', 'hydrogen', 'atom', 'atom']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Degenerate orbitals: orbitals with the same energy	['Degenerate', 'orbitals', 'orbitals', 'energy']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The electron structure of atoms are involved in a pattern, going from s to p to d then to f, as the charges of each orbital increase with the principal quantum number	['electron', 'structure', 'atoms', 'involved', 'pattern', 'going', 'p', 'f', 'charges', 'orbital', 'increase', 'principal', 'quantum', 'number']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	In the quantum mechanical model’s electron configuration, there are three rules that you need to follow. THESE RULES ARE IMPORTANT AND DEFINITELY WILL BE ON THE TEST	['quantum', 'mechanical', 'model', 'electron', 'configuration', 'three', 'rules', 'need', 'follow', 'RULES', 'IMPORTANT', 'DEFINITELY', 'TEST']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The Aufbau Principle: Electrons occupy orbitals of the lower energy first	['Aufbau', 'Principle', 'Electrons', 'occupy', 'orbitals', 'lower', 'energy', 'first']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	As mentioned, the charge of the orbitals are arranged as the following in the same principle quantum level: s<p<d<f	['mentioned', 'charge', 'orbitals', 'arranged', 'following', 'principle', 'quantum', 'level', 'p', 'f']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The Pauli Exclusion Principle: No two electrons in the same atom can have the same quantum number.	['Pauli', 'Exclusion', 'Principle', 'two', 'electrons', 'atom', 'quantum', 'number']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Translation: the quantum number is divided into many portions. You can understand it as there are different conditions to identify an electron. For example, an electron can be identified by its pqn, its type of orbital, its direction of spin, etc.	['Translation', 'quantum', 'number', 'divided', 'many', 'portions', 'understand', 'different', 'conditions', 'identify', 'electron', 'example', 'electron', 'identified', 'pqn', 'type', 'orbital', 'direction', 'spin', 'etc']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	As a result, no electron of the same orbital can have the same direction of spin, and each orbital can only hold 2 electrons	['result', 'electron', 'orbital', 'direction', 'spin', 'orbital', 'hold', 'electrons']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The Hund’s Rule: For degenerate orbitals, the lowest energy is attained when the number of electrons with the same spin is maximized.	['Hund', 'Rule', 'degenerate', 'orbitals', 'lowest', 'energy', 'attained', 'number', 'electrons', 'spin', 'maximized']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Translation: to keep the electron configuration accurate and stable, for each orbital of the same energy, the number of electrons with the same spin must be greatest	['Translation', 'keep', 'electron', 'configuration', 'accurate', 'stable', 'orbital', 'energy', 'number', 'electrons', 'spin', 'must', 'greatest']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Electron configuration: the arrangement of electrons into the different subshells of different energy levels in a quantum mechanical model	['Electron', 'configuration', 'arrangement', 'electrons', 'different', 'subshells', 'different', 'energy', 'levels', 'quantum', 'mechanical', 'model']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The electrons, as the Aufbau principle writes, are arraged from lower to higher energy levels	['electrons', 'Aufbau', 'principle', 'writes', 'arraged', 'lower', 'higher', 'energy', 'levels']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The first number is the principal quantum number, the letter is the orbital type, and the “exponential” on the right is the number of electrons in each subshell	['first', 'number', 'principal', 'quantum', 'number', 'letter', 'orbital', 'type', 'exponential', 'right', 'number', 'electrons', 'subshell']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	(Note: The configuration of electrons is very difficult to explain and requires lots of practice to understand. You should know how to do your homework.)	['Note', 'configuration', 'electrons', 'difficult', 'explain', 'requires', 'lots', 'practice', 'understand', 'know', 'homework']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Abbreviated configuration: The configuration of electrons of elements can be written as the closest noble gas element (must be smaller than the element itself) added with the additional subshells following it. Example: Cl:  [Ne] 3s2 3p5	['Abbreviated', 'configuration', 'configuration', 'electrons', 'elements', 'written', 'closest', 'noble', 'gas', 'element', 'must', 'smaller', 'element', 'added', 'additional', 'subshells', 'following', 'Example', 'Cl', 'Ne']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The inner-shell electrons are referred to as the core electrons.	['electrons', 'referred', 'core', 'electrons']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The electrons given after the noble-gas core are called the outer-shell electrons. The outer-shell electrons include the electrons involved in chemical bonding, which are called the valence electrons.	['electrons', 'given', 'core', 'called', 'electrons', 'electrons', 'include', 'electrons', 'involved', 'chemical', 'bonding', 'called', 'valence', 'electrons']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	For the elements with atomic number 30 or less, all of the outer-shell electrons are valence electrons.  	['elements', 'atomic', 'number', 'less', 'electrons', 'valence', 'electrons']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Electron configuration of ions: First write configuration of the element’s neutral state, then decide whether to loose or gain electrons based on whether it is a cation or an anion.	['Electron', 'configuration', 'ions', 'First', 'write', 'configuration', 'element', 'neutral', 'state', 'decide', 'whether', 'loose', 'gain', 'electrons', 'based', 'whether', 'cation', 'anion']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Some actual electron configurations differ from those assigned using the aufbau principle because although half-filled sublevels are not as stable as filled sublevels, they are more stable than other configurations.	['actual', 'electron', 'configurations', 'differ', 'assigned', 'using', 'aufbau', 'principle', 'although', 'sublevels', 'stable', 'filled', 'sublevels', 'stable', 'configurations']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Cr: 1s22s22p63s23p63d54s1	['Cr']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Cu: 1s22s22p63s23p63d104s1	['Cu']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Uncertainty and Significant Figures	['Uncertainty', 'Significant', 'Figures']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Uncertainty: Measurements in chemistry might be inaccurate by eye. This will create uncertainty or being unsure of the exact value of something. The uncertainty is calculated by half of the scale graduations	['Uncertainty', 'Measurements', 'chemistry', 'might', 'inaccurate', 'eye', 'create', 'uncertainty', 'unsure', 'exact', 'value', 'something', 'uncertainty', 'calculated', 'half', 'scale', 'graduations']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	To evaluate the accuracy of the experimental data, you may calculate the difference between experimental value and accepted value.	['evaluate', 'accuracy', 'experimental', 'data', 'may', 'calculate', 'difference', 'experimental', 'value', 'accepted', 'value']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Error = experimental value – accepted value	['Error', 'experimental', 'value', 'accepted', 'value']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Can be negative	['negative']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Systematic error:	['Systematic', 'error']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	incorrectly zeroed balance	['incorrectly', 'zeroed', 'balance']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	poorly calibrated or badly made instruments	['poorly', 'calibrated', 'badly', 'made', 'instruments']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	instrument parallax error (reading a scale from a position that is not directly in front of the scale)	['instrument', 'parallax', 'error', 'reading', 'scale', 'position', 'directly', 'front', 'scale']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	improper conditions	['improper', 'conditions']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Errors come from procedures, methods or theories	['Errors', 'come', 'procedures', 'methods', 'theories']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Systematic errors cannot be reduced by repetition.	['Systematic', 'errors', 'reduced', 'repetition']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Poor precision in measurements is associated with random uncertainty. 	['Poor', 'precision', 'measurements', 'associated', 'random', 'uncertainty']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Error associated with estimating the last digit of a reading is called random uncertainty. Random uncertainties arise mostly from limitations in the instrument. 	['Error', 'associated', 'estimating', 'last', 'digit', 'reading', 'called', 'random', 'uncertainty', 'Random', 'uncertainties', 'arise', 'mostly', 'limitations', 'instrument']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	This type of error is such that the value recorded is sometimes higher than the true value, sometimes lower.	['type', 'error', 'value', 'recorded', 'sometimes', 'higher', 'true', 'value', 'sometimes', 'lower']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Repeating the measurement a number of times and averaging the results reduces the effect of random uncertainty.	['Repeating', 'measurement', 'number', 'times', 'averaging', 'results', 'reduces', 'effect', 'random', 'uncertainty']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Usually，only one significant figure should be kept.	['one', 'significant', 'figure', 'kept']
3 IDX G9 CHEM S+.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Percentage uncertainty: The percentage uncertainty changes with the amount of material that you are measuring. Percentage uncertainty is also a guiding factor in choosing equipment for an experiment. 1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	3.1 What is Ecology?	['Ecology']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	A. Biosphere	['Biosphere']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Consists of all life on earth and all parts of the earth in which life exists	['Consists', 'life', 'earth', 'parts', 'earth', 'life', 'exists']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Atmosphere (gas), lithosphere (solid), hydrosphere (liquid)	['Atmosphere', 'gas', 'lithosphere', 'solid', 'hydrosphere', 'liquid']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- 11 km below sea level ~ 8km above sea level	['km', 'sea', 'level', 'sea', 'level']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	B. Ecology	['Ecology']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Ecology: The scientific study of interactions between organisms & environment	['Ecology', 'scientific', 'study', 'interactions', 'organisms', 'environment']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	C. Levels of Organisation	['Levels', 'Organisation']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	1) Individual organism	['Individual', 'organism']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- A species is a group of similar organisms that can breed and produce fertile offspring	['species', 'group', 'similar', 'organisms', 'breed', 'produce', 'fertile', 'offspring']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	2) Population	['Population']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Group of individuals that belong to the same species, area, and time	['Group', 'individuals', 'belong', 'species', 'area', 'time']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	3) Community	['Community']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- The assemblage of different populations that live together in the same area	['assemblage', 'different', 'populations', 'live', 'together', 'area']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	4) Ecosystem	['Ecosystem']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Organisms in the same community involving the physical environment	['Organisms', 'community', 'involving', 'physical', 'environment']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	5) Biome	['Biome']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- a group of ecosystems that share similar climates and typical organisms	['group', 'ecosystems', 'share', 'similar', 'climates', 'typical', 'organisms']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	6) Biosphere	['Biosphere']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- entire planet’s organism + physical environment.	['entire', 'planet', 'organism', 'physical', 'environment']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Biotic: living things	['Biotic', 'living', 'things']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Abiotic: non-living things	['Abiotic', 'things']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- the activities of organisms can influence abiotic factors	['activities', 'organisms', 'influence', 'abiotic', 'factors']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	D. Ecological method	['Ecological', 'method']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Observation: to use observations of natural phenomena to answer questions	['Observation', 'use', 'observations', 'natural', 'phenomena', 'answer', 'questions']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Experimentation: to test a hypothesis using designated processes	['Experimentation', 'test', 'hypothesis', 'using', 'designated', 'processes']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Modelling: to design a model based on real situations to observe and answer questions	['Modelling', 'design', 'model', 'based', 'real', 'situations', 'observe', 'answer', 'questions']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	3.2 Energy, Producers, and Consumers	['Energy', 'Producers', 'Consumers']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	A. Producers	['Producers']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Autotrophs: organisms that use solar /chemical energy to assemble inorganic compounds into complex (energy-rich) organic compounds	['Autotrophs', 'organisms', 'use', 'solar', 'energy', 'assemble', 'inorganic', 'compounds', 'complex', 'organic', 'compounds']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	B. Energy from the sun	['B', 'Energy', 'sun']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Photosynthesis: produce carbon hydrates such as sugars and starches with light energy	['Photosynthesis', 'produce', 'carbon', 'hydrates', 'sugars', 'starches', 'light', 'energy']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Formula: CO2 + H2O + Light energy → Carbohydrates + O2	['Formula', 'Light', 'energy', 'Carbohydrates']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	C. Life without light	['Life', 'without', 'light']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Chemosynthetic bacteria in the deep sea, volcanic vents, hot springs, etc.	['Chemosynthetic', 'bacteria', 'deep', 'sea', 'volcanic', 'vents', 'hot', 'springs', 'etc']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Formula: Co2 + Hydrogen sulfide + 02 → Carbohydrates + sulfur compounds	['Formula', 'Hydrogen', 'sulfide', 'Carbohydrates', 'sulfur', 'compounds']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	D. Consumers	['Consumers']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Heterotrophs: acquire energy from other organisms	['Heterotrophs', 'acquire', 'energy', 'organisms']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Carnivore: eat animals	['Carnivore', 'eat', 'animals']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Herbivore: eat plants	['Herbivore', 'eat', 'plants']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Omnivore: eat both plants and animals	['Omnivore', 'eat', 'plants', 'animals']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Scavenger: consumes the remains.	['Scavenger', 'consumes', 'remains']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Detritivores: ingest detritus particles 	['Detritivores', 'ingest', 'detritus', 'particles']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Decomposers: release digestive enzymes	['Decomposers', 'release', 'digestive', 'enzymes']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Saprotrophs: Living or non-living organic matter, secreting digestive enzymes into it and absorbing digestive product	['Saprotrophs', 'Living', 'organic', 'matter', 'secreting', 'digestive', 'enzymes', 'absorbing', 'digestive', 'product']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	3.3 Energy Flow in Ecosystem	['Energy', 'Flow', 'Ecosystem']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	A. Food chains & Fool webs	['Food', 'chains', 'Fool', 'webs']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- One way	['One', 'way']

1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Food chains: A series of steps in which organisms transfer energy by feeding	['Food', 'chains', 'series', 'steps', 'organisms', 'transfer', 'energy', 'feeding']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Vary in length	['Vary', 'length']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Phytoplankton: primary producers that are a mixture of floating algae.	['Phytoplankton', 'primary', 'producers', 'mixture', 'floating', 'algae']

1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Food chains show how energy moves through an ecosystem	['Food', 'chains', 'show', 'energy', 'moves', 'ecosystem']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- A food web shows how food chains interact	['food', 'web', 'shows', 'food', 'chains', 'interact']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Decomposers convert dead material to detritus	['Decomposers', 'convert', 'dead', 'material', 'detritus']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- releases nutrients 	['releases', 'nutrients']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- recycles nutrients	['recycles', 'nutrients']

1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	C. Trophic Level	['Trophic', 'Level']

1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	2.2 Properties of Water	['Properties', 'Water']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	A. Polarity	['Polarity']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- The greater probability of finding the shared electrons in the water close to its oxygen atom than near its hydrogen atoms	['greater', 'probability', 'finding', 'shared', 'electrons', 'water', 'close', 'oxygen', 'atom', 'near', 'hydrogen', 'atoms']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- The oxygen end has a slight negative charge and the hydrogen end has a slightly positive charge	['oxygen', 'end', 'slight', 'negative', 'charge', 'hydrogen', 'end', 'slightly', 'positive', 'charge']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Polar molecule: charges unevenly distributed.	['Polar', 'molecule', 'charges', 'unevenly', 'distributed']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	B) Hydrogen Bonding	['B', 'Hydrogen', 'Bonding']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Polar molecules such as water can attract each other.	['Polar', 'molecules', 'water', 'attract']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Hydrogen bond: the weak attraction between a hydrogen atom on one water molecule and the oxygen atom on another	['Hydrogen', 'bond', 'weak', 'attraction', 'hydrogen', 'atom', 'one', 'water', 'molecule', 'oxygen', 'atom', 'another']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	C) Cohesion	['C', 'Cohesion']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Attraction between molecules of the same substance	['Attraction', 'molecules', 'substance']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Surface tension	['Surface', 'tension']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	D) Adhesion	['Adhesion']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Attraction between molecules of different substances	['Attraction', 'molecules', 'different', 'substances']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Example:	['Example']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		-Meniscus: adhesion between water and glass molecules is stronger than the cohesion	['adhesion', 'water', 'glass', 'molecules', 'stronger', 'cohesion']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	between water molecules	['water', 'molecules']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Capillary Action: adhesion. between water and glass cause water to rise in a narrow tube against the force of gravity	['Capillary', 'Action', 'adhesion', 'water', 'glass', 'cause', 'water', 'rise', 'narrow', 'tube', 'force', 'gravity']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	E) Heat Capacity	['E', 'Heat', 'Capacity']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Amount of heat energy required to increase its temperature	['Amount', 'heat', 'energy', 'required', 'increase', 'temperature']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	F) Solutions	['F', 'Solutions']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- water polarity allows it to dissolve both ionic compounds and other polar molecules	['water', 'polarity', 'allows', 'dissolve', 'ionic', 'compounds', 'polar', 'molecules']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Solute: the substance that is dissolved	['Solute', 'substance', 'dissolved']

1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	6) The pH Scale	['pH', 'Scale']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- PH Scale: Measurement system to indicate the concentration of H+ ions in solution	['PH', 'Scale', 'Measurement', 'system', 'indicate', 'concentration', 'ions', 'solution']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- From 0 to 14	[]
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Basic: OH->H+	['Basic']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Neutral: OH- =H+	['Neutral']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Acidic: OH-<H+	['Acidic']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Lower PH, greater acidity, and less basic	['Lower', 'PH', 'greater', 'acidity', 'less', 'basic']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	3.4 Cycles of Matter	['Cycles', 'Matter']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	A. Recycling in the Biosphere	['Recycling', 'Biosphere']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Energy enters as light (trapped by photosynthesis) and usually loss as heat	['Energy', 'enters', 'light', 'trapped', 'photosynthesis', 'usually', 'loss', 'heat']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Matters/nutrients are recycled	['recycled']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Matter: anything that takes up space and has mass 	['Matter', 'anything', 'takes', 'space', 'mass']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Matter is never created/destroyed	['Matter', 'never']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Matter only change	['Matter', 'change']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	B) Energy flows and Nutrient Cycles	['B', 'Energy', 'flows', 'Nutrient', 'Cycles']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Energy enters from sunlight	['Energy', 'enters', 'sunlight']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Producers capture sunlight	['Producers', 'capture', 'sunlight']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Energy flows through the trophic levels in the food chain	['Energy', 'flows', 'trophic', 'levels', 'food', 'chain']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Energy transfer is approximately 10% from one level to the next	['Energy', 'transfer', 'approximately', 'one', 'level', 'next']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Energy transfers to detritivores or decomposers in dead organic matter	['Energy', 'transfers', 'detritivores', 'decomposers', 'dead', 'organic', 'matter']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Heat energy is lost through cell respiration	['Heat', 'energy', 'lost', 'cell', 'respiration']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Energy loss due to material not consumed	['Energy', 'loss', 'due', 'material', 'consumed']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Nutrients absorbed by a producer from the ecosystem	['Nutrients', 'absorbed', 'producer', 'ecosystem']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Nutrients move through the food chain by digestion of other organisms	['Nutrients', 'move', 'food', 'chain', 'digestion', 'organisms']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	C) The water cycle	['C', 'water', 'cycle']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	1) Evaporation: Water→ vapour	['Evaporation', 'vapour']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- Transpiration: water loss from plant leaves	['Transpiration', 'water', 'loss', 'plant', 'leaves']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	2) Condensation: cooling water vapour condenses into droplets around dust particles	['Condensation', 'cooling', 'water', 'vapour', 'condenses', 'droplets', 'around', 'dust', 'particles']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	3) Precipitation: Rain, sleet, snow, hail	['Precipitation', 'Rain', 'sleet', 'snow', 'hail']
1 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	4) Runoff: the flow of water occurring on the ground/underground	['Runoff', 'flow', 'water', 'occurring']

3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	 4.5 Aquatic Ecosystems	['Aquatic', 'Ecosystems']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	 Types of Aquatic Ecosystems	['Types', 'Aquatic', 'Ecosystems']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Freshwater Ecosystems	['Freshwater', 'Ecosystems']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	    - Rivers and Streams: Flowing water, high oxygen levels, diverse organisms adapted to current.	['Rivers', 'Streams', 'Flowing', 'water', 'high', 'oxygen', 'levels', 'diverse', 'organisms', 'adapted', 'current']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	    - Lakes and Ponds: Standing water, different zones (littoral, limnetic, profundal), seasonal changes.	['Lakes', 'Ponds', 'Standing', 'water', 'different', 'zones', 'littoral', 'limnetic', 'profundal', 'seasonal', 'changes']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Marine Ecosystems	['Marine', 'Ecosystems']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	    - Intertidal Zone: Area between high and low tides, organisms adapted to changing conditions.	['Intertidal', 'Zone', 'Area', 'high', 'low', 'tides', 'organisms', 'adapted', 'changing', 'conditions']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	    - Neritic Zone: Shallow ocean waters, high biodiversity, rich in nutrients.	['Neritic', 'Zone', 'Shallow', 'ocean', 'waters', 'high', 'biodiversity', 'rich', 'nutrients']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	    - Oceanic Zone: Open ocean, vast, low nutrient levels in some areas.	['Oceanic', 'Zone', 'Open', 'ocean', 'vast', 'low', 'nutrient', 'levels', 'areas']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	 Abiotic Factors in Aquatic Ecosystems	['Abiotic', 'Factors', 'Aquatic', 'Ecosystems']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Light: Penetration affects photosynthesis and varies with depth and water clarity.	['Light', 'Penetration', 'affects', 'photosynthesis', 'varies', 'depth', 'water', 'clarity']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Temperature: Influences metabolism and distribution of organisms.	['Temperature', 'Influences', 'metabolism', 'distribution', 'organisms']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Salinity: Affects osmosis in organisms, different levels in freshwater and marine ecosystems.	['Salinity', 'Affects', 'osmosis', 'organisms', 'different', 'levels', 'freshwater', 'marine', 'ecosystems']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	 Aquatic Organisms	['Aquatic', 'Organisms']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Producers: Phytoplankton (in marine) and algae (in freshwater) are primary producers.	['Producers', 'Phytoplankton', 'marine', 'algae', 'freshwater', 'primary', 'producers']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Consumers	['Consumers']

3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	    - Fish, crustaceans, and other larger animals are higher-level consumers.	['Fish', 'crustaceans', 'larger', 'animals', 'consumers']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Decomposers: Bacteria and fungi break down dead organic matter.	['Decomposers', 'Bacteria', 'fungi', 'break', 'dead', 'organic', 'matter']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	 5.1 How Populations Grow	['Populations', 'Grow']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	 Population Characteristics	['Population', 'Characteristics']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Population Size: Number of individuals in a population.	['Population', 'Size', 'Number', 'individuals', 'population']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Population Density: Number of individuals per unit area or volume.	['Population', 'Density', 'Number', 'individuals', 'per', 'unit', 'area', 'volume']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Dispersion: Patterns of how individuals are spaced in a population (clumped, uniform, random).	['Dispersion', 'Patterns', 'individuals', 'spaced', 'population', 'clumped', 'uniform', 'random']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	 Population Growth Models	['Population', 'Growth', 'Models']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Exponential Growth: Occurs when resources are unlimited and population size increases rapidly.	['Exponential', 'Growth', 'Occurs', 'resources', 'unlimited', 'population', 'size', 'increases', 'rapidly']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Logistic Growth: Population growth slows as it reaches the carrying capacity of the environment due to limited resources.	['Logistic', 'Growth', 'Population', 'growth', 'slows', 'reaches', 'carrying', 'capacity', 'environment', 'due', 'limited', 'resources']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	 Factors Affecting Population Growth	['Factors', 'Affecting', 'Population', 'Growth']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Birth Rate: Number of births per unit time.	['Birth', 'Rate', 'Number', 'births', 'per', 'unit', 'time']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Death Rate: Number of deaths per unit time.	['Death', 'Rate', 'Number', 'deaths', 'per', 'unit', 'time']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Immigration: Movement of individuals into a population.	['Immigration', 'Movement', 'individuals', 'population']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Emigration: Movement of individuals out of a population.	['Emigration', 'Movement', 'individuals', 'population']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	 5.2 Limits to Growth	['Limits', 'Growth']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	 Limiting Factors	['Limiting', 'Factors']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Density-Dependent Factors	['Factors']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	    - Competition for resources (food, space, mates) increases as population density rises.	['Competition', 'resources', 'food', 'space', 'mates', 'increases', 'population', 'density', 'rises']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	    - Predation and parasitism can have a greater impact on dense populations.	['Predation', 'parasitism', 'greater', 'impact', 'dense', 'populations']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	    - Disease spreads more easily in crowded populations.	['Disease', 'spreads', 'easily', 'crowded', 'populations']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Density-Independent Factors	['Factors']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	    - Natural disasters (fires, floods, earthquakes) can reduce population size regardless of density.	['Natural', 'disasters', 'fires', 'floods', 'earthquakes', 'reduce', 'population', 'size', 'regardless', 'density']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	    - Harsh weather conditions can affect survival.	['Harsh', 'weather', 'conditions', 'affect', 'survival']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	 Carrying Capacity	['Carrying', 'Capacity']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- The maximum number of individuals an environment can support over a long period.	['maximum', 'number', 'individuals', 'environment', 'support', 'long', 'period']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Populations tend to stabilise around the carrying capacity.	['Populations', 'tend', 'stabilise', 'around', 'carrying', 'capacity']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	 5.3 Human Population Growth	['Human', 'Population', 'Growth']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	 Historical Growth of the Human Population	['Historical', 'Growth', 'Human', 'Population']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Early Growth: Slow growth rate for most of human history due to high death rates (disease, famine, lack of medical knowledge). 3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Accelerated Growth: During the Industrial Revolution, improvements in agriculture, medicine, and sanitation led to decreased death rates and increased population growth.	['Accelerated', 'Growth', 'Industrial', 'Revolution', 'improvements', 'agriculture', 'medicine', 'sanitation', 'led', 'decreased', 'death', 'rates', 'increased', 'population', 'growth']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	 Patterns of Human Population Growth	['Patterns', 'Human', 'Population', 'Growth']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Developed Countries: Generally have lower birth rates and slower population growth, with some approaching zero population growth. 3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Developing Countries: Higher birth rates, but death rates are decreasing, leading to rapid population growth.	['Developing', 'Countries', 'Higher', 'birth', 'rates', 'death', 'rates', 'decreasing', 'leading', 'rapid', 'population', 'growth']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	 Factors Affecting Human Population Growth	['Factors', 'Affecting', 'Human', 'Population', 'Growth']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Birth Rates	['Birth', 'Rates']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	    - Cultural and religious beliefs can influence family size.	['Cultural', 'religious', 'beliefs', 'influence', 'family', 'size']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	    - Access to education and employment opportunities for women can lower birth rates.	['Access', 'education', 'employment', 'opportunities', 'women', 'lower', 'birth', 'rates']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Death Rates	['Death', 'Rates']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	    - Advances in medical technology and healthcare have reduced mortality.	['Advances', 'medical', 'technology', 'healthcare', 'reduced', 'mortality']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	    - Improved nutrition has increased life expectancy.	['Improved', 'nutrition', 'increased', 'life', 'expectancy']
3 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Migration: The movement of people between countries and regions affects population distribution.	['Migration', 'movement', 'people', 'countries', 'regions', 'affects', 'population', 'distribution']

2 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Energy enters as light (trapped by photosynthesis) and is usually lost as heat	['Energy', 'enters', 'light', 'trapped', 'photosynthesis', 'usually', 'lost', 'heat']

2 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	B) Energy Flows and Nutrient Cycles	['B', 'Energy', 'Flows', 'Nutrient', 'Cycles']
2 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Energy enters from sunlight	['Energy', 'enters', 'sunlight']
2 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Producers capture sunlight	['Producers', 'capture', 'sunlight']
2 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Energy flows through the trophic levels in the food chain	['Energy', 'flows', 'trophic', 'levels', 'food', 'chain']
2 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Energy transfer is approximately 10% from one level to the next	['Energy', 'transfer', 'approximately', 'one', 'level', 'next']
2 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Energy transfers to detritivores or decomposers in dead organic matter	['Energy', 'transfers', 'detritivores', 'decomposers', 'dead', 'organic', 'matter']
2 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Heat energy is lost through cell respiration	['Heat', 'energy', 'lost', 'cell', 'respiration']
2 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Energy loss due to material not consumed	['Energy', 'loss', 'due', 'material', 'consumed']
2 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Nutrients absorbed by a producer from the ecosystem	['Nutrients', 'absorbed', 'producer', 'ecosystem']

2 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	A) Solar Energy and the Greenhouse Effect	['Solar', 'Energy', 'Greenhouse', 'Effect']
2 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Greenhouse Effect	['Greenhouse', 'Effect']
2 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- 1) Solar energy arrives as sunlight strikes the earth’s surface	['Solar', 'energy', 'arrives', 'sunlight', 'strikes', 'earth', 'surface']
2 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- 2) Some of the solar energy is absorbed and converted into heat	['solar', 'energy', 'absorbed', 'converted', 'heat']
2 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- 3) Some heat (heat energy) radiates back into space, atmosphere gases trap some	['heat', 'heat', 'energy', 'radiates', 'back', 'space', 'atmosphere', 'gases', 'trap']
2 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38		- This is called the greenhouse effect, which maintains earth’s average temperature	['called', 'greenhouse', 'effect', 'maintains', 'earth', 'average', 'temperature']
2 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	- Greenhouse gases	['Greenhouse', 'gases']

2 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	E.g. where it lives, how it interacts with the environment 	['lives', 'interacts', 'environment']
2 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Resource	['Resource']
2 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Any necessity of life	['necessity', 'life']
2 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Tolerance	['Tolerance']
2 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The ability to survive and reproduce under a range of environmental circumstances 	['ability', 'survive', 'reproduce', 'range', 'environmental', 'circumstances']

2 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Expand more energy for homeostasis  less energy for growth and reproduction	['Expand', 'energy', 'homeostasis', 'less', 'energy', 'growth', 'reproduction']
2 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Determines habitat	['Determines', 'habitat']
2 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Competition	['Competition']
2 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Occurs when organisms attempt to use same limited ecological resource in same place and same time	['Occurs', 'organisms', 'attempt', 'use', 'limited', 'ecological', 'resource', 'place', 'time']

2 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	1. Helps determine number and kinds of species in community	['Helps', 'determine', 'number', 'kinds', 'species', 'community']

2 G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	1 species will be better at competing for limited sources and eventually exclude other species	['species', 'better', 'competing', 'limited', 'sources', 'eventually', 'exclude', 'species']

6 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Gene pool: All genes, including all diff. alleles for each gene that are present in population	['Gene', 'pool', 'genes', 'including', 'diff', 'alleles', 'gene', 'present', 'population']

6 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	When population is in genetic equilibrium/no evolution	['population', 'genetic', 'evolution']
6 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Allele frequencies in a population remain constant from generation to generation	['Allele', 'frequencies', 'population', 'remain', 'constant', 'generation', 'generation']
6 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Five conditions required:	['Five', 'conditions', 'required']

6 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	No mutation——No new alleles be introduced into the gene pool	['new', 'alleles', 'introduced', 'gene', 'pool']
6 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	No sexual selection——All members of the population must have an equal oppurtunity to produce offspring	['sexual', 'members', 'population', 'must', 'equal', 'oppurtunity', 'produce', 'offspring']
6 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	No migration——Population does not gain or lose alleles by any movement of individuals into or out of population	['gain', 'lose', 'alleles', 'movement', 'individuals', 'population']
6 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	No natural selection——No phenotype can have a selective advantage over another	['natural', 'phenotype', 'selective', 'advantage', 'another']

6 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	For a population in genetic equilibrium:	['population', 'genetic', 'equilibrium']
6 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	p+q=1	[]
6 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	(p+q)2=1	[]
6 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	p2+2pq+q2=1	[]
6 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	p=frequency of the dominant allele A	['dominant', 'allele']
6 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	q=frequency of the recessive allele a	['recessive', 'allele']
6 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	p2=frequency of genotype AA(homozygous dominant)	['genotype', 'AA', 'homozygous', 'dominant']
6 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	2pq=frequency of genotype Aa(heterozygous dominant)	['genotype', 'Aa', 'heterozygous', 'dominant']
6 IDX G9 BIO S.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	q2=frequency of genotype aa(homozygous dominant)	['genotype', 'aa', 'homozygous', 'dominant']

5 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	17.1 Genes and Variation	['Genes', 'Variation']
5 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Genetics: The scientific study of heredity	['Genetics', 'scientific', 'study', 'heredity']

5 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Genotype: Particular combination of alleles an organism carries	['Genotype', 'Particular', 'combination', 'alleles', 'organism', 'carries']

5 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Phenotype: All physical, physiological, and behavioral characteristics of an organism	['Phenotype', 'physical', 'physiological', 'behavioral', 'characteristics', 'organism']
5 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Genetics Joins Evolutionary Theory	['Genetics', 'Joins', 'Evolutionary', 'Theory']
5 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	1. Heritable traits are controlled by genes that are carried on chromosomes	['Heritable', 'traits', 'controlled', 'genes', 'carried', 'chromosomes']
5 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	2. Mutations in genes generate various alleles, generating variation	['Mutations', 'genes', 'generate', 'various', 'alleles', 'generating', 'variation']
5 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	3. Individuals with phenotypes better suited to their environment produce more offspring and pass on more copies of their genes	['Individuals', 'phenotypes', 'better', 'suited', 'environment', 'produce', 'offspring', 'pass', 'copies', 'genes']
5 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	4. Evolution is any change in the relative frequency of alleles in a population over time	['Evolution', 'change', 'relative', 'frequency', 'alleles', 'population', 'time']
5 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Sources of Genetic Variation	['Sources', 'Genetic', 'Variation']
5 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	1. Mutation	['Mutation']
5 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Any change in the genetic material of a cell (gene/chromosome mutation)	['change', 'genetic', 'material', 'cell', 'mutation']
5 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Can be beneficial, neutral or harmful, mostly neutral	['beneficial', 'neutral', 'harmful', 'mostly', 'neutral']
5 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Only mutations in germ line cells that produce gametes (sex cells) can be passed on to offspring	['mutations', 'germ', 'line', 'cells', 'produce', 'gametes', 'sex', 'cells', 'passed', 'offspring']
5 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	2. Sexual reproduction	['Sexual', 'reproduction']
5 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	1. Meiosis (crossing over produces new combinations of alleles, and independent assortment of homologous chromosomes)	['Meiosis', 'crossing', 'produces', 'new', 'combinations', 'alleles', 'independent', 'assortment', 'homologous', 'chromosomes']
5 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	2. Fertilization of sperm and egg	['Fertilization', 'sperm', 'egg']
5 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	3. Lateral gene transfer	['Lateral', 'gene', 'transfer']
5 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	An individual organism passes genes to another that is not its offspring	['individual', 'organism', 'passes', 'genes', 'another', 'offspring']
5 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Can be intraspecific or interspecific, increases genetic variation	['intraspecific', 'interspecific', 'increases', 'genetic', 'variation']
5 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	e.g., bacteria conjugation	['bacteria', 'conjugation']
5 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Single-Gene and Polygenic Traits	['Polygenic', 'Traits']
5 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	The number of phenotypes for a trait depends on how many genes control it	['number', 'phenotypes', 'trait', 'depends', 'many', 'genes', 'control']
5 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Single-Gene Traits	['Traits']
5 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	A trait controlled by only one gene	['trait', 'controlled', 'one', 'gene']
5 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	e.g., pea plant flower color, with two alleles and two phenotypes	['pea', 'plant', 'flower', 'color', 'two', 'alleles', 'two', 'phenotypes']
5 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	e.g., human blood type, with three alleles and four phenotypes	['human', 'blood', 'type', 'three', 'alleles', 'four', 'phenotypes']
5 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Polygenic Traits	['Polygenic', 'Traits']
5 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Traits controlled by two or more genes	['Traits', 'controlled', 'two', 'genes']
5 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Wide (and usually continuous) range of phenotypes, tends to show normal distribution	['Wide', 'usually', 'continuous', 'range', 'phenotypes', 'tends', 'show', 'normal', 'distribution']
5 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	Also influenced by environmental factors	['Also', 'influenced', 'environmental', 'factors']
5 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:38	e.g., human skin color is controlled by more than four genes	['human', 'skin', 'color', 'controlled', 'four', 'genes']

4 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	6.3 Biodiversity	['Biodiversity']
4 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	The Basics of Biodiversity	['Basics', 'Biodiversity']
4 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Biological diversity (a.k.a. biodiversity): the total of all the genetically based variation in all organisms in the biosphere	['Biological', 'diversity', 'biodiversity', 'total', 'genetically', 'based', 'variation', 'organisms', 'biosphere']
4 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Ecosystem diversity: the variety of habitats, communities, and ecological processes	['Ecosystem', 'diversity', 'variety', 'habitats', 'communities', 'ecological', 'processes']
4 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Species diversity: the number of different species in the biosphere or a certain area	['Species', 'diversity', 'number', 'different', 'species', 'biosphere', 'certain', 'area']
4 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Genetic diversity: the total of all different forms of genes present in a species	['Genetic', 'diversity', 'total', 'different', 'forms', 'genes', 'present', 'species']
4 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Richness: the number of different species present	['Richness', 'number', 'different', 'species', 'present']
4 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Evenness: how similar the abundance for each species present is	['Evenness', 'similar', 'abundance', 'species', 'present']
4 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Simpson’s Diversity Index	['Simpson', 'Diversity', 'Index']
4 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	 = the total number of organisms of a particular species ()	['total', 'number', 'organisms', 'particular', 'species']
4 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	 = the total number of organisms of all species ()	['total', 'number', 'organisms', 'species']

1 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	3.1 What is Ecology?	['Ecology']
1 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	The Basics	['Basics']
1 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Biosphere	['Biosphere']
1 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Consists of all life and all parts of the Earth with life	['Consists', 'life', 'parts', 'Earth', 'life']
1 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Ecology	['Ecology']
1 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Scientific study of interactions among organisms and between organisms and their physical environment	['Scientific', 'study', 'interactions', 'among', 'organisms', 'organisms', 'physical', 'environment']
1 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Greek root: oikos (house) 	['Greek', 'root', 'oikos', 'house']

1 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Levels of Organization (least to most inclusive)	['Levels', 'Organization', 'least', 'inclusive']
1 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	1. Individual organism	['Individual', 'organism']
1 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	2. Population: group of individuals of one species living in the same area	['Population', 'group', 'individuals', 'one', 'species', 'living', 'area']
1 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Species: similar organisms that can produce fertile offspring	['Species', 'similar', 'organisms', 'produce', 'fertile', 'offspring']
1 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	3. Community: all the different populations that live together in an area	['Community', 'different', 'populations', 'live', 'together', 'area']
1 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	4. Ecosystem: all organisms in an area together w/ their physical environment	['Ecosystem', 'organisms', 'area', 'together', 'physical', 'environment']
1 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	5. Biome: group of ecosystems sharing similar climates and organisms	['Biome', 'group', 'ecosystems', 'sharing', 'similar', 'climates', 'organisms']
1 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	6. Biosphere: our entire planet	['Biosphere', 'entire', 'planet']
1 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Environmental Factors	['Environmental', 'Factors']
1 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Environment: all conditions/factors surrounding an organism	['Environment', 'surrounding', 'organism']
1 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Biotic factor	['Biotic', 'factor']
1 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Biological	['Biological']
1 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Any living part of the environment an organism might interact with	['living', 'part', 'environment', 'organism', 'might', 'interact']

1 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Physical	['Physical']
1 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Any nonliving part of the environment	['nonliving', 'part', 'environment']
1 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	E.g., water availability and temperature for a bullfrog	['water', 'availability', 'temperature', 'bullfrog']

2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Some is reflected into space, some is absorbed and converted into heat (infrared radiation)	['reflected', 'space', 'absorbed', 'converted', 'heat', 'infrared', 'radiation']

2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Unequal distribution creates the tropical, temperate, and polar climate zones	['Unequal', 'distribution', 'creates', 'tropical', 'temperate', 'polar', 'climate', 'zones']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Heat transport in the biosphere 	['Heat', 'transport', 'biosphere']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Warm air (such as air near the equator) is less dense and rises, expanding and spreading north/south and losing heat along the way, sinking as it cools	['Warm', 'air', 'air', 'near', 'equator', 'less', 'dense', 'rises', 'expanding', 'spreading', 'losing', 'heat', 'along', 'way', 'sinking', 'cools']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Cool air (such as air near the poles) is denser and sinks toward the surface, pushing air at the surface outward and warming as it travels, rising as it warms	['Cool', 'air', 'air', 'near', 'poles', 'denser', 'sinks', 'toward', 'surface', 'pushing', 'air', 'surface', 'outward', 'warming', 'travels', 'rising', 'warms']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Earth’s rotation makes winds blow from west to east over temperate zones and east to west over the tropics and poles	['Earth', 'rotation', 'makes', 'winds', 'blow', 'west', 'east', 'temperate', 'zones', 'east', 'west', 'tropics', 'poles']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Warm currents add moisture and heat to air, while cool currents cool air	['Warm', 'currents', 'add', 'moisture', 'heat', 'air', 'cool', 'currents', 'cool', 'air']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Deep ocean currents are caused by cold water near the poles sinking	['Deep', 'ocean', 'currents', 'caused', 'cold', 'water', 'near', 'poles', 'sinking']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	The water rises in warmer regions through upwelling	['water', 'rises', 'warmer', 'regions', 'upwelling']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	4.2 Niches and Community Interactions	['Niches', 'Community', 'Interactions']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	The Niche	['Niche']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Tolerance	['Tolerance']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Ability to survive and reproduce under a range of environmental conditions	['Ability', 'survive', 'reproduce', 'range', 'environmental', 'conditions']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Organisms experience stress outside of their optimum range of tolerance	['Organisms', 'experience', 'stress', 'outside', 'optimum', 'range', 'tolerance']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Expends more energy on homeostasis, less for growth/reproduction	['Expends', 'energy', 'homeostasis', 'less']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Habitat	['Habitat']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	The place where an organism lives, determined by range of tolerance	['place', 'organism', 'lives', 'determined', 'range', 'tolerance']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Niche	['Niche']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	The role/position an organism has in its environment, unique to each species	['organism', 'environment', 'unique', 'species']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Comprises habitat, activity patterns, resources it obtains, etc.	['Comprises', 'habitat', 'activity', 'patterns', 'resources', 'obtains', 'etc']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Resource: a necessity of life (e.g., water, nutrients, light, food, space)	['Resource', 'necessity', 'life', 'water', 'nutrients', 'light', 'food', 'space']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Physical aspects: abiotic factors, such as water or temperature	['Physical', 'aspects', 'abiotic', 'factors', 'water', 'temperature']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Biological aspects: biotic factors, such as reproduction, diet	['Biological', 'aspects', 'biotic', 'factors', 'reproduction', 'diet']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Competition	['Competition']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	When organisms attempt to use the same limited ecological resource in the same place at the same time	['organisms', 'attempt', 'use', 'limited', 'ecological', 'resource', 'place', 'time']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Intraspecific (within the same species) or interspecific (between different species)	['Intraspecific', 'within', 'species', 'interspecific', 'different', 'species']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Shapes ecosystem by	['Shapes', 'ecosystem']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Determining number and kinds of species	['Determining', 'number', 'kinds', 'species']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Determining the niche each species occupies	['Determining', 'niche', 'species', 'occupies']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Causing species to divide resources	['Causing', 'species', 'divide', 'resources']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	The Competitive Exclusion Principle	['Competitive', 'Exclusion', 'Principle']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	No two species can occupy exactly the same niche in exactly the same habitat at exactly the same time (one will outcompete the other for resources)	['two', 'species', 'occupy', 'exactly', 'niche', 'exactly', 'habitat', 'exactly', 'time', 'one', 'outcompete', 'resources']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	As a result, species usually divide resources	['result', 'species', 'usually', 'divide', 'resources']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Predation, Herbivory, and Keystone Species	['Predation', 'Herbivory', 'Keystone', 'Species']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Predation (in predator-prey relationships) 	['Predation', 'relationships']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	An interaction in which one animal (the predator) captures and feeds on another animal (the prey)	['interaction', 'one', 'animal', 'predator', 'captures', 'feeds', 'another', 'animal', 'prey']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Can affect size of prey populations and where prey can live/feed	['affect', 'size', 'prey', 'populations', 'prey']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Herbivory (in herbivore-plant relationships)	['Herbivory', 'relationships']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	An interaction in which one animal (the herbivore) feeds on producers (such as plants)	['interaction', 'one', 'animal', 'herbivore', 'feeds', 'producers', 'plants']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Can affect size/distribution of plant populations where plants can survive/grow	['affect', 'plant', 'populations', 'plants']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Keystone Species	['Keystone', 'Species']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	A non-producer species that has a disproportionately large effect on its community relative to its abundance, where changes in its population can cause dramatic changes in the structure of a community	['species', 'disproportionately', 'large', 'effect', 'community', 'relative', 'abundance', 'changes', 'population', 'cause', 'dramatic', 'changes', 'structure', 'community']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	E.g., sea otters (sea urchin eaters), beavers and elephants (habitat creators)	['sea', 'otters', 'sea', 'urchin', 'eaters', 'beavers', 'elephants', 'habitat', 'creators']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Symbioses	['Symbioses']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Relationships in which two species live closely together	['Relationships', 'two', 'species', 'live', 'closely', 'together']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Mutualism (+/+)	['Mutualism']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Relationship in which both benefit	['Relationship', 'benefit']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	E.g., clownfish and anemone, rhinoceros and tickbird	['clownfish', 'anemone', 'rhinoceros', 'tickbird']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Parasitism (+/-)	['Parasitism']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Relationship in which one organism lives in/on another organism and harms it	['Relationship', 'one', 'organism', 'lives', 'another', 'organism', 'harms']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Generally, parasites weaken but do not kill their host	['Generally', 'parasites', 'weaken', 'kill', 'host']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	E.g., Tapeworms (in host), fleas, ticks, lice, leeches, mosquitoes (on host)	['Tapeworms', 'host', 'fleas', 'ticks', 'lice', 'leeches', 'mosquitoes', 'host']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Commensalism (+/0)	['Commensalism']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	One organism benefits and the other is neither helped nor harmed	['One', 'organism', 'benefits', 'neither', 'helped', 'harmed']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	E.g., barnacles and gray whales, remoras and sharks	['barnacles', 'gray', 'whales', 'remoras', 'sharks']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	4.3 Succession	['Succession']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Ecological Succession	['Ecological', 'Succession']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	A series of more-or-less predictable changes that occur in a community over time	['series', 'predictable', 'changes', 'occur', 'community', 'time']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Primary Succession	['Primary', 'Succession']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	The establishment of a community in an area of exposed rock that does not have any topsoil	['establishment', 'community', 'area', 'exposed', 'rock', 'topsoil']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Early stages can be very slow	['Early', 'stages', 'slow']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Pioneer species	['Pioneer', 'species']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	The first species to colonize barren areas	['first', 'species', 'colonize', 'barren', 'areas']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Lichen (a mutualistic symbiosis between a fungus and an alga) fix atmospheric N2, break down rock, add organic material to form soil	['Lichen', 'mutualistic', 'symbiosis', 'fungus', 'alga', 'fix', 'atmospheric', 'break', 'rock', 'add', 'organic', 'material', 'form', 'soil']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Mosses: simple plants	['Mosses', 'simple', 'plants']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Ferns/herbs/small shrubs come in and change the environment further	['shrubs', 'come', 'change', 'environment']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Trees come in, and their leaves provide shade and a cooler temperature	['Trees', 'come', 'leaves', 'provide', 'shade', 'cooler', 'temperature']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Over time, more and more species find a suitable niche and survive	['time', 'species', 'find', 'suitable', 'niche', 'survive']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Primary succession often follows:	['Primary', 'succession', 'often', 'follows']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Volcanic explosions creating new land or sterilizing existing areas	['Volcanic', 'explosions', 'creating', 'new', 'land', 'sterilizing', 'existing', 'areas']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Retreating glaciers leaving only exposed bare rock	['Retreating', 'glaciers', 'leaving', 'exposed', 'bare', 'rock']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Secondary Succession	['Secondary', 'Succession']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Occurs where existing communities are not completely destroyed by disturbances	['Occurs', 'existing', 'communities', 'completely', 'destroyed', 'disturbances']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Proceeds faster than primary succession	['Proceeds', 'faster', 'primary', 'succession']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Seeds, roots, and soil present	['Seeds', 'roots', 'soil', 'present']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Secondary succession often follows:	['Secondary', 'succession', 'often', 'follows']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Wildfires that destroy lots of plants but stimulate seed growth	['Wildfires', 'destroy', 'lots', 'plants', 'stimulate', 'seed', 'growth']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Hurricanes or other natural disturbances	['Hurricanes', 'natural', 'disturbances']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Human activities like logging and farming	['Human', 'activities', 'like', 'logging', 'farming']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Climax Communities	['Climax', 'Communities']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Ecological communities in the final stage of succession, in which the species composition is relatively stable	['Ecological', 'communities', 'final', 'stage', 'succession', 'species', 'composition', 'relatively', 'stable']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Natural disturbances are common in many communities, and secondary succession in healthy ecosystems following them often reproduce the original climax community	['Natural', 'disturbances', 'common', 'many', 'communities', 'secondary', 'succession', 'healthy', 'ecosystems', 'following', 'often', 'reproduce', 'original', 'climax', 'community']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	4.4 Biomes	['Biomes']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Major Biomes	['Major', 'Biomes']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Regional climates can often be affected by proximity to oceans or mountain ranges	['Regional', 'climates', 'often', 'affected', 'proximity', 'oceans', 'mountain', 'ranges']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	E.g., cold/warm ocean currents, leeward/windward side of a mountain	['ocean', 'currents', 'side', 'mountain']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Biomes are described in terms of abiotic factors like climate and soil type, and biotic factors like plant and animal life	['Biomes', 'described', 'terms', 'abiotic', 'factors', 'like', 'climate', 'soil', 'type', 'biotic', 'factors', 'like', 'plant', 'animal', 'life']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	1. Tropical Rainforest	['Tropical', 'Rainforest']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Tall trees form a dense covering called a canopy 50-80m above the forest floor	['Tall', 'trees', 'form', 'dense', 'covering', 'called', 'canopy', 'forest', 'floor']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Below, shorter trees and vines form a layer called the understory	['shorter', 'trees', 'vines', 'form', 'layer', 'called', 'understory']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Abiotic: high precipitation; nutrient-poor soil	['Abiotic', 'high', 'precipitation', 'soil']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Plant life: large leaves maximize sunlight in understory, tall trees have buttress roots, epiphytic plants grow on branches of tall trees (commensalism)	['Plant', 'life', 'large', 'leaves', 'maximize', 'sunlight', 'understory', 'tall', 'trees', 'buttress', 'roots', 'epiphytic', 'plants', 'grow', 'branches', 'tall', 'trees', 'commensalism']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Animal life: camouflage / color-changing / climbing / jumping / flight adaptations	['Animal', 'life', 'camouflage', 'climbing', 'jumping', 'flight', 'adaptations']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	2. Tropical Dry Forest	['Tropical', 'Dry', 'Forest']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Rainy and dry seasons, droughts follow periods of rain	['Rainy', 'dry', 'seasons', 'droughts', 'follow', 'periods', 'rain']

2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Plant life: deciduous, waxy leaves, and store water in tissues to survive dry seasons	['Plant', 'life', 'deciduous', 'waxy', 'leaves', 'store', 'water', 'tissues', 'survive', 'dry', 'seasons']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Animal life: enter estivation (≈ hibernation) or migrate during dry seasons	['Animal', 'life', 'enter', 'estivation', 'hibernation', 'migrate', 'dry', 'seasons']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	3. Tropical Grassland / Savanna / Shrubland	['Tropical', 'Grassland', 'Savanna', 'Shrubland']

2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Animal life: Migrate or burrow and remain dormant in dry seasons	['Animal', 'life', 'Migrate', 'burrow', 'remain', 'dormant', 'dry', 'seasons']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	4. Desert	['Desert']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Abiotic: low precipitation; varying temp.; mineral-rich, organic-material-poor soil	['Abiotic', 'low', 'precipitation', 'varying', 'temp', 'soil']

2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Animal life: often nocturnal, large ears and other extremities to lose body heat	['Animal', 'life', 'often', 'nocturnal', 'large', 'ears', 'extremities', 'lose', 'body', 'heat']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	5. Temperate Grassland	['Temperate', 'Grassland']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Abiotic: seasonal temperature change; moderate rain; fertile soil; occasional fires	['Abiotic', 'seasonal', 'temperature', 'change', 'moderate', 'rain', 'fertile', 'soil', 'occasional', 'fires']

2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	7. Temperate Forest	['Temperate', 'Forest']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Fertile soils rich in humus, a material formed from decaying leaves and other organic matter	['Fertile', 'soils', 'rich', 'humus', 'material', 'formed', 'decaying', 'leaves', 'organic', 'matter']

2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Animal life: many hibernate or migrate, others have camouflage in the winter	['Animal', 'life', 'many', 'hibernate', 'migrate', 'others', 'camouflage', 'winter']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	8. Northwestern Coniferous Forest	['Northwestern', 'Coniferous', 'Forest']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Abiotic: mild temp; cool dry summers; abundant rain out of summer; rocky acidic soil	['Abiotic', 'mild', 'temp', 'cool', 'dry', 'summers', 'abundant', 'rain', 'summer', 'rocky', 'acidic', 'soil']

2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Animal life: extra insulation in fat / downy feathers or migrate for winter	['Animal', 'life', 'extra', 'insulation', 'fat', 'downy', 'feathers', 'migrate', 'winter']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	10. Tundra	['Tundra']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Permafrost, a layer of permanently frozen subsoil, limits plant height	['Permafrost', 'layer', 'permanently', 'frozen', 'subsoil', 'limits', 'plant', 'height']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Abiotic: strong winds; low precipitation; short and soggy summers; long, cold, dark winters; poorly developed soils; permafrost	['Abiotic', 'strong', 'winds', 'low', 'precipitation', 'short', 'soggy', 'summers', 'long', 'cold', 'dark', 'winters', 'poorly', 'developed', 'soils', 'permafrost']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Plant life: mosses and other plants grow low to avoid strong winds, legumes have nitrogen-fixing bacteria to adapt to poor soil, seed dispersal by wind is common	['Plant', 'life', 'mosses', 'plants', 'grow', 'low', 'avoid', 'strong', 'winds', 'legumes', 'bacteria', 'adapt', 'poor', 'soil', 'seed', 'dispersal', 'wind', 'common']
2 G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Animal life: many migrate to avoid winters, year-round residents have adaptations such as natural antifreeze, small extremities that limit heat loss, and a varied diet	['Animal', 'life', 'many', 'migrate', 'avoid', 'winters', 'residents', 'adaptations', 'natural', 'antifreeze', 'small', 'extremities', 'limit', 'heat', 'loss', 'varied', 'diet']

3 IDX G9 BIO H.docx	2025-04-04 19:31:39	Carrying capacity: max number of individuals in a species that an environment can support long term	['Carrying', 'capacity', 'max', 'number', 'individuals', 'species', 'environment', 'support', 'long', 'term']
